contributors.bio: I am a car geek dating back to my childhood, when I took notice of the various sizes, shapes, and designs of cars. I named all of our family cars and cried when they reached the end of their useful life. I’ve been mentally composing automotive reviews for years, but it wasn’t until some years ago, when I read one of Jean Jennings's columns while waiting for an appointment, that I realized that it was possible. And here I am… grateful and enjoying every second. My next goal in life is to learn to drive a manual.

pageElements.text: Just when I thought the Porsche Macan debut had taken my breath away, Kia came along and debuted the gorgeous K900, a top-of-the-line rear-wheel-drive sedan that's slated for sale in the spring.

Kia deeply embeds itself in the luxury-sedan segment with the K900. Featuring smooth, gorgeous lines and a very luxurious equipment list, it is truly a beauty. A well-appointed interior with high-quality materials throughout makes it a worthy competitor with other cars in this segment. I was beyond impressed.

The Kia K900 received a welcome worthy of the brand's new flagship, with a lavish multimedia production featuring live violinists and a lush soundtrack for the car's entrance. Better than a movie premiere, the car's introduction and unveiling only hinted at its true beauty and elegance. After all, this is the Korean automaker's attempt to put a luxury sedan up against some pretty intense competition out there.
Buyers will have their choice of 3.8-liter 311-horsepower V-6 or, for extra power, a 5.0-liter V-8 that makes 420 horsepower, both teamed with an eight-speed transmission.

Prices weren't officially announced, but expect the K900 to start at around $50,000. Various options include a huge 12.3-inch color screen, a head-up display (Kia's first), and a seventeen-speaker, 900-watt Lexicon audio system.  A panoramic sunroof, park assist, and a host of other features make this car worthy of its star status. Can you tell I love this car?

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The week before Thanksgiving, I was thanking Volkswagen of America for hosting me along with a merry band of journalists at the Los Angeles Auto Show press preview days. They left a 2013 Tiguan for me at the airport because I arrived a day before everyone else in order to set up camp in my room at The Standard hotel.

I started Monday bright and early, ready to field back-to-back radio interviews across the country to talk about Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Automobile of the Year. Not quite early enough. I began the busy morning by missing my first interview with Detroit hometown hero and recent inductee in the National Radio Hall of Fame, WJR’s Paul W. Smith.
Arrgghhhhh.
Paul W. announced the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray as Automobile of the Year without my sugary, weepy patter, as he told me the next day, when I was graciously rescheduled.

After that, though, surrounded by a zillion notes (“don’t forget to mention automobilemag.com as much as possible”), I leapt from call to call, crisscrossing the nation’s radio waves, talking about Corvette; Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Man of the Year, chief Vette engineer Tadge “Don’t Take No for an Answer” Juechter; the city of Detroit; the industry; and even threw in a little JeanKnowsCars.com while I was at it.

I picked up JKC videographer Scott Allen and my husband, Tim, from LAX and headed to a late lunch and a stiff Bloody Mary at The Standard. I couldn’t wait to show Tim the shower and its clear glass viewing wall next to the bed. Enforced voyeurism is really not our thing. I checked at the reception desk to see if there was a room with a private bathroom. No luck. An entire hotel built for voyeurs. We decided on staggered breakfast shifts so the other could shower in privacy.
Enough of that visual. Good night.

You might have seen my chaotic auto show videos. It is always like that for me. But this year in L.A. I decided that Scott and I would focus only on shooting as many car designers as we could manage, talking about the hottest car on their stands. We’ll roll out these videos over the next few weeks in Jean’s Driveway, where we have a special section called Designer Walkaround.

In between designer appointments, I gave BMW design head Adrian van Hooydonk Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Design of the Year for the brilliant i8, a car the Automobile’s design editor, Robert Cumberford, praised as retaining “all the spirit and sense of the show car’s Blade Runner futurism in something we can buy and drive in 2014.” Amen.
I also gave GM North America president Mark Reuss his well-deserved 2014 AOY trophy for the Stingray. His favorite color Stingray is blue, so that’s where we posed.

Your title here...

I managed to miss all of the important reveals, which meant I missed (not) being mashed in the crowd with the other several thousands of journalists, bloggers, and people who managed to sneak in. Instead, I carefully timed my walk of the vast show (covering two large halls) to arrive when most everyone else had surged on to the next announcement. This gave me a perfect opportunity to do a lightning walk of the Audi exhibit. Four different iterations of the soon-to-be-hot A3 were on stage just on Wednesday, and we got the shorthand version of what and when from product manager Anthony Foulk:

No parties for me, which meant I missed (not) dubious celebrities Simon Cowell and Kelly Osbourne at the Jaguar party. Instead, I visited the new Jaguar F-Type coupe on the stand with chief designer Ian Callum and shared the great news of his brother Moray’s elevation to the top design job at Ford in the wake of the sudden departure of J Mays. I also ran into Moray, who was as calm and beatific as I had ever seen him. “Hold that feeling close,” I told him. “There will be blood.”
There always is.

Thursday was a much quieter day at the show, where I spent a pleasant morning looking at what I’d missed in the crowd and doing a live interview with another WJR radio luminary, Frank Beckmann. I also discovered that one of my interviews was picked up by Howard Stern. He made fun of my voice, which is only slightly more mockable than my overall demeanor. You go, Howard!
The best part of the day was heading out to Hollywood Park, a ripped-up, lumpy, vast parking lot in a dicey neighborhood, to drive some crazy VWs. Stand by for my report on that later this week.

contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pages.metaDescription: Dr. Pascale Gousseland's love for her new Mini Cooper Countryman, as narrated to Elizabeth Sobieski.
pages.name: index

pageElements.text: “My car 'ees' so stylish and so much fun!” says Dr. Pascale Gousseland, a New York-based French psychoanalyst specializing in family practice, addiction, and personality disorders. We are in a covered parking garage on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, and Pascale points to a copper-hued (she calls the color “cognac”) crossover with white hood stripes. It's her new Mini Countryman.

As a young student at the Sorbonne in Paris, Pascale scooted around the Place de l’Etoile, the insane traffic circle that revolves around the Arc de Triomphe where twelve boulevards converge, in a dark blue Mini that she absolutely adored. There were neither airbags nor air conditioning in the iconic two-door vehicle, and the only "très cool" option was a radio. She eventually had to replace that spirited car with other Minis, which tended to break down after meeting too many potholes.

From the Continent to the Continental

Pascale's family then did the unthinkable (for Parisians)! They moved to the United States, and her father, Pierre, became passionate about large American automobiles, what Pascale calls “boat cars”: Cadillacs and Lincoln Continentals offering an automatic ride that seemed to float compared with the old manual-transmission Minis, which served passengers a “tape-cul”: a sore butt on a long drive. Her father’s final Lincoln was “spacious and gracious,” according to Pascale, who is also a published poet. And when her father died nine years ago, she inherited his beloved 1994 vehicle.

The Lincoln was a good car for making jaunts to her weekend home in Greenwich, Connecticut. Her three not petite dogs were able to travel in luxury. But after 137,000 miles, it was time to retire that silver ship.

Mini Nostalgia Claims Another Customer

And Pascale immediately thought about the speedy small cars of her youth. She had begun to notice more Minis in New York and wondered about the newest models. The original inexpensive front-wheel-drive BMC Mini Coopers were top-drawer rally racing cars in the 1960s that eventually became the most popular British automobiles ever made. But now the Mini name was part of Germany's BMW.

At the dealership in White Plains, New York, she test-drove several models: the Clubman, the Paceman, and the Countryman, and was impressed. The new Minis felt solid, the ride as smooth as that of a “boat car,” and she admired the retro styling. She returned to the dealer with her three dogs and a blanket, and the dealer allowed her to try the various models for canine-carrying size. She saw that the dogs, Matheo, Scottee, and Foo, immediately relaxed in the Mini Cooper S Countryman ALL4, a four-door hatchback with a back seat that flattens. There's no space relinquished to a spare tire, as the car features run-flat tires that can sustain themselves for fifty miles when punctured. And the rear windows supplied unobstructed viewing for the dogs.
It is a happy, funny, original car. You feel very comfortable inside. It is full of little gadgets. And I feel safe, which was never true in the old Mini.

Delighted with what she encountered, she ordered the cognac-colored car with extensive options, including all-wheel drive, a two-tone leather interior, Bluetooth and USB connectivity, a sunroof, xenon headlights, an adjustable traction control system, keyless entry, rear parking sensors, auto-dimming mirrors, heated mirrors, and an automatic transmission. And it boasts a terrific Harman Kardon ten-speaker audio system, mocking the tinny radio of old.

Although her Mini only has a 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, the S model is turbocharged, producing 181 horsepower and 177 pound-feet of torque. Pascale tells me: “It is a happy, funny, original car. You feel very comfortable inside. It is full of little gadgets. And I feel safe, which was never true in the old Mini. My new car has seven airbags!"

The Car for a City Dweller

The garage attendant brings the handsome Mini out to the street, and we drive downtown. The car is so agile and easy to park! Pascale notes she can always find parking places in the city, even though the Mini dwells in the garage at night. Its fuel economy averages 26 miles per gallon, and the warranty covers four years or 50,000 miles, with free maintenance for the first three years or 36,000 miles.

The dashboard looks typically English, even though Mini has been owned by BMW for twenty years. Like its driver, this car is very international. The Countryman engine is still manufactured in the U.K., the transmission is from Japan, and the car was assembled in Graz, Austria. And a Countryman ALL4 won the Dakar Rally in 2013.
While her father’s beloved old Lincoln still exists in her mother’s garage, Pascale now gets to zip around New York City looking "très chic" in her Mini that now has all the comfort of a Maxi.

images.caption: Pascale and Mini Cooper S Countryman.
The white racing stripe is part of the "happy, funny, original" feeling Pascale likes.
She manages to find room for three dogs in the car.
Tres chic, says French expatriate Dr. Pascale Gousseland.
Even though Jean Knows Cars believes in harnesses for dogs in the car, check out how well three large dogs fit in this Countryman!

pageElements.text: Once you arrive at an auto show—especially one like the Los Angeles Auto Show, which has two large halls that take some time to cover in detail—it's hard to get outside. And once you do get outside, you are in downtown L.A., surrounded by triple-decker freeways jammed with cars that are frequently stopped cold, and a sky the color of seven-layer bean dip.

But my L.A. show host, Volkswagen of America, planned a fun couple of hours driving a trio of oddball Volkswagens at Hollywood Park, a vast parking lot in Inglewood, California, within a thirty-minute drive of the show. Make that a one-hour drive at 1 p.m. Well, let's just say that once committed to leaving the show, I abandoned the idea of ever getting back to it the same day. The traffic was even more horrendous than normal, so the idea of driving any cars at all without the great mass of southern California humanity pressing upon me from all sides seemed sweet indeed. When I arrived at the Hollywood Park, I noticed the sky was getting blacker by the minute and looked like it was going to pour rain, which, by the way, it very rarely does in L.A. The wind was whipping like hell, and it was not warm in the least.

While a couple of other journalists were out on the course, I headed for the al fresco lounge that VW had set up in the parking lot (as one does when entertaining the automotive press), complete with a gourmet food truck, to have a warm cup of coffee and a bowl of chili. Much to my surprise, there was Hans Stuck, Hurley Haywood’s old Audi teammate back when Audi dominated Trans-Am racing. All I could think about when I saw him was the famous story about when Stuck and a racing buddy were waiting for a flight from a race in Australia back to Germany and decided to kill time taking the rental car for a little drive out of town into the Outback.

During the course of the drive, they nailed a random kangaroo with the rental. They jumped from the car and stared at this dead kangaroo lying in the middle of the road, when crazy Stucky got a crazy idea. They sat the dead kangaroo up on his feet, dressed it in Stuck’s sport coat and hat, and just when they were about to take a picture of Stuck with the deceased (but quite dapper) kangaroo, it came to life and hopped off into the Outback. It was still wearing Stuck’s sport coat.

Problem was, the sport coat held Stuck’s return ticket and passport. We can only imagine Stuck and friend explaining themselves to the local Australian authorities. If that story is apocryphal, it doesn't really matter, does it?

I write of kangaroos and food trucks because I had forgotten that driving concept cars was not really my idea of a good time. It’s like writing. It’s fun to have written, but not so much fun to write.

Volkswagen XL1 Concept

My first drive was in the XL1, revealed at the 2011 Qatar Auto Show and promised by Dr. Martin Winterkorn, VW’s chairman, to be in production by 2013. The last I looked, 2013 was winding quickly down, and the car I drove was definitely not ready for prime time. At least not in America. Never mind that VW has in fact sold fifty XL1s in Germany for about $150,000 apiece. The harshness and noise would make this car totally unacceptable here. The whole purpose of the car was to be a hyper-fuel-efficient exercise, a “one-liter car” in that it could go 100 kilometers on one little liter of fuel. After several years of trying and several iterations, this current XL1 actually beat the goal, achieving 100 km on 0.9 liter of diesel fuel.

VW engineers employed every aero, every fuel economy, and every weight-saving trick it had learned in the nine years it worked on the one-liter car. The ingredients: a slippery body (rearview cameras replaced side mirrors) with a Cd of .189, a lightweight monocoque made of carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer, polycarbonate side windows, and a Volkswagen TwinDrive plug-in hybrid powerplant allowing separate or tandem operation of a lithium-ion battery, an electric motor, and a one-liter, two-cylinder TDI engine.

One reason cars weigh a lot is that they’re heavily padded to create a magic carpet ride and a quiet womb for the driver. With every scrap of non-essential padding gone and the rear-mounted diesel essentially sitting behind my head, the XL1 was all lumbering rattletrap with no magic carpet ride to write home about.

Still. Do the kilometers-to-miles conversion. If VW actually brings this incredible accomplishment to the American public, 261 miles per gallon may be worth putting up with a few body noises, suspension thumps, and diesel rattles. But for $150,000, I think I want my cake and I want to eat it, too.

Volkswagen Design Vision GTI

The Design Vision GTI was revealed during VW’s press conference earlier in the day as an exercise showing how far Volkswagen could go in making the most futuristic, the most extreme GTI they could conceive of. It looks pretty damn cool.

This GTI has a twin-turbo V-6 making 503 horsepower, a 0-to-62-mph time of 3.9 seconds, and a top speed of 186 mph. So it makes sense that it was first seen at the Worthersee tuner show in Germany, and it also makes sense that VW is bragging it “eats any type of racetrack.” We would not be eating Hollywood Park this afternoon.

The Vision was much more finished than the XL1, but also a concept-car queen. When I jumped in, I was asked not to make any tight turns and to just drive conservatively around the big wide oval cone course that was set up for our “amusement.”

Only it's never really amusing to drive concept cars. Maybe it’s slightly cool to be seen moving inside one, but not so amusing. There was one moment of fun, though. In both of these concept cars, we drove around a very simple track. It was basically a large swath of asphalt with a slight curve and a breaking point at the end of it through one tight-ish turn that brought us back to the start. On the other side of the parking lot, facing us, I spotted the LAPD doing police car testing. I admit that the devil in me wished I had a super hot GTI and a full-blown slalom course that I could scream through, squealing the tires all the way, and scare the crap out of the cop cars facing us on the other side of the parking lot. Yes, I know. Very juvenile.

APR Super Beetle

The hottest car at Hollywood Park was conceived by the rabid VW fanboys of VWvortex.com and built by APR Motorsport, one of VW’s racing supplier partners. It was unveiled at the 2012 Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) Show, where it won the Gran Turismo Best European Import at SEMA 2012 award for its utter fabulosity.

“A Super Beetle should be super, and to us that means adding all-wheel drive and 500 horsepower to a bone stock Turbo Beetle,” wrote VWvortex.com editor Jamie Vondruska, a month before SEMA in 2012. “And thus our latest project car is born. Yes, we’re excited.”

Of course the first thing APR did was see just how much power that basic turbo engine could produce without actually doing anything to it. They got all the way up to 420 horsepower on standard pistons and rods before they blew the engine. These guys are a laugh riot. Once they got that out of their system, they went to town making an incredibly robust 500-horsepower racing engine for the car from one of the best engines on the planet. Once you do that, you'd better have a suspension and brakes that can handle the power. So the APR Super Beetle gets an H&R adjustable coil-over suspension with VW Racing StreetSport+ camber plates and H&R Sport sway bars, plus more suspension modifications from APR's work on the Audi TT RS. Brakes are from Volkswagen Racing to handle what VW described as "more rigorous stopping duties." I don't know what VW plans to do with this car now that I've had a shot at it, but the result was my idea of a proper show car. One you could drive the wheels off.

Carry on, boys!
To those few Neanderthals on the VWvortex.com site, yes, indeed, the APR Super Beetle is "still a car for girls." Hahaha, goofballs! It's for girls who will use it to kick your sissy butts.

God bless you, Jamie. I peeled off three laps of the quick and dirty cone course set up just for the APR Super Beetle (man, this was some terrible pavement, and what was with the ditch right through the middle of the course ?!?) before the rain came.  When the sky finally dumped, the VW handlers came out and shut us down, putting an end to a most amusing afternoon. Those three laps were worth the trip out from the convention center, and definitely a lot more fun than a second day of clomping around the L.A. Auto Show.
If I'd worn a hat, I'd have tipped it to VW for bringing the auto show spirit to life out on the track.

title: A Rolls-Royce Kitchen Make-Over
subTitle: The Rolls-Royce Wraith's bespoke designer reimagines my New York City kitchen.
promoTeaserSmall: The Rolls-Royce Wraith's bespoke designer reimagines my New York City kitchen.
promoTeaser: The Rolls-Royce Wraith's bespoke designer reimagines my New York City kitchen.
metaTitle: A Rolls-Royce Kitchen Make-Over - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Rolls-Royce Kitchen Make-Over: Rolls Bespoke designer Alex Innes helped me dream up the Rolls of kitchen remodels. See what we came up with on JeanKnowsCars.com..

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: When I get around to renovating my eighty-four-square-foot NYC kitchen, I want to adapt the best features from a well-designed car. After years of being in the automotive business, I am constantly awed by the innovative ways that vehicles are engineered to be more streamlined, more efficient, more technologically advanced, and ultimately more sustainable.  With that in mind, I went straight to the top for advice.

At the recent reveal of the 2014 Rolls-Royce Wraith in Scottsdale, Arizona, I sat down with Alex Innes, bespoke designer for Rolls-Royce. Bespoke, in brief, means custom made. As in, you can have your Wraith coupe painted in a favorite shade of red nail polish, have your initials woven into the leather seats, or use a tree from your personal forest to outfit the interior. For any of your automotive whims or desires having to do with outfitting your Rolls-Royce, Innes is the go-to man.
After showing Innes my Pinterest folder of images of my non-bespoke (and rather cluttered and tiny) New York City kitchen, I asked him a few questions.
Holly Reich: Do you think you can do anything to help me streamline my small kitchen, taking cues from the Rolls-Royce Wraith?
Alex Innes: On the interior of the Rolls-Royce Wraith, our interior design philosophy is not to bombard the customer with a lot of choices. A kitchen should be clean and quiet.
HR: I’ll go with that. So, what is one of your favorite parts of the Wraith’s interior?

AI: I like the Canadel paneling in the cabin. [Canadel, an open-grain wood imported from Asia, has a light satin finish and is meant to suggest the feel of a super-luxury yacht.]

The Canadel would also be incredibly practical to use in your kitchen because it has a sealed polyester backer. The wood grain in the Wraith is matched up [the grains are at the same angle] throughout the interior; the same could be done in your kitchen.

From there I knew I had Innes's attention. I presented him with a sheet of white printer paper, and we both started sketching. By the way, I wasn’t so far off base. He told me that this is exactly the way he works with a bespoke Rolls-Royce client.
HR: Let’s start with the splash back behind the oven and sink.

AI: I can imagine using a strip of piano black paneling with Canadel wood above it. I would install a single strip of frosted glass—a glowing bar like the ones we have behind our door handles—between the two surfaces. As for the sideboard, I would use satin chrome.  We could hide the sink area with a hood. One would press a button to flip it up and expose the sink and drying board. And the tap would also rise as the hood sinks.
Inside the cupboard, we’d have something like self-ejecting parts. Like the butler is offering you the plate you want to use; you wouldn’t have to reach to get it.
HR: What about the cabinets?

AI: Our doors are hinged to open and close quietly, as would the cabinet doors in your kitchen. One would press a button to open and close them. Inside the cupboard, we’d have something like self-ejecting parts. Like the butler is offering you the plate you want to use; you wouldn’t have to reach to get it. It would be an offering device, like the umbrellas we have in the Wraith [an umbrella is stowed inside the driver’s door]. You would simply push a button, and whatever you need would pop out.
HR: Do you mean that the pots, pans, plates, and glasses could fold out?
AI: Yes. For instance, the plates would fan out on tiers. It’s the perfect mechanical solution.
HR: What should we line the cabinets with?
AI: They would be Canadel veneer on the bottom; the rest would be satin steel. And the angles of the wood would line up with the wood above the sink and the wood floor.
HR: Do you have any suggestions for the appliances?

AI: We would get the Rolls-Royce of refrigerators and appliances. [He suggested the stylish products of Smeg USA.] The refrigerator would have a glass front, to mimic the panoramic roofs on some of our vehicles.
HR: I would love to use that gorgeous aquamarine-colored glass you have in your vehicles for my lighting.
Oh, yes, that Lalique-like frosted look in our cars. We could use it as soft ambient boulevard lighting under the cabinets.

AI: Oh, yes, that Lalique-like frosted look in our cars. We could use it as soft ambient boulevard lighting under the cabinets. The spots would come from underneath the cabinets and light up the satin surface of the sideboards. We could also use the starlight headliner as pulsing overhead lights in the ceiling. [The starlight headliner on the Wraith features thousands of tiny fiber-optic lamps hand woven by craftspeople into the roof lining.]
HR: May I keep my blackboard?
AI: The key thing is that it’s a living space, so you want to enjoy it. I guess you could keep the blackboard. [I think he wasn’t too keen on it…]
HR: Any last touches?

AI: We have a guy in Goodwood who paints a narrow pinstripe by hand all the way around the top shoulder of the Wraith. You could have a hand-painted line on front of the cupboards in any color you choose.
HR: I think I’ll do a Salamanca blue, the color of the Rolls-Royce Wraith that I drove today.
Endnote: As driven, the Wraith I tested came in at $359,150, including destination charge. To outfit my Rolls-Royce kitchen would come in at around $75,000.

title: 2014 Fiat 500L Easy
subTitle: The Italian icon has expanded to MPV size. Is it adorable or bloated? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: The Italian icon has expanded to MPV size. Is it adorable or bloated? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: The Italian icon has expanded to MPV size. Is it adorable or bloated? Here's what we think.
metaTitle: 2014 Fiat 500L Easy - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Fiat 500L Easy: The Italian icon has expanded to MPV size. Is it adorable or bloated? Here's what we think. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
2014 Fiat 500L Easy

Price: $25,545 as tested, including destination
Engine: 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 160 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/33 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Glass A-pillars
Option I can’t live without: Rearview camera and ParkSense rear park assist (both part of Premier package, $1,745)
You might also be considering: Kia Soul, Nissan Cube, Mini Cooper Countryman

What I Think:

I had been waiting eagerly since the hottest days of summer to get into Fiat's new 500L, and when my turn finally arrived, it was during the first snowstorm of the season. Well, that's part of the package when you live in Michigan, but instead of fulfilling my dream of la dolce vita with the sun streaming through the imported windows of the boxy "urban utility vehicle" from Fiat, I was scraping a thick layer of snow and ice off the windows. Instead of joyriding, carefree, around downtown Ann Arbor, I was gingerly navigating icy roads. But it wasn't all bad; I only had to unstick from drifts on the roadside twice in one day.

Seriously, though, the real test of livability is whether adverse conditions will still make you enjoy a car. You're not going to have ideal weather every day when you own it, after all. So, in a roundabout way, I enjoyed trying out the 500L in the snow for what it told me about the real-world ownership experience.

The 500L answers a question that I'm not sure who asked: What if you love the idea of a cute little Fiat, but you need a bigger car? Fiat is obviously looking to put a competitor up against the Mini Countryman, the Kia Soul, and the Nissan Cube in the stylish-box category, and to give American buyers a reason to buy a Fiat instead of a small crossover like a Kia Sportage. The fact that this one starts just under $20,000 is a definite enticement to the first-time car buyer or, really, anybody who is in the market for an affordable vehicle. There are four levels to the 500L lineup: the entry-level Pop, which costs $19,995 with destination charge; the Easy, the car we tested, which starts at $20,995; the higher-end Lounge, and the off-road-styled Trekking (which only looks rugged).

I happen to really like the way the 500L looks, and my eighteen-year-old son, Henry, a cranky iconoclast whose tastes run to ancient Volvos, agreed with me as he climbed into the passenger's seat. The body shape reminds me of the Steve Jobs insistence on rounded edges on Apple's icons. Just from feedback around me, I already know that it's not to everyone's taste, but Henry and I think it's seriously cute.

You hop in, and the first thing you notice is sterling visibility. I particularly appreciated the clear glass A-pillars, paired with clear glass D-pillars in the back corners. These create a nearly 360-degree view, even though it meant I had more windows to scrape ice off. I couldn't enjoy the power sunroof ($950) since it was obscured by more ice, but on a nicer day or one where I felt more inclined to clear off the roof of the car, I would have.

I was less a fan of the interior than I thought I'd be. The two-tone seats are not that comfortable, and the mainly grey ("Cementite") with black trim in the midlevel Easy model we had, I suspect, would start to look dirty in a matter of a few months. They do come in other colors; I'd go for dark surfaces myself. And then, the overall feeling was just not quirky. Compared with, say, the goofy instrument panel of the Smart Fortwo or the Mini Countryman, the switchgear was bland and disappointingly ordinary. A notable exception was the excellent Beats audio system, a $700 package that included SiriusXM with a one-year subscription. The heated front seats ($350) were much appreciated given the weather and, I increasingly believe, a must-have on a new car for anyone in cool climates. There were several non-skid surfaces and cubbies for placing phones and other devices, including a nice open shelf below the glove box, and connectivity was, as you'd expect, completely up to date.

But what counts more than looks inside a car is how safe you feel, and the Fiat 500L can compete with the heavy hitters in that department. It was named a Top Safety Pick in 2013 by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, garnering the top Good rating in all tests. It only missed the latest 2014 rating, issued this week, because Fiat doesn't offer front crash prevention technology (such as forward collision warning systems), a new IIHS requirement this year. The 500L is fitted with front and rear head curtain airbags and front seat-mounted torso airbags. There's also a separate driver's-side knee airbag in the lower instrument panel to help mitigate knee injuries in front crashes. Although the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration hasn't yet crash tested the 500L, the Top Safety Pick verdict means I'd feel confident in getting this car for one of my kids. (Sorry, Henry, not anytime soon.)

The 500L may be targeted at space-hungry Americans, but it's thoroughly European. It is built in Serbia, in the same plant that used to make the Yugo, but let's not think about that one too long and hard. The engine is sourced in Italy and, despite the Chrysler connection, the car has zero North American content. You're buying the Italian dream, and Fiat has done well in marketing the car that way.

That makes sense, since I think much of the appeal of buying a Fiat is the self-indulgence of owning a European car with a romantic pedigree. European streets are filled with tiny MPVs similar to the 500L: the Ford B-Max, the Citroen C3 Picasso, the Opel Meriva, and others. But, rising gas prices notwithstanding, it's not clear to me whether Americans really want one of those. We are still interested in having power at our disposal when we need it, and the 1.4-liter four, even though it's turbocharged, was not as vigorous as I'd like when I accelerate.

The Verdict:

I will stop short of saying I was dashing through the snow in the 500L, but the one-horse part is partly right. Perhaps because I did need that extra bit of pep to cope with the weather, I felt—and colleague Molly Jean agreed with me—that this Fiat seemed a little underpowered. That's interesting, because the 1.4-liter MultiAir turbo is the same engine I enjoyed in the Dodge Dart. Maybe there's something about the minibus seating position in the 500L that makes you feel you're just toddling along. And maybe, on a nicer, more carefree driving day, it would have mattered less.

If you are attracted to Fiats, I am not sure this 500L will do it for you aesthetically; I feel the same way about the Mini Countryman. These expanded models no longer seem like the minicars their makers started with, and if what you really want is a Mini Cooper or a 500, you might want to just go ahead and get one. On the other hand, if you are looking at other cubist products, or a small crossover, or if your budget means you need a car in the low $20,000s, the 500L is an interesting alternative. You won't see these coming and going, no matter what the weather.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie White: The 500L is an odd little car, and it looks too much like a bloated panda for me to consider it attractive. But if you can get past the exterior (or if you're one of the people who love it), the rest of the car has a lot to recommend it. The interior feels airy, spacious, and much more practical than the tiny 500. For the price, it has good standard and optional equipment. The back seats aren't terribly comfortable, but you could put adults back there and they wouldn't immediately complain. It may not be the right quirky car for me, but it could be the right one for you!

Scott Allen: I agree with Annie about the 500L's body. I think it has blowfish qualities. Maybe that roundness is what makes it feel so spacious inside. Everything was pretty easy to reach, although I didn't really like the controls for the audio system with its push buttons to go from one channel to the next. It was slow and distracting. And I didn't really understand the Euro Twin Clutch automatic transmission, but I also felt the car lacked power. I wouldn't buy the 500L because it just doesn't feel as serious to me as something like a Honda Civic.

Molly Jean: Unfortunately, the Fiat 500L leaves me teetering on the edge of adoration. It does not have the same level of attention to design and style that the 500 boasts. To me, it looks rather bloated. It appears to me that design decisions were compromised to make this car more attractive to the space-obsessed American market. The choice of materials seems cheap, and I especially think the seat material feels and looks bargain basement. And, where is the sublime mint green exterior paint choice? However, bravo to those same designers, because once inside, it feels downright spacious. What the 500L loses in style cred, it gains in affordability and usefulness. With its $19,995 base price (including destination), the 500L would definitely be a contender if I was buying my daughter a spankin' new vehicle. But I wouldn't put the ribbon on it until I purchased some aftermarket seat covers. As for myself, I'll take a pass.

pageElements.text: The insurance industry's nonprofit, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, has just issued its list of 2014 Top Safety Pick+ winners, and the emphasis is all on that little plus sign. The IIHS testing, like Common Core standards in the public schools, has been toughened to require Good ratings, the top score, in four different crash tests, plus at least a Basic rating for front crash prevention technology. Still, twenty-two vehicles were named Top Safety Pick+, with an additional fifteen getting the Top Safety Pick rating for 2014.

The Top Safety Pick award originated in 2006, but Top Safety Pick+ was new last year. IIHS calls it "the next level of safety" because Plus winners are those that have systems that can keep crashes from happening or mitigate the damage from them. The crash tests it administers are side, roof strength, head restraint, and small overlap front (in which 25 percent of the driver's side front is crashed into a rigid barrier at 40 mph). IIHS rates front crash prevention systems on a scale of Basic, Advanced, and Superior, evaluating the presence of either standard or optional forward collision warning and autobrake technology. A car qualifies for the Basic rating if it meets the performance criteria of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), IIHS said.

The fact that the organization is keeping a firm hand on the standard is good news for anyone shopping for a new car right now, even though the winner's circle is a lot smaller in 2014. Last year saw a list of 130 total Top Safety Pick and Top Safety Pick+ winners. Some dropped from the 2014 list because they simply haven't been tested yet; others haven't met the small overlap test standard (the test is shown at right). IIHS hastens to note that the 2013 winners still met "a high level of protection in four main crash types" even if they didn't repeat as winners.

See the IIHS website for the complete list of Top Safety Pick and Top Safety Pick+ winners for 2014.

Who won?

Without further ado, here are the vehicles that garnered the Top Safety Pick+ rating:

New this year:
Acura MDX and RLX
Infiniti Q50
Mazda 3 and CX-5
Toyota Highlander and Prius
Volvo S80

Winners with crash prevention as standard equipment:
Honda Civic Hybrid
Volvo S60, S80, and XC60

And:
Ford Fusion
Honda Accord (two- and four-door) and Odyssey
Lincoln MKZ
Mazda 6
Mercedes-Benz M-Class

pageElements.text:
Mercedes-Benz AMG Vision Gran Turismo

There are a lot of concept cars that look like they belong in a video game; this one really does. The fifteenth birthday of the Gran Turismo video game series for PlayStation was celebrated this year with the release of Gran Turismo 6, even more realistic than the five generations that came before it. Mercedes-Benz developed the concept you see in this video specifically for an existence in the PS3 game.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/5Jvb520Ct84?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The Gran Turismo concept was the work of Mercedes-Benz's Advanced Design Studios in Sindelfingen, Germany, along with Carlsbad, California, for the exterior, and Como, Italy, for the interior. They selected AMG's 585-horsepower V-8 biturbo engine, an aluminum space frame body, and heavy use of carbon fiber to end up with a light concept car at 3,053 pounds. All this for a car you can only enjoy in the virtual world, which kind of makes the virtual world more attractive.

Gran Turismo game creator Kazunori Yamauchi welcomed the concept with a statement: "For me as a child, the concept cars announced by automobile manufacturers in motor shows were fantastic presents that always brought promise of a bright future."

Well, this is a present for you, all right, Mr. Yamauchi. The Mercedes-Benz AMG Vision Gran Turismo is deliberately extreme, with a low, flowing silhouette and glowing red ambient contour lines. Its LED grille is aglow with varying light patterns, and its high brake light in back displays the Gran Turismo logo.

pageElements.text:
Price: $34,995 (base price of this model, including destination)
$40,640 as tested (including destination)
Engine: Liquid-cooled AC motor, 1.4-liter "range extender" engine, 16 kWh lithium-ion battery, total 149 horsepower
Transmission: One-speed automatic
Charge time: Four hours at 240V, ten to sixteen hours at 120V
Fuel economy: 98 mpg-e (35-mile range on electric only); 37 mpg combined (gasoline engine)
My favorite standard feature: Efficiency display screens: they're addictive; Ceramic White interior trim
Option I can’t live without: White Diamond tricoat exterior paint ($995)
Notable standard features on this model: Traction control, pedestrian safety signal, remote start, leather-wrapped steering wheel, efficiency display screens, Chevrolet MyLink radio with seven-inch screen
Notable options on this model: Heated seats, leather seat trim (included in Premium package, $1,395), rearview camera and rear park assist (included in Safety package, $575), forward collision alert and front park assist, lane departure warning, and front-view camera (included in Safety package #2, $595); audio system with navigation and touchscreen ($895), seventeen-inch wheels with black inserts ($695), Bose speaker system ($495)
You might also be considering: Ford C-Max Energi, Nissan Leaf, Toyota Prius

Do you spend a lot of time in the car as a solo commuter, driving under twenty miles to work and back every weekday but tend to go on longer jaunts on weekends and vacations? Having spent several days behind the wheel of a Chevrolet Volt, I’m convinced that person is the ideal owner of this plug-in hybrid.

That’s because the Volt can get you up to thirty-eight miles on electricity alone, running smoothly and silently down the road, keeping the driver feeling very smart and savvy. Hit that zero-charge threshold, and the Volt will automatically switch to gasoline power, or what Chevrolet calls "extended range," with no action from you. The power comes from a 16.5 kWh, T-shaped lithium-ion battery that powers the Volt's electric drive unit. When the battery charge is gone, there's a a gasoline-powered electric generator that kicks in, working with the car's electric motors. The technology is complex, but as a driver, I just need to know that I can drive as far as I want without powering down like a neglected iPhone. Range anxiety: gone!

What it can’t do is fit more than four, thanks to the battery load it's carrying, and those two in the back seat are not going to be comfortable for long distances. That disqualifies it as a family car, in my book and in the books of my long-legged teenagers.

There was a time, not so long ago, when the Chevrolet Volt was the eagerly anticipated electric car of the future. It came out in concept form in early 2007, low-slung and sleek, with wraparound windows that looked like Geordi’s eyewear in Star Trek: The Next Generation. Sexy! So, when I first saw one out on the roads in 2010, I was, frankly, disappointed. The production version looked a lot closer to something designed by committee, and the price that rested at about $40,000 felt like a pretty big penalty for being an early adopter.

But what do I know? Automobile Magazine's design editor, Robert Cumberford, explained the differences between the design of the concept and the production model in this article back in 2009. The more mainstream appearance, he explained, "also gives the car lower drag, more cabin space, and a tighter turning circle."

That all makes sense to me. But, frankly, there is just something a little uncool about the Volt relative to the trendy Nissan Leaf, Toyota Prius, and Ford C-Max that hybrid or EV shoppers would also be looking at. One way to overcome a charm deficit: Chevrolet cut the cost of the car by some $5,000 earlier this model year, which makes the Volt look more interesting in an increasingly crowded hybrid market. The Toyota Prius Plug-In starts at $30,800, and the Ford C-Max Energi starts at $33,745. That price cut still keeps the Volt at $34,995, but it also offers more power, more range, and better fuel economy than its competitors. But what does it feel like to be inside one? I wondered.
On first sight, I gave this Volt credit for looking like the electric car of the future as imagined by the artistic sketches of the 1960s.

On first sight, I gave this Volt credit for looking like the electric car of the future as imagined by the artistic sketches of the 1960s. That tricoat white exterior color is a $995 option, an added cost that I would reject with a snort on most cars, but it helps this sedan turn the corner from dull to dashing. Inside, I immediately bonded with the bright white ceramic trim and the candy-colored data screens in front of my face. Cue Jetsons theme! The rearview camera, one of my must-have features on any vehicle, looked especially good surrounded by the white ceramic. Then there are the digital dash readouts, which can be customized in what Chevrolet calls a Configurable Cluster. Awesome. You can set it up to show you the minimal information: how much electric range is left, for example. Or you can get it to show you full details and specs as shown in this Chevrolet video clip, and obsess over your fuel economy.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/O2paBpQPE3w" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

I couldn't wait to see if I could really get thirty-eight miles out of a charge. Unfortunately, the exterior temperature was hovering around ten degrees, so I went through the electricity a lot faster than that. Chevrolet has a helpful video on YouTube in which an engineer tells you not to heat up the interior beyond basic comfort in the winter, and if possible, leave it in a garage. Too bad, as I grew to enjoy the silent treatment from the Volt, even though I only got about twenty-eight miles before...listen for it...there: the generator kicked in.

But, speaking of power, I was pleasantly surprised how much fun the Volt was to drive. I mean, it is a mid-size sedan that looks like a fleet car. But actually, it was pretty nice on the road and not at all underpowered. It accelerated well, held its own in freeway traffic, and in every way felt "normal." That alone might make an EV conquest out of a buyer who doesn't consider herself adventurous or an early adopter. The Volt's list of safety and convenience features is right up to date, including several reasonably priced safety option packages that include that rearview camera plus traction control, lane departure warning, navigation, and Bose stereo, among other things. It wasn't long before I was completely in the groove of Volt ownership: drive it to the office and plug it in during the day; enjoy getting home and back again the next day without using any gasoline (and without driving any less assertively than usual). The normalcy of the Volt experience was probably the biggest surprise, and biggest selling point, for me.

Electric-drive vehicles still make up a minuscule share of total car sales—3.8 percent in 2013, according to the Electric Drive Transportation Association—and I’m convinced it’s not just because this is new technology; it’s because you can get a comparable traditionally powered car for thousands less, and people don’t (yet) see the benefit to themselves personally. With the prices starting to come down, and more public outlets becoming available so the idea of plugging in your car becomes more acceptable, I'm guessing more and more people will be ready to adopt this kind of vehicle. If you're on the fence, the Volt just might get you the rest of the way there.

The Verdict:

This is not the coolest, latest thing in hybrid vehicles. But it's also not the boring sedan that you might have expected until you get inside. The Volt deserves a lot more respect than I was expecting to give it. It is fun to drive not just because it's, you know, fun to drive, but because you can enjoy geeking out over the gasoline-to-electric ratio and keeping track of your fuel efficiency. You can also enjoy how long you can go without pulling into a gas station. It's got all the safety and technology features you would want on a new sedan, plus it will save you a bunch of money on fuel. According to Chevrolet, the average user fills up the tank once a month and saves $900 a year on fuel costs. The average mpg number for the eighteen Volt owners who post their results on the EPA's Fueleconomy.gov: 150.7 mpg.

Now, if you're going to sit down with an amortization table and figure out whether the fuel savings will equal the extra cost over a "regular" car, you might not get the numbers to crunch, but there's something very satisfying about dipping a toe into the waters of alternative power on a day-to-day basis. And, with the new price reduction, if you get the maximum $7,500 tax credit, you're talking about a starting price around $28,000, just about where you'd be for a traditionally powered sedan.

Give this car a try. I know I could see myself owning one, which is not what I thought I'd say before I overcame my prejudices and climbed in.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: When the Volt was first introduced at the tail end of 2010, I was totally unimpressed with the plastic used on the interior. But fast-forward to 2014 and I am perfectly happy with the "stormtrooper" white plastic. In fact, I grew to love the ultra-modern center instrument panel. I was also pleasantly surprised by the driving experience. It is definitely not a sports car but it can accelerate quickly, and is a perfectly competent car. If I was buying an electric or a hybrid I would make sure to test drive the Volt, even though still take away points for being an FLC (funny looking car).

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: The artist Virginia Overton has recast the pickup truck from a capable worker to conceptual work of art. I saw the most recent example of her work in Miami Beach in December: Overton’s interpretation of a 1993 Dodge Ram. It was included in Venus Over Manhattan’s group exhibition “Piston Head: Artists Engage the Automobile,” held at the Herzog & de Meuron parking garage in Miami during Art Basel in December. The Ram appeared in silver metallic paint, lined with a simple, suggestive red racing stripe along the body and hood leading up to the windshield. An immovable red tonneau cover obstructed its bed, limiting its capabilities. The truck was actually a former workhorse, made lame through the act of stripping it of its basic skills.
Overton has mined the truck’s functionality with a keen eye for the part and process of labor-intensive work. Her work invokes the physicality of construction.

Overton has explored the pickup truck as sculpture in several exhibitions, and in each instance she has mined the truck’s functionality with a keen eye for the part and process of labor-intensive work. Her work invokes the physicality of construction and incorporates materials as they relate to the environment, calling the nature of work into question. In 2012, she created a site-specific truck installation of a 1994 2WD Toyota for the Highline park in New York City. It sat in an elevated car park visible from the Highline's walkway, with its bed entirely bricked off.

For the 2012 exhibition “Chevy Deluxe” at the Power Station in Dallas, she installed a blue light box into the bed of a faded 1984 Chevrolet  Deluxe pickup that was displayed in the gallery. She once received a permit to park a pickup truck in front of the White Box Gallery for a 2007 show.
“I pimped my truck by adding green neon to the underside and then drove it on top of a glass mirror, where I left it for the show,” she said in an Interview Magazine article.

Overton, who grew up in rural Tennesee, also told Interview: “I think the roughness of my work comes from the fact that I grew up on a farm. You learn to use and reuse the same materials in a pretty thrifty way.” Her work incorporates solid, constructive materials like Sheetrock, fluorescent light tubing, and wood beams. In another, earlier truck-themed excavation, she drove from Norfolk, Virginia, to Memphis, Tennessee, acquiring discarded tool and rubbish en route to her destination, tossing them into the bed.

For her recent exhibition at the Kunsthalle in Bern, Switzerland, she said, “I feel like the work I make can exist in a museum or on a driveway or in a barn or whatever, and still function as real things in the world, not as some extraneous objects to be placed on a pedestal.”

contributors.bio: I am a person who loves to study other people. I like to interview them, learn about their lives, photograph them, and write their stories. The people at Jean Knows Cars noticed me through my project, Humans of Ann Arbor. In that project, I tool around the city of Ann Arbor, introducing myself to anyone who draws my eye. If they are open to it, I take a photo of them and hear a little bit about them. Then I post the photos and stories on Facebook. Humans of Ann Arbor has followers from all over the world who check in on a daily basis to see ordinary people and their extraordinary stories. I have been studying people since I was a little girl in Missouri. Where I grew up, studying people often led you to the cars they loved. My grandpa had a gas station in Claycomo, Missouri, which he opened in the 1950s, and he passed his love of cars and taking care of the people who drove them down to my dad. Dad was a mechanic and a service supervisor all his life. We had a steady barrage of cars coming into our lives…mostly Chevys. To impress my dad, I learned to identify every car I could, and I used to name the cars while we drove down the road. Car culture is big in Missouri. Would you believe that I had friends who were sisters named Nova and Chevelle? If you didn’t grow up the way I did, you might not get the significance of that, but suffice it to say that my people love their cars. The car I adored most was the Chevrolet Corvair my dad gave me when I was in high school. It spent more time in my dad's shop than it did on the road, but in those moments when it was drivable, I knew what it was to love a car. It was a thing of beauty: pale cream with a plaid madras interior. I loved the sound and feel of the engine…it was more like a soft purr than a roar. I can still remember how it smelled and what it was like to drive it with the windows rolled down on a warm day. I've had lots of cars since then, and I loved some of them, too. But the Corvair was my first car love and will always be my favorite. After high school, I drove my car to Springfield, Missouri, to study communications at Missouri State. Later, I drove a different car to Chicago to study photography at Columbia College. I worked in Chicago as a freelance photographer and studio manager for many years before moving to Ann Arbor, where I continue to do freelance photography. I am excited about combining my love of studying people with my interest in cars. I want to explore how cars serve us, how they are intertwined in our lives, and what makes us love them. I can't wait to let you know what I find out.

pageElements.text: “When my parents were cool” is the caption under a photo a friend recently posted on social media. In the photo, two impossibly sophisticated people, dressed to the nines, are stepping out of an amazing old car that appears to be from the Thirties or Forties. The man is helping the woman out, and both of them look excited to start an evening of what I can only imagine will include dinner, cocktails, dancing, and witty conversation with charming friends. The photo is so interesting because everything in it paints a vivid picture of a time and place that has gone by.
Cars in photographs are like a date stamp that puts everything into context.

When we look at photos of ourselves, they link us to our memories. When we see photos of our parents or grandparents, they link us to history. Cars in photographs are like a date stamp that puts everything into context. In decades to come, the photos we take of our families and cars now will make our children giggle about the clothes they were wearing, the hairstyles their parents had, and how cool those old cars that you had to steer yourself were!

image.altText: The Car Stays in the Picture

pageElements.text: The Spangler family and I went outside for photos that included their two cars: a 2011 Ford Flex they call “Black Sidious," after the Star Wars character Darth Sidious, and their 1993 Ford F-150 that they call “The Bengal Bomber,” which was painted in Bengal tiger stripes with $40 worth of spray paint. Both of the cars mean a lot to them, so we tried out a few things and came up with five different ways for you to take photos with your car that will stand the test of time.

1. Be natural.

A natural, unposed photo of your family getting ready to go somewhere in the car shows everyone as they actually are. You can take this in your driveway so you can also see a bit of the house, the garage, or the neighborhood. This is a slice-of-life photo to capture your real life. People and cars always look best in soft light, so try taking this photo when it is overcast, or during “magic hour” just before sunset.

2. Pile in.

A photo of you in the car is going to remind you of all the places your car took you and all of the memories you made along the way. You will be reminded of details like which side you sat on, which of the adults usually drove that car, and what it felt like to sit in that particular seat. You may even start to remember details of the scenery you saw through the windows when you were on a road trip, or the game you played together to make the time pass. Future members of your family will imagine what adventures you may have had that day.
Silliness always, 100 percent of the time, makes a better photo than forced smiles.

image.altText: The Car Stays in the Picture

pageElements.text:
3. Ham it up.

Let the personalities in your family shine through. Get everyone in front of the car, and tell them to yell out their favorite food, or maybe, “Go Bengals!” Tell them to say anything but “cheese.” Ask them to jump up and down. The idea is to make everyone have fun, and to capture it on film. Silliness always, 100 percent of the time, makes a better photo than forced smiles.

4. Play with framing.

Really look at what is in your viewfinder. Try stepping forward a few feet or sideways, or squat down. Move around until you get a nice view of the car and the people. Notice if there are weird, distracting things in the frame, and move until they aren’t showing. If you just take a few seconds to think about the best way to take your photo it will result in a really nice image you can be proud of.

image.altText: The Car Stays in the Picture

pageElements.text:
5. Get close.

Try taking a photo of the little people in your life playing together, with the car filling the background. This gives you just a little glimpse of the car while your kids are the main focus. This is an easy way to take a simple photo where everything in the frame is something that is important to you.
After you have taken these photos, just put them somewhere safe and wait. In ten to fifteen years and beyond, the details of time and place will come more sharply into focus than they are now.
You’ll probably laugh at your hair and your clothes, but if you are lucky you might say to yourself, “Wow. I don’t remember ever looking that cool.”

title: 10 Cars for Downton Abbey's Women
promoTeaserSmall: Jump forward in time, and let's imagine what cars they'd drive if they were going to a dealer today.
promoTeaser: Jump forward in time, and let's imagine what cars they'd drive if they were going to a dealer today.
metaTitle: 10 Cars for Downton Abbey's Women
metaDescription: 10 Cars for Downton Abbey's Women: Jump forward in time, and let's imagine what cars they'd drive if they were going to a dealer today. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I just learned on the TV news that Barack Obama enjoys watching Downton Abbey. I’m not sure what impact that has on his policy agenda, but it’s nice to hear that our head of state is emotionally involved in the life stories of such beautifully drawn characters as Mrs. Patmore, dominator of the kitchen, and Lady Mary, the emotionally challenged widowed aristocrat.

One thing Downton Abbey and President Obama have in common is an extremely rich online population of detail checkers and historical-accuracy wonks. Check out for yourself the Internet Movie Car Database, which grouses: “The second season ends in 1920, yet we see a 1925 Sunbeam and numerous Model T Fords that hadn't been built yet.” Excellent point, although not one that takes much away from enjoyment of the period-charm series.

It made me wonder, though: Suppose there really was no need for historical accuracy, and the characters in Downton Abbey could step out of time and choose whatever 2014 model car they felt best expressed their personalities?

Here’s a highly subjective list of some of the current starring women of Downton Abbey, and what I imagine they would choose to drive from today's showrooms. What do you think of my suggestions? Got some of your own? Please comment!

1. Violet, The Dowager Countess of Grantham (Maggie Smith)

First of all, the Dowager Countess would never stoop to drive herself. She is shown in Season 4 of Downton Abbey being chauffeured in a traditional 1920s luxury tourer. As a modern shopper, I think she would choose a Mercedes-Benz S550 sedan in basic black with the nut brown/black leather interior and burl walnut trim, none of which cost extra. It could be driven by a modern-day chauffeur quite well. She’d give approval to the heated rear seats ($620), but she’d disdain the cabin fragrances and air purification of the Air Balance package ($350) as tacky. Total cost: $94,445, including destination. As Oscar Wilde would say, Violet is a woman who has very simple tastes: she is always satisfied with the best.

Jean disagrees, feeling sure the Dowager would have a Rolls-Royce. Much as I can see Violet in the back seat of a Phantom, I believe she'd choose a lower profile and more discretion on modern streets. But let's split the difference and presume she would own both the Rolls and the S-Class.

2. Cora, Lady Grantham (Elizabeth McGovern)

Coming from money that she couldn’t keep control of, and far from her home country, Lady Grantham needs to be driving an American car. I'd love to see her in something resolutely modern, in which, as a soon-to-be empty nester, she can go have an independent adventure for once. How about a Tesla Model S? Hers would be in Tesla's aristocratic-looking multi-coat Pearl White. She'd also get the all-glass panoramic roof. Inside would be tan leather seats with lacewood accents. The price would come to $69,720 total, assuming she got the U.S. tax credits, and she can have one of the footmen plug it in during the evenings.

3. Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery)

Her husband having been killed behind the wheel of a sporty AC Six Roadster in Season Three, Lady Mary will value safety...and a closed roof. I see her in a top-end Audi A8 4.0 TFSI, with quattro all-wheel drive and an eight-speed automatic transmission. She’ll choose it in a personality-matching Glacier White metallic, with Titanium Gray Valletta leather seats. Lady Mary will definitely check the box for the $3,250 Driver Assistance package (adaptive cruise control, top-view camera, Audi side assist, and lane assist), plus the required additional Premium package ($4,000) with LED lights, ventilated massaging front seats, and more safety features. None of it might have saved Matthew, but Lady Mary is all about self-preservation. She’s got an empire to build. Total cost: $91,150, including destination.

4. Lady Edith (Laura Carmichael)

Left at the altar, undermined by her older sister, and condescended to by almost everyone else, Lady Edith is just not a lucky person. She loves cars, though, so let’s picture her going down the road in the new BMW 4 Series coupe. (She does seem to have Germany in her future, after all.) Let's let her have it in the Sport Line trim. Hers might be the Mineral Grey Metallic outside, and an interior in Coral Red Dakota leather with black accent stitching, complemented by brushed aluminum trim. She'll take the Technology package ($3,150) giving her BMW's navigation system, head-up display, and smartphone apps, and the Dynamic Handling package ($1,000) for the variable sport steering and adaptive M suspension. She'll want to be civilized but drive fast, and there's no doubt she'd be an early adopter of technology. Top it off with the six-speed manual transmission (a no-cost option), and she'll be paying a reasonable $53,775 (including destination). Her other car, by the way, is a black Chevrolet Corvette roadster.

5. Lady Rose MacClare (Lily James)

A relatively new addition to the ensemble cast, Lady Rose is young, silly, and doesn’t mind slumming at a thé-dansant with the working class, as long as she can get back into her silk in time to join the ruling class for dinner at the castle. She’d like to drive a Mazda MX-5 Miata to let her buzz back and forth from one walk of life to another. The Miata would be the top Grand Touring model with a power retractable hard top and black leather seats. She’d look at it in Zeal Red but go with the cuter and less aggressive Liquid Silver in the end. She’d pay an extra $1,390 for the Premium package to get the Bluetooth connectivity that she'd rarely stop using while driving. Total cost: $32,735. I suspect she’s destined to be married off before long to someone who has a Bentley and no sense of humor, so let her have her fun for now.

6. Isobel Crawley (Penelope Wilton)

Mrs. Crawley is nothing if not sensible. She always has some kind of social-work project or garden activity in the works, so she would be an excellent customer for a Volvo wagon. The Volvo XC60 T6 AWD crossover would suit her need for timeless quality and meet her requirement for strictly no frivolity. She might choose it in Twilight Bronze Metallic (a $550 option), a resolute color for middle-class tastes. Inside, she’d pick the Soft Beige leather upholstery and walnut trim. She’d spring for the rational Technology package ($1,500) for its adaptive cruise control, lane departure alert, and collision warning with auto brake. She might add on the park assist camera ($850) but would draw the line at adding any luxury options with no practical purpose. Total cost: $45,365, including destination. She’d enjoy bringing it in under $50,000, I suspect.

7. Mrs. Hughes (Phyllis Logan)

The Scottish house mother puts on no airs, but her longing for a little romance in her life is undeniable. She should be driving something indulgent, but she’d be more likely to turn wistfully to a duller car. But this is my fantasy, so she gets a Cadillac ATS. She’d choose it in Radiant Silver, with the base 2.5-liter four-cylinder that makes 202 horsepower, and choose the caramel-and-black leatherette interior. Since this would be a big expenditure for her, she’d spring for the theft-deterrent Advanced Security package ($380). She’d love the Cadillac CUE telematics and the SiriusXM, both included. Final price: $35,270, including destination. Maybe she can get Carson to go for a spin.

8. Anna Bates (Joanne Froggatt)

Anna has made the best of the hard knocks she’s been presented with, and who (besides Thomas Barrow, perhaps) can fail to love her? She is always warm and kind, but clearly she has very few illusions. Even if she had money, she would not waste a cent on comforts for herself. Her husband, of course, Mr. Bates, needs an accessible vehicle. I think the Bateses would like a Dodge Grand Caravan. Minivans are easy to get in and out of, and they are practical for the occasional picnic or trip to London to investigate the latest intrigue in either of their lives. (Besides, I harbor a personal hope that they’ll have or adopt children eventually.) They’d pick the base American Value Package model, in cheerful Redline Red. Despite the base trim level, they’d get Chrysler’s UConnect audio, a six-speed automatic transmission, and a 3.6-liter V-6. Mrs. Bates would appreciate this simple but friendly transport, especially since she’d get it for a total of $20,490.

9. Mrs. Patmore (Lesley Nicol)

I love the frazzled kitchen despot Mrs. Patmore. She’s very uncomfortable with technology and change, so she will need a car that is extremely user-friendly and traditionally designed. She’d probably love the Toyota RAV4. I think a woman who spends most of her life trapped below stairs would enjoy a moonroof, so she’ll step up to the midlevel XLE to get one. She will stick with the front-wheel-drive model, though; no AWD newfangledness for her. The four-cylinder engine and six-speed automatic transmission are plenty exciting enough. She’d like the pretty green Spruce Mica exterior, which would go nicely with what’s left of the red in her hair, teamed with a sensible black cloth interior. Total price: $25,150. I just hope she takes time to go for a drive on her half-day off.

10. Daisy Mason (Sophie McShera)

Last but not least, we come to Daisy, the kitchen maid turned assistant cook. She still wears her wedding ring, I noticed in Episode 1 of Season 4, although her marriage to a dying young soldier lasted only minutes. This hard-working girl is still a dreamer, and since she has become close to a doting father-in-law, she is definitely on the move upward from extremely impoverished beginnings in life. She would look good behind the wheel of a Volkswagen Beetle, and she'd like one in sunny Yellow Rush. Let's make it the TDI for durability and fuel economy; Daisy is likely to keep a car for a long time. The Sunroof, Sound & Navigation model, with a six-speed automatic with Tiptronic and sport mode, adds up to $28,915, a lot for an assistant cook but not too much for the eventual head of the Downton kitchen. Take that, Ivy!
