contributors.bio:
Robert Cumberford is a designer who became a writer by accident. His race report on the 12 Hours of Sebring was published when he was an eighteen-year-old Art Center student in 1954. Subsequently he has published thousands of articles on cars and airplanes, in American, Asian, English, European, and South American magazines. He contributed to several books, including the entire text of the well-reviewed Auto Legends, now available in five translated editions -- French, German, Spanish, Italian, and Polish in addition to the original English version. In 1985, Automobile Magazine founder David E. Davis, Jr., invited him to be one of two executive editors when Automobile was in the planning stages. Cumberford demurred, saying he knew nothing about magazine production and claims he still doesn’t, except that it’s important to meet deadlines. He contributed features from the beginning and began his popular “By Design” column in the sixth issue, September 1986.

In car design, Cumberford was even more a youthful prodigy. He sketched the body for the first car ever built to his designs when he was a fifteen-year-old Los Angeles high-school student. That car, the Parkinson Jaguar Special, is still active in historic racing sixty years after it was created. Hired directly by General Motors’ legendary Vice President of Design, Harley J. Earl, Cumberford became a professional car designer at nineteen. Leaving Detroit, he returned to California to attend UCLA to study philosophy. He rejoined the automotive world in the early 1960s and has continued to create new automotive shapes since then, always as an independent design consultant. He has lived and worked in six of the fifty United States and in France, Mexico, and Switzerland. The range of his design projects includes both racing and touring cars, trucks, aircraft, boats, hovercraft, and even ecological architecture.

He is known worldwide for strong opinions but is well-respected in the design world because it is known that he is always completely honest in his views, with no agenda other than respect for good design and good designers. “There’s no ad hominem,” he says, “I judge the design, not the designers. There are designers I really like personally who’ve been credited with designs I heartily dislike -- for reasons I always state very clearly -- and designs I love done by people with whom I have absolutely no affinity. Except that we both like their work.”

pageElements.text: Auto shows are huge events in major cities all over the world. They attract big crowds of local residents but are not popular with city fathers because they really don’t generate much attraction for tourists. Nor do they increase hotel and restaurant and entertainment receipts. Thus, they are often staged at times when the exposition hall rental is cheap because no one wants to visit a city then anyway. Detroit’s North American International Auto Show is perhaps the most important of all such shows to industry leaders and the world press, attracting more than 5,000 international journalists despite the dubious attractions of a ruined and bankrupt city in the dead of winter. The NAIAS used to be held the first week in January until the world press rebelled, most members preferring to stay home with their families over the holidays, so now it has moved to the second full week in the month.

One of the key reasons for non-specialist people to attend is not to see the new cars that you’ll be able to buy at a neighborhood dealership a day, week, or month after the show. Those are pretty much irrelevant to most of us. Manufacturers flood media with publicity about them. What appeals is to get a look at some of the dazzling “concept cars” that manufacturers confect for these events, unveiled at the very last instant. Those concepts are secret and—if you know how to look at them—significant. They can portend much about the future of specific companies and even the economies of entire countries.
One of the many functions of a one-of-a-kind show car is to lead to acceptance of change.

The automobile-related economy—manufacturing, selling, and servicing the cars themselves, plus the petroleum industry that is symbiotically tied to cars—is staggeringly gigantic, involving the investment and circulation trillions of dollars. And pounds and euros and renminbi and yen, of course. So a car that resonates with the public—as the first Ford Mustang did fifty years ago—can mean the fortunes of a massive enterprise can rise overnight. And one that doesn’t—Cadillac’s Cimarron, for example, or its botched diesel engine—can besmirch a firm’s reputation so badly that billions of dollars and dozens of years are needed to erase bad memories.

The currently popular term for very special cars that are made by serious people with vast industry backing, i.e., mainstream manufacturers, may be “concept” cars, but other terms have been used in the past. At the absolute peak of American prosperity in the 1950s, such vehicles were known as “dream cars,” and they reflected an optimism and willingness to try anything so long as it could be seen as “progress.” General Motors became famous for its Motorama shows, staged in New York’s Waldorf-Astoria hotel ballroom. In low-rent-rate January, of course. Its multiple dreams, never fewer than one for each of the company’s five car divisions, were not really cars. For the most part, they didn’t even run, simply being Hollywood-style stage props, enormously heavy objects that had to be pushed or tugged into place.

That still happens, of course, but most manufacturers now take pride in bringing vehicles to shows that do have real engines and can move—slowly and carefully, please—under their own power. Since cars, like birds and wild animals, can not really be fully assessed aesthetically until you see them in motion, wonderful films are made to be displayed on giant video screens behind the cars at shows. BMW went further at last fall’s Frankfurt Motor Show, with an indoor circuit encompassing hills and curves, allowing its new electric and hybrid cars to circulate all day long, taking chosen clients for exhilarating rides inside its pavilion.

Whenever you see someone’s new baby one of the first things you look for is visual signs of the parents. “Oh, he looks just like his father!” is a common cry, unless it’s “She’s the image of her mother.” This is a natural tendency that really applies to cars as well. Is there a perceptible family linkage? Can you see something of the object’s genetic heritage? You should, however subtle the traces, because one of the many functions of a one-of-a-kind show car is to lead to acceptance of change. Sometimes a company will have a clear plan to change a popular model, and to make that palatable for its clientele, a transitional “concept” model is actually made after the real car has been completely tooled and slated for introduction in a year or two. What it amounts to is having that future model face-lifted back to the past.

image.altText: how to look at a concept car

pageElements.text: Sixty-two years ago, General Motors decided to make a new sports car, the Chevrolet Corvette, with a revolutionary fiberglass-reinforced plastic body. It was shown at the Waldorf in January, and the first of 200 or so 1953 production models was sold in June. Public relations people—and careless historians—like to say that the “concept” was so popular that it was decided to produce the car. That’s always a possibility, but never in just six months. Take Chrysler Corporation’s Viper, like the initial Corvette an almost Spartan two-seat sports model. Shown at the NAIAS in 1989, it was so popular that a decision to produce it was made after the show, and by 1992 it was available in the marketplace. That concept has now evolved through three generations (compared with the Corvette’s seven successive iterations). That same pattern of evolution obtained for Volkswagen’s New Beetle, first shown in 1994 at Detroit as the clearly labeled Concept One. Four years later it was in production, and it is now in its second generation.

image.altText: how to look at a concept car

pageElements.text: Last year Toyota showed a “concept” in Detroit, the Furia (right), that was simply a teaser for the forthcoming Corolla. Whether it accustomed buyers to a new look is debatable. Basically the preceding Corolla was an undistinguished assemblage of uninteresting details, the Furia was a mess, and the current Corolla is blah again.

image.altText: how to look at a concept car

pageElements.text: Far more interesting and very much more significant was the Toyota Fun-vii (right), presented at Tokyo in 2011, then slightly revised as the diji for Detroit 2012 and revised yet again as the iiMo for the Geneva and Sao Paulo shows that year. Akio Toyoda, head of the firm his grandfather started long ago, said it should be considered as a sort of giant smartphone. Indeed, the entire external surface of the body is a display screen, so the car can change colors, patterns, visual textures, and I suppose that you could project the profile of an ancient MG on the sides and have a virtual electric sports car.

When one sees a car with as much imaginative advanced technology as that Toyota has, you start to wonder about what it might mean to you. Since it was always first presented with a solid black exterior, you would think it impossible to see out, and wonder if the car is meant to drive itself. And this gives you the central point in how to observe a concept car: make your observations absolutely personal. Ask yourself how a particular execution of the Platonic Ideal of an automobile relates to your interests and concerns. Thousand horsepower, 200-plus miles per hour performance may excite teenage boys and andropausal men having mid-life crises, but does it mean anything at all to you?
Make your observations absolutely personal. Ask yourself how a particular execution of the Platonic Ideal of an automobile relates to your interests and concerns.

Think about practicalities, like washing the car you’re looking at. Would its surface asperities caress your hands or threaten to tear your skin? Is there just enough surface decoration, or is there too much? Does the glass area seem adequate? How well will you be able to see out the back? If visibility seems poor, how did the designers deal with the problem? Many cars today have cameras that give you a nice view behind when you put the transmission in reverse. That’s an idea Buick proposed on a dream car half a century ago, and it has taken a long, long time to become accessible. Are there imaginative features on the car you’re examining that you’d like to have for yourself? Or are some of the feature so complex that even thinking about using them makes you nervous?

Sometimes concepts are presented, generate great interest, are put into production… and fail miserably in the marketplace. Isuzu showed a concept of the vehiCross, a high-style SUV, in 1993, put it into production in 1997, and cancelled it in 2001 after selling fewer than 6,000 units worldwide. Isuzu no longer makes cars at all, only trucks, probably as a consequence of a failed concept car.

In 2011, Ford showed a B-Max SUV concept in Geneva and put it into production pretty much as shown. With no central pillar, the whole side can be opened, and entry is particularly easy. But the sliding rear doors are very heavy with their incorporated side impact protection, almost impossible to shut if the car is facing uphill. It’s a great concept—I bought one (shown here) and love it—but Ford had to pause production for a few weeks last year because it is far less practical than it seemed and sales stalled. So that’s another thing to consider: Can you put children in the concept easily, and if so, can they manipulate the doors?
Elaborate doors, even the entire side lifting up gullwing style, aren't there because there is any intention of producing them, but to let you see the interior clearly.

Parents of small children know that car interiors are going to take a beating from feet on the seats, spills of sticky liquids, pet hair shedding, and other aspects of daily life. Look at any concept with a critical eye for those aspects of living with a car. Many concept cars have elaborate, complex doors, even the entire side of the car lifting up, gullwing style. They are there not because there is any intention of producing them, but to allow you to see the interior clearly. Think about how you would use the car were it equipped with normal doors.

Every concept car is a source of valuable information for the firm presenting it. There will be people in the crowd listening carefully to the comments made by visitors talking among themselves, and you might even be asked to respond to a questionnaire by a charming young person from the company, so your thoughts really are likely to be carefully considered, perhaps even implemented. So really paying attention to concept cars and thinking about what they might mean to you personally could very well alter the future.

contributors.bio: I'm a trial attorney, car blogger, and motorsports enthusiast whose idea of fun is going to Detroit in January or watching a six-hour endurance race. A native Texan, I currently live and work in the Austin area. When I'm not in the courtroom, you can find me driving my red Mini John Cooper Works, wrangling my pets or enjoying some delightful Texas cuisine (Tex-Mex and barbecue!). In 2013, I started a blog, Motorista, to document my car adventures and opine on all things auto related. The courtroom is no longer a man's world, and the car world won't always be, either!

pageElements.text:
Anna is a JKC reader who joined our Group of Seven consumer panel a year ago, when we assembled a group of women from around the country to tour the 2013 North American International Auto Show in Detroit. (See video of that tour here.) She is an attorney in Austin, Texas, but she really loves cars. When we learned Anna was coming up to Detroit for the auto show, we thought it would be a lot of fun to ask her to walk the show floor during the press preview days, enjoy looking at the cars before the rest of the public got to, and share her very personal, very heartfelt impressions of what she saw. And that's just what she did. Here's part two.

Day Two of the Detroit Auto Show…a little less crazy, a lot more opportunity to get up close with the cars, take a second look, form opinions.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: First, let me reconfirm my excitement about the Chevrolet Corvette Z06 and the SRT Viper. They looked just as good today as they did yesterday, particularly the Viper in anodized carbon metallic paint. I cannot wait for the opportunity to drive these cars someday. I tend to be a German-car girl, but Chevy and SRT have definitely turned my head. I’m glad to have some American brands to be excited about!

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: Another perennial favorite of mine: the Audi R8. It’s not new or particularly newsworthy this year, but it still quickens my pulse every time I see it. I can’t explain what it is; it just has presence. Being able to sit in the R8 was newsworthy for me this year. I considered not getting out of the R8 at all, but reason prevailed. After a while.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: I got my first look at the new Audi S3, a slightly more attainable car for me and one I would definitely consider if I was in the market. Like every Audi, it looks great, combining elegant design with serious performance. It’s nice to see versions of performance cars such as Audi S, Mercedes AMG, or BMW M offered for enthusiasts like me, who want a rip-snorting car but at a more manageable price. Of course, as a purist, the other half of me argues that the brands shouldn’t dilute their performance divisions by taking them downmarket…to people like me. But when I see such a car, like the S3 and the Mercedes-Benz CLA45 AMG, I stop arguing with myself. I want one of these cars!

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: Let’s divert back to the unattainable for a moment, though. Because the Porsche 918 Spyder is seriously hot. Seriously. Yes, it features some of the most of-the-moment and groundbreaking technology in the industry. Whatever. It looks fabulous. I went blind to the very lovely 911 Turbo S when I saw the 918 Spyder lurking behind it in its very own room. I homed in like a laser. Of course, the 918 Spyder sells for $845,000, so after taking several photos, I homed right back out. In another life, perhaps.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: Surprisingly, even while reveling in the sublimity of the 918 Spyder, an SUV caught my eye. I am not an SUV person, and hopefully never will be (no offense, SUV people; I know you think you need them). However, the Porsche Macan looks great. It is smaller and more refined and coherent-looking than its big brother the Cayenne. In fact, it’s quite lovely. The interior feels more focused on performance than utility (which is a good thing, I think!). If I felt the need for an SUV, I would want a Macan. I did not expect that.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: I also never expected to say that I would be interested in new cars from Acura and Lexus. But I was! Acura had a lovely stand this year, much more dynamic than prior years. With more than a little pomp and circumstance, the automaker introduced its new concept car, the Acura TLX. No, it’s not the sportiest car out there. But the detailing is very nice, and the car looks aggressive. Acura needs an injection of sportiness and performance, and I really hope the TLX delivers on that front.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: The Lexus RC F, a performance coupe headed for production, made a big splash. I have always considered Lexus to be somewhat soft and anodyne, more focused on luxury than any pretension to performance. (I don’t count the LFA supercar, considering it cost over $400,000 and had a production run of, what, two?) The more aggressive “spindle” grille that has recently appeared on new Lexus models seemed a step in the right direction, but with no car worthy of such a face, it struck me as a rather pointless design. Finally, Lexus has created a car for its spindle grille. The RC F radiates attitude. It looks mean, and I want to drive it in the worst way. Did I really just say that about a Lexus?

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: In other shocking news, I don’t hate the Toyota FT-1 concept car. It doesn’t make me swoon, but it doesn’t make me cackle, either (as last year’s Corolla Furia concept did). I don’t particularly care for the front or the rear, but the side view is surprisingly believable. I approached the car prepared to laugh, but I didn’t. How disappointing. Actually, I would love for Toyota to make a car I could like. I enjoy my righteous indignation, but only to a point.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: Other cars I didn’t find very interesting at a glance, but really liked on closer inspection: the Infiniti Eau Rouge (fabulous color, lovely and aggressive details), the Volvo Concept XC Coupe (surprisingly interesting; I kept staring at it) and the Nissan Sport Sedan Concept. I actually strongly disliked the Nissan until I spent some time looking at it more closely. The front end is too busy for my taste, but the little details were interesting, like the bump in the rear spoiler for the rounded top of the Nissan logo. I would like to see some of those thoughtful details carry over to a production model.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: I almost missed the Nissan GT-R Nismo, which was tucked away on an upper level. Oh my. That was a thing of beauty and a joy forever. I may have openly drooled.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: Less drool-worthy, but likely more notable: Cadillac continued its string of hits with the introduction of the ATS coupe. I really like the Cadillac design language and thought the ATS coupe looked great. I would love to see an ATS-V in the near future. And dare I suggest an ATS-V wagon?? That could be wicked.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: Other observations: the new Mercedes-Benz C-Class interior is fantastic. The new Subaru WRX STi had bland styling. BMW brought new M models in fabulous colors, a welcome relief from silver and black. Note to carmakers: bring cool colors to the shows. Silver does your cars no favors. BMW also brought a nifty motorcycle. The Cadillac ELR, my favorite debut from last year, looked lovely in its production-ready iteration. If you want to demonstrate your environmental consciousness and have the $60,000 to $70,000 to do so, buy an ELR.

And there were a number of racing cars, which I am always excited to see. Mazda and Scion get points for bringing actual racing cars with scratches, dents and duct tape.  Mazda also had its new 2014 prototype, which I look forward to seeing in endurance races this year. I’ve always been annoyed by Mazda's term “Skyactiv,” but I have to admit it looked pretty good plastered all over the prototype. Maybe it’s one of those words you just need to see in big letters, over and over again.

Chevrolet and Honda brought Indy cars, and Infiniti brought a Formula 1 car. Ford had a dirt-covered F-150 2.7-liter EcoBoost Baja Truck, which was very cool. The brand-new Corvette C7.R featured prominently next to the Corvette Z06.

image.altText: anna eby day 2 at auto show

pageElements.text: Acura gets points from me for bringing two racing cars, one of which hugged the wall like Spiderman, looming over the TSX. And the fabulous Delta Wing, which I saw make its racing debut at Circuit of the Americas, made an appearance.

I admit, the production cars are nice, but, at the end of the day, the racing cars make my heart beat the fastest.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: There's an important talk you probably haven't yet had, but should, with your young teenager.

Insurance agent Nathan Lamb cautions that parents should start thinking about, and budgeting for, teenage drivers when they turn fourteen, not sixteen. The jump is substantial, particularly if one buys into the American fantasy of a new car for Sweet Sixteen. It’s a lovely present, if you want to give yourself the companion gift of a huge premium increase at the same time.

Have a discussion with your teenager about all of the components that go into auto insurance, including the importance of a clean credit history.  You might need to explain credit scores.  Auto insurance provides a nice example of the relationship of credit history to other facets of adult life.  Remind them that good credit demonstrates responsibility; it also speaks to your character in your ability to pay your insurance premiums.  Good credit factors into lower premiums. Conversely, a bad credit score has real financial implications.
Here are a few choices you and your teenager need to make about how she or he will fit into your insurance plans.
For example, if I were I to add my sixteen-year-old to my policy with the Fiat 500 as my only car, the total cost of my insurance would increase 65 percent.

1. Add your teen to your own policy? Benefit: You can benefit from multi-vehicle discounts, if your insurer offers them, and the policy is based on your credit history and age, not just your teen's. Although you will note the vehicle your teen will use as his or her primary vehicle, like you, he or she is covered as an occasional driver on other cars as well. Downside: Your premium will go up for a few years, now that you’ve added a young and inexperienced driver. The number, of course, depends on the coverage you chose, but in my case, for example, were I to add my sixteen-year-old to my policy with the Fiat 500 as my only car, the total cost of my insurance would increase 65 percent. The increase takes into account the higher risk of an accident and the related claims associated with teenage drivers.

2. Get your teen his or her own policy? Benefit: Your own insurance rates won't be affected, and you won't be on the hook for any damage your teenager causes on your policy. Downside: It is more expensive to get a separate policy for each of you, and your teen's policy won't benefit from your own history and rates. Nathan cautions that this really is a last resort, one that occurs when the teen has had too many accidents or moving violations. The teen will be placed with a higher-risk insurer, which means much higher premiums.

3. Get your teen his or her own car? Nathan's advice: keep the old family car for the teen and give yourself the new one. It costs far less to insure a teen for a clunker than a shiny new Mustang. I’ll add that, two years ago, when I started talking to my Honda salesman about replacing my 2002 Odyssey, he advised me not to sell it or trade it in but to save it for my daughter, who was at that point fourteen. His argument: “You don’t want to be insuring a teenager on a new vehicle!”

Nathan echoed my salesman’s advice.  Again, in my case, were we to keep the ’02 Odyssey in addition to the Fiat and list Sarah’s primary vehicle as the Odyssey, my insurance will go up 57 percent, less than if I insured her on the Fiat alone.  Why?  I would keep the multi-car discount, and the resale value of an ‘02 Odyssey is far less than that of a '13 Fiat.

4. Establish responsibility. Since you are establishing parameters for your driving teen (who is responsible for paying for gas or routine maintenance), set your teen straight on accidents as well. Discuss how expensive they are, who pays for them, and how auto insurance works. If you are getting your teen his or her own car, you might consider limited collision. If your teen is in a wreck because of poor choices, the onus on fixing or replacing the car falls on him or her. Depending on the make and model year, you could be talking a couple of hundred dollars for a ding up to many thousands of dollars for major work. How you work this with your teen falls to parenting style. I asked Nathan what he was doing with his own upcoming teenage driver. He smiled and said, “She’ll be driving my old 2007 Camry. And if she wrecks it, she’ll be walking until she can afford to buy her own car. It’s a one-shot deal in our house.” That’s my kind of parenting as well, but every parent has to find his or her comfort zone. Determine that zone before an incident so your teen understands his or her responsibility.
5. Finally, don’t let your teen feel too entitled. A car is not a right; it is a privilege. That’s a good lesson to learn even at sixteen.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Each time we buckle in our babies, toddlers, and kids, we parents are putting a world of faith in our children’s car seats. Now the U.S. Department of Transportation's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, or NHTSA, has proposed expanding car seat testing to include side impacts. That's an important measure since, in children twelve and under, side impacts are responsible for nearly as many fatalities and serious injuries as frontal crashes, according to NHTSA.
in children twelve and under, side impacts are responsible for nearly as many fatalities and serious injuries as frontal crashes, according to NHTSA.

Right now, car seats are submitted to a 30-mph frontal crash simulation. The new test would be, as NHTSA describes it, a simulation of "a full-scale vehicle-to-vehicle side impact" in which a vehicle traveling at 30 mph T-bones the side of a smaller car going 15 mph. Unlike a front or rear impact, in which sometimes several feet of car material lay between occupants and the car or tree it's crashing into, the only barrier in a side impact is the car door or side panel, which can crush dangerously inward. NHTSA is adding a new three-year-old crash test dummy; the agency already has a twelve-month old dummy in its arsenal.

If the new rule is adopted, manufacturers will have three years to modify their products where necessary to meet the improved safety standards. You can weigh in during a ninety-day public comment period available soon via the government’s eRulemaking Portal. Just go to regulations.gov and enter reference number NHTSA-2014-0012 in the big blue search box.

Remember, having the best car seat money can buy is no asset if you aren’t using right.  According to the NHTSA, about 75 percent of children are either not in car seats at all or are riding in seats that are not installed properly. Yes, it can be tough to get older kids to stay in that booster or to get that clip-in base in the right position. Our car didn’t have the LATCH system, which was instituted in 2002, and it seemed only my husband was strong enough to effectively tighten the seatbelt to the car seat.  Since I knew he couldn’t be there every time I needed to move the seat I had to work out my own leverage system to get our daughter’s car seat installed properly.

So, read your car seat manual carefully and instruct any other caregivers installing the seat how to do it correctly. For added reassurance use the NHTSA Child Car Seat Inspection Station Locator, and have your installation skills double-checked. After all, regulations only get us halfway to safety. We parents have to make sure our kids make it the rest of the way.

metaDescription: Time for Super Bowl Car Ads: Our choices for the most innovative ads the carmakers came up with this year. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Super Bowl XLVIII is this Sunday, and whether you’re rooting for Peyton Manning and the Denver Broncos or Russell Wilson and the Seattle Seahawks (or none of the above), everyone can agree that the Super Bowl is home to some of the year’s best commercials, and especially car commercials. These days, you don't even need to wait until the actual game to see them. Here are a few of the most interesting:

1. Volkswagen: Wings

No, Volkswagen’s “Wings” commercial won’t hit you in the same emotional way its acclaimed Super Bowl ad “The Force” did in 2011. Nevertheless, “Wings” is a hilarious take on the line from It’s a Wonderful Life that “Every time a bell rings, an angel gets his wings.” It’s also a great way for the brand to remind viewers that, as one study found, there are more registered Volkswagens with more than 100,000 miles than any other car brand.

2. Kia: The Truth

Almost fifteen years ago, we watched Morpheus offer Neo a choice in the film The Matrix: take the blue pill (“the story ends, you wake up in your bed and believe whatever you want to believe”) or take the red pill (“you stay in Wonderland, and I show you how deep the rabbit hole goes”).

Now Laurence Fishburne is back in his iconic role in Kia’s Super Bowl commercial “The Truth.” In it, Morpheus offers the same basic choice to a young luxury-car-owning couple, with one caveat: take the blue key (“and go back to the luxury you know”) or take the red key (“and you’ll never look at luxury the same way again”).

Cue the all-new Kia K900, the company’s first luxury sedan. Between filmed explosions that might as well be from The Matrix, agents, and bending spoons, Kia does a terrific job of showing us that the K900 really may make us change the way we look at luxury. The only thing this commercial lacks is a cameo from Keanu Reeves.

3. Jaguar: Rendezvous

Jaguar's sixty-second "Rendezvous" is the first appearance of the marque at the Super Bowl, and it's the kickoff to a full ad campaign that rolls out the new F-Type. Sir Ben Kingsley and other ruggedly handsome faces you'll recognize from the movies make appearances as villains, asking the intriguing question, "Did you ever notice how, in Hollywood movies, all the villains are played by Brits?" This is the most cinematically rich ad of the bunch, and it ought to be: It was directed by Tom Hooper, who won an Oscar for directing The King's Speech.

4. Hyundai: Dad’s Sixth Sense

Hyundai will show two commercials at the big game, but the one that stands out to us is “Dad’s Sixth Sense,” an ad for the all-new Genesis luxury sedan. The commercial shows a father consistently jumping in to save his son from potential injury as a toddler all the way up to his teenage years. But there’s only so much a parent can do from the passenger's seat, giving Hyundai the opportunity to show off the Automatic Emergency Braking feature on the 2015 Genesis.

5. Audi: Doberhuahua

If there’s one thing the staff at Jean Knows Cars knows, it's dogs. Despite this, even we have some reservations about the Doberhuahua, an unpleasant blend of Doberman Pinscher and Chihuahua. Even Sarah McLachlan, showing more sense of humor than you might expect, makes an appearance in this cartoonish ad.

Though the all-new Audi A3 doesn’t make an appearance until the forty-five-second mark of this one-minute ad, the humorous setup of “Doberhuahua” is Audi's way of marketing its A3 as a no-compromise compact luxury sedan and taking aim at the competition (Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class)...

6. Chevrolet: Romance

Chevrolet’s “Romance” follows a 2015 Silverado Heavy Duty owner’s journey as he trailers a newly purchased bull back to his ranch. Beginning with a soft piano score and the husky voice of a male narrator, “Romance” seems just like every other truck commercial. That is, until the music picks up, and the soft piano is replaced by the unmistakable sound of “You Sexy Thing” by Hot Chocolate. This commercial reminds you that the Super Bowl is expecting a mainly male audience in a partying mood, but Chevrolet wins points for having also released this father-daughter ad the same week.

Plus: Budweiser: Puppy Love

Budweiser’s Super Bowl ad “Puppy Love” has nothing to do with cars (nor should any alcohol-related ad), but we just had to share it. The commercial follows the friendship of a puppy and a Clydesdale horse whose pesky owners continue to get in the way and try to keep the two apart.

Car Max: Slow Clap

Car Max's "Slow Clap" commercial is just silly. What town does this guy live in? But it gets a mention because Car Max also made a puppy version.

Toyota: Muppets

Toyota calls on the Muppets and actor Terry Crews, a former NFL player, to show off how spacious its Highlander is. Are all those Muppets strapped in?

pageElements.text: The lucky members of the USA’s two-man and two-woman bobsled teams are driving BMWs at the XXII Olympic Winter Games.. The German automaker used its EfficientDynamics technology to redesign the two-man bobsled. Michael Scully from BMW DesignWorks USA headed the project, aimed at making the U.S. team more competitive with a lighter and faster sled. It must have worked! The two-man team of Steven Holcomb and Steve Langton took the bronze medal on February 17 by an extremely invigorating 0.03 second over the next closest sled, that of the Russian team of Alexander Kasjanov and Maxim Belugin.
The BMW sled is sure to be just as much fun to watch when the women's teams compete on Feb. 18 and 19. (Full schedule here.)

BMW has provided Team USA a fleet of six of the new bobsleds. They're made of lightweight carbon fiber similar to that in the BMW i electric concepts. Traditionally, bobsleds have been made of fiberglass. The change has permitted massive weight savings. The two-person teams are helmed by Elana Meyers and Steven Holcomb, who took gold at Vancouver four years ago as head of the four-man team. Here's a brief glance at the team and the sled from NBC.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/HJZtOjseTxk" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
The U.S. team hasn’t won the gold in two-man bobsled since 1936. Interestingly, the last three Olympic gold medals in the sport have gone to...Germany.

Why isn't BMW supplying the German team instead of Team USA? I asked BMW spokeswoman Stacy Morris that question. She pointed out that Team USA is the only national Olympic team that doesn't get government funding and went on to say: "BMW consulted on the design of the German bobsled but didn't design the sled. A German government sport organization designed their sled." If you're looking for an argument for less government...

BMW held a sendoff party last week at its Munich headquarters for more than 100 athletes and functionaries of the U.S. bobsled, skeleton, and speedskating teams. They were treated to “traditional German-themed entertainment” on their way to Sochi and were offered tours of the BMW Welt facility, a shrine to the company’s products and activities next door to HQ. It was festooned with a Team USA banner for the occasion.

The automaker is into the Olympic Games in a serious way: BMW of North America is the Official Mobility Partner of the U.S. Olympic Committee, meaning it’s not just the bobsledders who will be spending some quality time in BMWs this month.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I love hitting the decade birthdays—twenty, thirty, forty, and so on—because it has always given me a chance to update my “story.” You know what I mean? The story of your life, what you like, what you believe, who done you wrong, all wrapped up in a couple of paragraphs that you present to people you meet? You’d be amazed at how moldy that story can get in ten years!

I have just emerged from a decade of nonstop adventure. Only this week, the progression of adventure slowed to a crawl as my broken right ankle continued to heal and I continued to NOT DRIVE. This gave me an opportunity to drink champagne at the SURPRISE office party, orchestrated by office manager extraordinaire Jackie Guenther. Balloons everywhere! A cake shaped like my Barbara Feinman VooDoo top hat! A lot of old friends from early years of Automobile Magazine and Car and Driver!

Then, traveling and cooking companions from the Poland, Ohio, arm of the large Boniface clan swooped in to fetch me home for a long birthday weekend, marked by snow, snow, and then a whole lot of snow. This killed the planned day of winter sport because the roads were a disaster. Interstate down to one crappy lane of barely moving cars, on-off ramps unplowed, north-south roads blown shut by drifting snow.

But Sunday was brilliant blue, the perfect opportunity to ride in my birthday present, a diesel-engined Kubota RTV with a hydraulic dumping bed, a winch, and a trailer hitch. This is reminiscent of the time I received the black-diamond Carhartt coveralls which fit my husband perfectly. I will be wearing the key on a chain around my neck lest he wear it out. If that’s even possible! We are now a two-Kubota family. They clearly should be advertising in Automobile Magazine and on JeanKnowsCars.com! A write-in campaign might help.

The stalwart Dufeks (parents of one of our G-7 favorites, Jacqueline) showed up at the farm late morning, bearing a big juicy King Cake, FedExed from New Orleans by LSU grad Candi Dufek. No one got the baby Jesus baked in their slice, but we all wore Mardi Gras (and Saints) beads and geared up for the Super Bowl. It wasn’t until they left to get ready for Super Bowl at home that I realized we had a bona fide Honest-to-God Seattle Seahawks hero on the couch. Donnie Dufek was drafted into the original team and played his entire eight-year career there. He was a star special teams player (and the only player to lead the club in special-teams tackles four times), after storming to fame as a Michigan Wolverine. He was captain of both teams. Never mind that he was also drafted while at Michigan by the NHL and the WHA.

Mostly, he’s Donnie, and he talked for an hour without stopping about what makes a team brilliant, why the same teams always hover around the top of the food chain, and why it’s so exciting to watch great teams play. Interesting to me that everything he said was a primer in how to be a great magazine or a great website, which is: it’s all about the team.

And then the Seahawks won. By halftime, our viewing regimen had shifted to bathroom breaks during play, glued to the couch for the ads. Enough has been said about the ads, right? The twelve-year-old boy in me can’t stop laughing about VW’s wing size comparo at the urinal. Bob Dylan was the freakiest, creepiest ad. Cool message, but…Bob Dylan?
I wept, I laughed, I yawned, I ate Doritos.

My actual birthday is today. I walked into the office to find a large black case marked with tape: FRAGILE PHILIP TREACY LONDON FRAGILE punctuated by his signature unicorn. My hat had arrived, my birthday present to myself! Flowers, cars, photos, birthday wishes from all corners of my blessed life—all part of my story for the new decade.

Thank you all for your contribution to Jean Knows Cars. You are kind and considerate to us and to each other. You are helpful and funny and I try to read every single comment on the site, on our Facebook page, on our Instagram feed, and in the Twitterverse, which is where I sometimes get a little out there. Sorry. Or not.
My husband is driving me to and from work while the ankle mends. You can imagine what kind of passenger I was while he was at the wheel of the Maserati Quattroporte.

My husband, Tim, has been spending four hours daily driving me to and from work while the broken right ankle mends enough to flex it. You can imagine what kind of bad passenger I was while he was the one at the wheel of the Maserati Quattroporte. (It was parked safely in the garage all weekend.) He is never mad, always teasing, the rock of our little family. Maybe I can coax him out again to review those Kubotas on a future episode of Jean’s Driveway. They are the only vehicles that can move freely in it these past two months!

Love,
Jean

title: The Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy
subTitle: Oh, Lord, won't you let me learn to drive in a Mercedes-Benz?
promoTeaserSmall: Oh, Lord, won't you let me learn to drive in a Mercedes-Benz?
promoTeaser: Oh, Lord, won't you let me learn to drive in a Mercedes-Benz?
metaTitle: The Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy: Oh, Lord, won't you let me learn to drive in a Mercedes-Benz? Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Your teenager may want to drive a Mercedes-Benz, but chances are you would like him or her to practice on something a little more….economical. However, the safety and driver assistance features of the modern Mercedes can’t be denied, and I know if I were suddenly wealthy, I wouldn’t sniff at making every one of my young adults the present of such a car.

That’s why I was interested to see that Mercedes-Benz USA has its own Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy. It’s intended to help teens “develop key decision-making skills…and create safer and more responsible drivers for life.” Sounds good to me, especially since teens are four times more likely to have a serious accident in their first year of driving. There’s a second point to the school, which is to educate parents as coaches for their teenage drivers.

The academy also addresses an interesting safety issue: many teenagers are waiting until they turn eighteen to start driving these days. That’s because Graduated Driver’s License (GDL) laws have rolled out all over the country, requiring teenagers to go through a gradual process from the learner’s permit to a restricted license at sixteen and on to full driving privileges over a period of years.

You’d think this would increase safety on the roads, but there’s a trend of people waiting to turn eighteen and taking the driver’s test, at which time they get full privileges immediately. The Mercedes program is intended to improve skills for those people as well as for drivers of all ages. I’m sure I could learn a few things from this school.

The Academy uses a range of Mercedes-Benz vehicles, each equipped with dual brake controls and dual rearview mirrors in the time-honored driving school style. Only one student is in the car at a time. A full program for the teenage learner costs $1,390—pricier than a traditional driving school, but a relative bargain considering that it includes fifteen hours of online modules, ten hours of classroom work, and sixteen hours of lessons behind the wheel, with complimentary pickup and dropoff.

Perhaps the most tempting of all is the Manual Transmission workshop. I learned to drive a stick in a rented Peugeot subcompact; how about you? At the Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy, manual-transmission learners are behind the wheel of an SLK250 roadster. A two-hour lesson is $230. There’s also a six-hour package ($660) and a ten-hour, five-lesson package for $1,050. This one is for already-licensed drivers or graduates of the academy’s regular program.
So let’s go!

Not so fast (so to speak). Like so many desirable things, the Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy is only in California. The first Mercedes driving school opened in 2011 in Los Angeles, there are programs available in Orange County, and a new fully fledged driving school opened in January in San Diego. There are also Mercedes-Benz Driving Academies in Germany, Canada, the U.K., the Netherlands, and China.

Mercedes-Benz is also offering free parent/teen workshops through schools and dealerships. Check the Driving Academy website for details on this and other programs.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Attending the U.S. introduction of the 2014 BMW 740 Ld xDrive at the Chicago Auto Show this week made me face the fact that you can’t really go wrong with BMW’s flagship sedan, the 7 Series. It is simply a beautiful piece of machinery. Adding diesel to the mix can only be a good thing!

"In 2009, BMW introduced its first modern diesel, the 335d X5, to the U.S.,” explained David Buchko, BMW Product and Technology Communications, at the introduction. What makes a "modern" diesel? "They're not like the diesels of old; they're clean and they're quiet," he explained.
These days, diesel technology has entered the eco arena, and since the 2009 introduction of the diesel BMW X5, one in five sold in the U.S. has been a diesel model.

BMW's history of producing diesel engines goes back more than three decades, to 1983. The first of these, a 2.4-liter straight-six engine, was available with a turbocharger. It was even sold to a number of American automakers for use in their vehicles. These days, diesel technology has entered the eco arena, and since the 2009 introduction of the X5, one in five sold in the U.S. has been a diesel model.

What's so great about this new diesel-powered BMW? To make you understand, here’s a brief snapshot. The lovely lines of the contoured exterior are painted a glowing metallic, pumped up with nineteen-inch alloy wheels and chrome accents and adorned with mellow LED headlights. The interior is plush with ivory white Nappa leather, with walnut root inlays and accents, including a customized instrument display.

This new model will feature BMW’s 3.0-liter TwinPower Turbo diesel engine, which brings on 255 horsepower and 413 pound-feet of torque. EPA fuel economy estimates and ranges are not yet available, but BMW says that combined mpg should be in the 30s. It was noted that other models equipped with this engine have seen a 25 to 30 percent improvement in fuel efficiency over their gasoline-powered equals.

As expected, the diesel model of the flagship sedan will offer all of the same amenities as its gas brother, including xDrive (BMW’s all-wheel-drive system) and fuel-saving strategies featuring driving dynamics control with Eco mode and auto start/stop.

The BMW 740Ld xDrive will kick off at $83,425 (including destination) when it arrives in U.S. showrooms this spring. Just FYI, that's $4,500 more than the gasoline-powered 2014 BMW 740Li sedan, which starts at $78,925.
For those of you interested in BMW’s advanced diesel but from a lower price point, Buchko noted that BMW will be offering the X3 diesel in 2015.

metaDescription: Stuck on the Road in Atlanta: Jenny was one of those people you heard about. How she coped when her 30-minute drive took 13 hours. Read her story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Jenny Gould, a dance teacher at a private school in Atlanta, Georgia, was released early from work on January 28 due to a freak winter storm. It was 1:30 p.m., and she was about to embark on an unprecedented journey home. A trip that normally takes her thirty minutes ended up taking thirteen hours.
The January 28 storm paralyzed the city of Atlanta. Nearly three inches of snow and ice caused one of the worst traffic jams in history.

“I started off on Interstate 75 North and it was gridlocked. Basically, I would move a tiny bit forward, stop and move a tiny bit forward, then stop and idle for forty-five minutes or so. It was hell!” she recounted.
But this was only the beginning of her hellish journey. Luckily, she had provisions (an orange, a granola bar, and a bottle of water), which she smartly rationed off during the entire fiasco.

After three hours of traffic jams and gridlocks on the Interstate, Gould took an exit to a back road. Her plan to escape the snarl was a bust. She was stuck on that shortcut for the next five hours.  
 
By that time it was dark, the temperature was dropping, and the roads were icing over.

“I kept telling myself to 'keep moving…you can do this,' " she said. “I was praying to God to just get me home. It was terrifying and surreal at the same time. I experienced a gamut of emotions, from fear and anger to intense determination.”

As Gould watched, an otherworldly scenario unfold outside her windshield. “Some people abandoned their cars and started walking, while others were getting stuck and looking lost and confused. It was like being in a zombie movie.”
She took an exit to a back road. Her plan to escape the snarl was a bust. She was stuck on that shortcut for the next five hours.

The teacher adds, “I am so grateful that my mechanic convinced me to buy state of the art Michelin Defender tires last summer.  The combination of those and my Nissan Altima coupe saved my life.” Were the wheels worth the investment?  You bet. While other vehicles were sliding all over the place, Gould’s 2010 Nissan Altima coupe remained solid. (No, this is not a car promotion! It also helped that Gould had lived in New York for many years and knew how to navigate snow and ice.)

To keep calm during the calamity, the dancer listened to talk radio to get storm updates and chatted with friends and family on her phone. It was also a mixed blessing that she wasn’t going it alone. The lines of cars around her provided some comfort.

The Moment of Truth

However, that would all change around 1:30 a.m. “I was faced with a major decision. There was a big hill up ahead, and I watched cars struggling, sliding, and getting stuck. At that point, I could either pull over in a scary industrial area and sleep in my car, or I could keep going.”
The driver decided to brave the incline. Once her Nissan tackled that obstacle, the road became what she described as an open, empty and frozen wasteland of whiteness.
“I was truly on my own as I proceeded over a bridge of sheer ice. The only vehicle on the road was a bus blinking its hazards in front of me. I followed it all the way home,” she said.
The survivor pulled into her driveway at 2:30 a.m. “It took thirteen hours, or the equivalent of a road trip to Dallas, Texas or hey, even Chicago!” she quipped.

The takeaway? Gould feels that a strong will, and remaining mentally and emotionally calm, can get you through anything. Since the debacle, she has packed a survival bag in the trunk of her car. It contains a change of clothes, boots, water, snacks, hand sanitizer, two blankets, two towels, and a first aid kit.
The survivor summed it up, “I am still adding to it, but hey, you never know in this age of unpredictable weather. You need to be ready.”

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: Even in years that haven’t experienced a Polar Vortex, ten percent of U.S. vehicle crashes are due to snow, sleet, ice, and slush, according to the Department of Transportation. That’s a lot of slipping, sliding, and insurance claims that might be avoided if more drivers knew how to operate their vehicles when the weather turns.

As a general rule, if you live in a part of the country where it snows and you can see your breath, you should have winter tires that offer more grip when the going gets slippery. A set of winter tires lasts about four winter seasons and will set the average driver back about $1,000, but the payback is potentially significant. A driver could pay that much in a deductible if she lost control of her car and cracked a fender. Or worse.
If you live in a part of the country where it snows and you can see your breath, you should have winter tires that offer more grip when the going gets slippery.

I have just been schooled in the benefits of winter tires at the Bridgestone Winter Driving School in Steamboat Springs, Colorado, where I spent a half day wheeling various Lexus vehicles around two snow-packed tracks, each with multiple types of turns and inconsistent surfaces. Designed to improve drivers’ inclement weather skills while simultaneously promoting the use of winterized wheels, regardless of what brand is stamped in the rubber, the school starts at $495 for a half day. One- and two-day schools are also available with passenger's-seat coaching in the techniques that will keep a car where it belongs: on the road.
After that eye-opening experience, I made this list of five techniques to remember when the roads are coated with snow:

1. Slow down.

Speed is not your friend when a road is coated with snow, slush, ice, or even worse—a combination of all three. Lighten up your lead foot, and you’ll be rewarded with more control.

2. Avert your eyes from that hulking snowbank.

In fact, keep your eyes off any other object you’d like to avoid. The surest way to make unwanted contact with a ditch or another driver’s bumper is to fixate on it. Look where you want to go, and the car is more likely to do the same.

3. A little steering goes a long way.

When you’re steered into a turn and the car still isn’t going where you’d like, the temptation is to steer in the same direction even more. The opposite action is needed. Steer less when entering a turn. And if you’ve already steered too much, unwind the wheel slightly to straighten out the car and try steering again—gently.

4. Don’t attempt to steer when accelerating or braking.

In slick conditions, steering, accelerating, and braking should be separate actions. Brake and accelerate in a straight line, and keep your foot off the pedals entirely when turning.

5. No sudden moves.

It might work on dry pavement, but sudden movements, such as manhandling the steering wheel or abruptly pressing the brake and accelerator pedals, are magnified by snow or ice. Handle the car as if it was a newborn baby, and you’re less likely to fishtail or spin out.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pageElements.text: We are stopped at a red light, and an orange L.A. Metro Local bus lurches to our side.  The bus driver draws opens his passenger door and calls out to Richard Pietruska, “That’s beautiful!”  And then Richard and I, in his exotic black on black 1996 Acura NSX, zoom off along the Pacific Coast Highway, the motor’s big purr a more seductive sound than some music.  Richard has driven the car at 110 mph, but we didn’t go quite that fast.

Richard Pietruska is an award-winning sculptor of car-derived artwork like those shown here.  He describes these works as “sort of an automotive fantasy without the wheels.” Richard is also a professor of automotive design at Pasadena’s Art Center College of Design.

I peer into the pristine garage of his Santa Monica home, a few blocks from the beach. Richard also possesses a 2001 Porsche 911 and requires a van for transporting his sculptures, but it’s the 1996 Acura two-door coupe that he loves. He says, “It was just one of those unique cars. It came along and I just happened to have money for another car, so I sold my 300ZX Nissan and moved up to the NSX.
"It’s such a great car to drive.  The interior’s open, the vista’s great, and it sounds good.  And it’s comfortable.  It’s a really amazing car.”

Honda had originally developed the NSX (New Sportscar eXperimental) in the 1980s to compete with Porsche and with the Italians, particularly Ferrari and Lamborghini.  In some ways, the Japanese beat the Europeans at their own game.  And at a lower price point.  It premiered VTEC (Variable Valve Timing/Lift Electronic Control), and its high-strength aluminum monocoque construction made it hundreds of pounds lighter than other athletic sports cars. The rear wheels were an inch larger than the front wheels.

The two-seater’s interior visibility was based on an F-16 cockpit concept, and riders noted superb ergonomics and extraordinary acceleration and performance. The cars were all hand-built in a unique factory in Tochigi, Japan.

It was a prohibitively priced car to make, and Acura stopped manufacturing the NSX in 2005, after a fifteen-year run. Many consider it one of the most influential sports cars in history. Demand for its blend of high performance, exceptional reliability, and drivability continues. There is also extreme brand loyalty; NSX clubs are found worldwide.

Fortunately for those aficionados, Honda’s 2015 production will include an ultra-high-tech second-generation Acura NSX, equipped with a mid-engine V-6 hybrid drivetrain, being manufactured in Ohio. The original NSX won Automobile Magazine’s Automobile of the Year and Design of the Year in 1991. I wonder how this supercar will be received next year!

Some enthusiasts have said the Acura NSX has the performance and looks of a Ferrari with Honda reliability.  Richard’s vehicle is both sexy and comfortable, crowned with a removable targa top.  It has power windows, locks, and mirrors and hand-sewn leather interiors and steering wheel trim. His car has a  3.0-liter V-6 that makes 270 horsepower with a five-speed manual transmission. It offers traction control and dual front airbags, a power driver’s seat, Bose stereo, and an alarm system.
While Richard has only around 70,000 miles on his, some NSX owners claim mileage in the 200,000 range with the cars still running impeccably, without maintenance headaches.

Richard Pietruska knows car design as few others do.  As a professor of transportation and product design at the Art Center, he has taught many of the most illustrious designers in the field. And in recent years, he has been pleased by the increase in female students.  He says, “Some of the women designers are getting more famous than the guys.”  Richard’s students have included Frank Stephenson, head of design for McLaren; Ford master designers Freeman Thomas, J Mays, and Chelsea Lau; Chris Bangle, the former chief of design for BMW; Henrik Fisker, former designer for Aston Martin and Fisker; Shiro Nakamura, head of design for Nissan; Franz von Holzhausen, chief designer at Tesla; GM design studio chief Frank Saucedo, and Cadillac senior designer Christine Park.  A couple of Richard’s alumni even helped design the original NSX.

Although he loves his Acura NSX, Ferraris have probably been Richard’s favorite car to sculpt, and he is the author and illustrator of the humorous book Fantastico Ferrari Fever as well as Perpetuating Porsche Paranoia. He also pursues the sculpting of “a lot of old cars, the Talbot-Lago, Bugattis, Jaguars.”

Richard shows me an intriguing anthropomorphic sculpture, a curving bronze Alfa Romeo with a female body reflected beneath it. He casts editions of his artwork in bronze, resin, stainless steel, aluminum, and fiberglass. He also sculpted our brother publication Automobile Magazine's Automobile of the Year trophy for the Porsche Boxster, in 1998. His preferred sculpture materials are those that are "related to automotive qualities,” says the member of the Automotive Fine Arts Society and proud owner of an Acura NSX.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: The FF stands for Ferrari Four meaning that rumbling V12 engine is in service of the closest the Italian carmaker comes to a four-seat family vehicle.  Something like a crossover masquerading in an exotic’s clothing the all-wheel drive can take the corners and also give you confidence in those mountain snowstorms.  Pop the back hatch to access the generous storage compartment for luggage or sports equipment. Each seat feels like its own little cockpit and the two rear ones fold down when necessary to extend cargo space.  Slide into the leather-covered cabin and enjoy meticulous Italian detail at every turn. If you plan on taking grandma for a ride she’ll need to use the front seat since, unlike the four-door Aston Martin Rapide, the FF has only two doors making easy rear access a challenge for some. However, when you step on the gas and feel the revs climb up to 8200 rpm there will be no doubt why you spent around $300,000 to own this versatile supercar.  The back-heavy look of the FF can seem like a departure from the classic Ferrari exterior silhouette and will not appeal to everyone.  However, enough prancing horse signatures remain to satisfy the buyer seeking a rarified vehicle that can get the groceries or tear up the track depending on their mood.

pageElements.text: Last year Honda redesigned its most unique mid-size offering to fully embrace the crossover badge it wears and leave behind those comments of, “What kind of car is that?” when it was known as the Accord Crosstour. The 2014 model carries the crossover torch with a more SUV-like body highlighted by larger foglamps, new wheels, wider rearview mirrors, and chrome accents that give it a more aggressive presence overall.  It’s lower to the ground like a car but has a high seating position for visibility, a feature especially important in a vehicle with a swooping rear end that cuts down on some of the greenhouse real estate in back.  To feel even more secure when backing out of the driveway, all Crosstours now come with a standard rearview camera.  Pick from two engine choices, a five-speed four-cylinder automatic or a paddle-shift-equipped six-speed V-6, and there are also front-wheel-drive or four-wheel-drive models to consider. Crossovers seek to tick a lot of users' boxes, and this one delivers great handling as well as an enviable 25.7 cubic feet of cargo space, and that’s before folding the 60/40 split rear seats down nearly flat. The interior is comfortable with good headroom, the stack and dash are neatly arranged ,but like its Accord sibling there is a certain panache lacking. Tech and driver assist options aplenty make up for the pedestrian interior, and count on Honda safety features to come standard. The Crosstour is more fuel efficient than earlier iterations, with Honda reporting that the two-wheel-drive I-4 achieves 22 mpg for city driving and delivers up to 31 mpg on the highway. Now that it has finally squeaked into the over-30 mpg-club, followers of the brand will be more attracted than ever to this most distinctive Honda.

Volvo XC70

Cool Tech:

The EX-L V-6 model is also available with real time four-wheel drive.
Active head restraints adjust forward to protect the neck in a rear-end collision.

Looks:

Beefier exterior gives a nod to the sport utility category but retains carlike accessibility.

pageElements.text: The 2014 Honda CR-Z gas/electric hybrid is perhaps the sportiest way to go green. Updated last year, the stylish coupe only seats two people, and maybe only two small people at that, with a slim 49.1 cubic feet of passenger space. Cargo space is spartan as well, but Honda seeks to make the most of it with storage bins in a rear console that can also fold down for longer items. The hatchback’s low back end gives it that speedster look but unfortunately also limits rear visibility.  Still, the tight squeeze fits with the character of the car. Buyers can choose between increased fuel economy with the continuously variable automatic transmission (36 mpg city/39 highway) and the driving enjoyment of a nicely weighted manual transmission that achieves a respectable 31 mpg for city driving and 38 on the highway.  Great fuel efficiency plus a low price point, starting around $20,000, will attract the young and eco minded as well as those looking for a fun second car.
