contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: For the second time in the past three years, GCH Irish's Robert Garcia De Padua was accepted at the prestigious Westminster Kennel Club dog show. Not to beat a dead horse (although I am still irked), but it would have been three for three if husband Tim hadn't gone cheap with mailing the entry last year and used FedEx instead of the USPS, which delivered our critical entry form one day too late.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/6GTqXS7pxIY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Okay, let's be brutally honest. I used to believe that entering Westminster is a total waste of time and money if you are not a breeder. But I've come to believe that this isn't a breeders' show: it's a show for professional dog handlers.

If there is doubt, watch Westminster on television and listen to the color commentator. After explaining that the judging is all about the dog and its perfection of form and personality (or lack thereof), he never fails to carry on most of the telecast about the handlers—where they've worked, how many times they've won best in show and on which dogs.

It makes perfect sense. In the byzantine world of showing dogs, the basic training ground for becoming a (paid) judge is to working up through the ranks as a professional handler. Perhaps not all, but certainly a majority of dog show judges have been handlers. And it's not uncommon to find someone judging a dog being handled by a former employee.

Despite knowing it is so, despite seeing it and experiencing it for Bob's five years on the show circuit, despite knowing that it will be like watching Russian figure skating judges at work, we still go to Westminster because it's still Westminster and we think Bob's perfect in every way. The phrase used in the dog show world to describe the myopic attitude is "kennel blind."
Bob the Reluctant Show Dog showed in Auburn, Indiana, last weekend, so people could go to a dog show and then go on to the fabulous Auburn-Cord-Duesenberg Museum.

Bob is the second highest-ranked Grand Champion Chesapeake Bay retriever in the state of Michigan. He is currently 106 points away from the 400 points he needs to earn the ultimate Gold Grand Champion status.
Hope you enjoy our own like "Best in Show" documentary.

pageElements.text: On the list of fun shopping excursions, buying new tires rates pretty low. Yet, every year our trusty tires transport an average of three tons of vehicle upward of 20,000 miles, making those four rubber circles key players in our personal safety. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration reports, “More than 11,000 tow-away crashes occur every year related to tire issues.” It can be tempting to let those aging tires roll on a few more months, but if yours are showing signs of wear, it’s time to go shopping. You can narrow down your search using online tools like Tire Rack's Tire Decision Guide. Here are five things to think about when shopping for new tires.

1. Know when it's time for a change. Keep an eye out for worn tread (if you see the threadlike wear indicators emerging on a tread, it’s definitely time for a change). You can use a penny or a quarter to do the time-honored tread depth check. Look for bulges in the sidewalls, but also pay attention to how the car drives. New road noise, the car pulling to one side, or a vibration in the steering wheel could all be signs that your tires are past their prime. Tiffane Thompson, a Michelin spokesperson, recommends rotating your tires about every 6,000 miles. That’s also the ideal time to have your service person give them a thorough inspection.

2. Know your type. There are many variations on the tire theme beginning with three basic categories. All-season tires, the little black dress of the tire world, are suited to a variety of driver demands. Built for longevity, they go from dry to wet to snow, all while keeping the ride quiet and the handing sufficient in most conditions. Winter tires have a unique tread that notches or bites into the snow and ice for better traction, but on clear roads, grip can suffer. Performance tires are designed for drivers who toss their cars through the corners expecting superior grip and handling in wet or dry conditions. The downside to racy performance is a softer tread that will wear more quickly and a ride you might feel in your backside.

3. Consider your climate. Thompson says all season tires will likely do the job year round for those of us in sections of the country with moderately cold seasons and snowfall. For dwellers in the great white north where severe winters and consistently frigid temps are the norm, she urges, “There is no substitute for winter tire usage for safe mobility.” If serious rainfall is your main weather challenge, seek out tires with a tread designed to maximize water evacuation for a reliable wet grip.

4. Make lifestyle choices. If you are focused on efficiency and reducing carbon emissions in other areas of your life, you might consider eco-friendly tires. They are constructed for low rolling resistance to boost fuel economy and sustainable manufacturing, putting less CO2 into the atmosphere. Some of the brand names are Michelin HydroEdge with Green X, Continental ProContact with EcoPlus Technology, Goodyear Assurance Fuel Max, and Kumho eco Solus HM KR22. Originally created for use on hybrid and other "green" vehicles, they are increasingly available for a range of vehicles.

5. Take the long view. No matter what tires you chose remember to ask detailed questions about the warranty. How many miles does it cover, and what, such as improper maintenance, could potentially void it? Some tire stores and manufacturers offer road hazard warranties, generally at extra cost, which may appeal to you for peace of mind. Thompson stresses the importance of maintenance as well. “To prolong tire life, try to avoid hard stops and starts…keep your car in alignment, and maintain proper tire pressure.”
So evaluate your driving needs, grab your wallet and go shopping for best quality tire you can afford.  Your most precious cargo is riding on this purchase.

pageElements.text: When you sit in the driver’s seat of the all-new 2015 Audi A3, as I just did, you could easily miss how tech-laden this car is. There aren’t a lot of dials or screens. In fact, the look is spare and minimal. Turn on the engine, and a screen pops up offering route guidance. Still, nothing here screams pencil protector and nerdy glasses. But the technology is there, integrated into the car in a way that’s probably a bit of a historical moment in car design. There is a good reason this car was launched officially in Silicon Valley, heart of technology, and just a stone’s throw from Google, which was a partner in the development of this car.
A reasonably informed nerd might assume the machine being made here is a slick gaming tablet rather than a sweet ride: Nvidia, Google, ATT, and Qualcomm were in on it.

Take a look at the tech companies Audi partnered with on the A3. A reasonably informed nerd might assume the machine being made here is a slick gaming tablet rather than a sweet ride: Nvidia, Google, AT&T, and Qualcomm were in on it. The technology is baked quietly into the vehicle, not riveted on after the fact. But you will know it’s there when you use it.
As a tech geek, I love to see this much technology in my ride. So let me introduce you to technologies that make this car worthy of a Silicon Valley launch.

From Qualcomm: Gobi 4G/LTE Modem

Got a smartphone? There is a good chance, then, that you hold one of Qualcomm’s products in your hand every day. This company makes the Snapdragon processors and modems that power some of the most powerful smartphones on the market. The A3 has the newest Gobi 4G/LTE modem.

Your next question is probably, “Why?” Does my car need to connect to the Internet if I have a smartphone? Yes, it does, for reasons that make this car future proof: Want to connect your laptop, tablet, and whatever else you or your family uses to access the information superhighway while you fly down the tarmac superhighway?

This modem creates a fast Wi-Fi hotspot in the car and lets passengers connect up to eight devices. But that’s not the only reason. When a car can connect to the Internet to update its own software and maps, it won’t ask you to plug in a USB dongle or take it to the dealer to do that. And you won’t ever have to suffer outdated maps or technology. The car can do small, frequent updates the same way your phone does.

So, as the Internet of things evolves, your connected car can update itself to keep up, connecting to your house, your phone, other cars, parking structures, and the rest of the world. Connected! It’s what computers—be they desktop, laptop, tablet, phone, toaster, or sexy sedan—like to be.

From AT&T: The Data Connection

AT&T is providing the data connection to that Gobi modem, making the A3 the first car on the streets to have a 4G/LTE connection. (There are other cars following quickly, including all cars with OnStar.) And that means that after a six-month free trial period, when you will no-doubt become completely dependent on having data in the car, you’ll have to buy your car a data plan. Audi and AT&T will offer two options: a 5GB six-month plan for $99 or a 30GB thirty-month plan for $499.

From Nvidia: The Graphics Processor

Ask any teenager what the difference is between your perfectly adequate work computer and the one he or she covets for playing high-end graphical games. The answer is likely to be “an Nvidia graphics processor.” These little microchips handle high-speed, ultra-rich displays without choking or making you wait. That means the A3’s in-dash display will deliver detailed, intricate graphics that can keep up with the apps and services you will want to display there.

From Google: The Mapping

This machine is connected, has a data feed, and is capable of high-speed graphics processing? That makes Google Maps Street View and Google Earth possible right in that pop-up display. Because isn’t that where you want to keep your maps? In the car? Yes. You are driving a computer.

title: 2014 Kia Cadenza
subTitle: Who'd have expected? A smooth, capacious full-size sedan from Korea. Should you buy it?
promoTeaserSmall: Who'd have expected? A smooth, capacious full-size sedan from Korea. Should you buy it?
promoTeaser: Who'd have expected? A smooth, capacious full-size sedan from Korea. Should you buy it?
metaTitle: 2014 Kia Cadenza - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Kia Cadenza: A smooth, capacious full-size sedan from Korea. Who'd have thought? Should you buy it?

pageElements.text:
Price: $35,900 base price (including destination), $41,950 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 293 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Eight-inch screen with navigation and rearview camera display
Option I can’t live without: Heated everything: steering wheel, both front seats (which is a standard feature), and both outboard rear seats
Notable standard features on this model: Dual-zone climate control with auto filtration; Infinity surround sound audio; Bluetooth connectivity; SiriusXM radio (three months free); paddle shifters; heated power-folding mirrors; rain-sensing wipers; leather-trimmed seats, steering wheel, and shift knob
Notable options on this model: Technology package ($3,000) includes “smart” cruise control, blind spot detection, lane departure warning, electronic parking brake, hydrophobic windows in front door, nineteen-inch alloy wheels; Luxury package ($3,000) includes panoramic dual sunroof, ventilated driver’s seat, power telescoping steering wheel, and power rear window sunshade
You might also be considering: Buick LaCrosse, Chevrolet Impala, Chrysler 300, Lexus ES350, Toyota Avalon

How do you feel about a luxury sedan with the name “Kia” on the grille? If you are prejudiced against the Korean brand because you think it only makes cheap econocars, you are several years out of date. This is an ambitious automaker with every intention of making its name synonymous not only with value but with quality.

How do I know this? Because I drove this full-size Cadenza on a 640-mile round trip last weekend, and I was thoroughly impressed. From physical comfort, aesthetics, and driving enjoyment points of view, this car is a keeper.

There’s something really pleasant about getting into a big car that has more than enough room, especially when it’s as cleanly attractive as this one. There’s a kind of unpretentiousness that rightly goes along with that Kia badge—and Kia gets major points from me for not trying to make this car gaudy in an attempt to justify the $41,950 as-tested price.

A cadenza, as you may or may not know, is moment in a classical concerto performance when the orchestra sits quietly while the violinist, cellist or other soloist gets to play a virtuosic passage. It may be an odd name for a car that isn’t exactly a virtuoso, but it’s better than the name it has in the Korea market, K7. It’s the biggest Kia for now, but the seriously luxurious 2015 Kia K900 sedan is coming soon, priced starting just over $60,000. (Not sure why they didn't name it something equally majestic, such as the Glissando, or the Oratorio.)

But back to the Cadenza. I open the trunk: It’s almost too big, in terms of being a large, uncontoured flat space. In fact, I opened it to put my computer bag inside, then decided it was just going to roll around in there, and instead I loaded it in the back seat. I would have liked some kind of trunk organizer or separator, and if I bought this car, I’d get one. But if you were going on a road trip, you could probably fit most or all of your gear in this trunk and leave the passenger compartment for the passengers—always a bonus. Trunk volume: 15.9 cubic feet, about on par for its class, but humongous for those who are used to mid-size or smaller cars.

There are almost too many driver-coddling features on the Cadenza to name. It starts with the side mirrors, which close up against the car’s body when you park, then reopen when you unlock the car. These have light bars that light up and sparkle as you open the door and climb in. The seats adjust to a neutral position when you shut off the ignition, and they regain the settings you’ve chosen as soon as you get back in. The seats are easily positionable, including lumbar support for the driver (not the front passenger, however). And everything is heated: four seating positions, plus the steering wheel. This can not possibly be overrated when the temperature outdoors is in the single digits.

The UVO telematics were easy to use, clear, and easy to adjust—virtually no learning curve to pair my iPhone, change the radio station, or adjust the climate control. The dual sunroofs filled the interior of the car with light, most welcome at the end of a long winter, and the off-white leather upholstery added to the clean, clear feeling inside. No shiny fake wood; no bright colors; nothing extraneous. There’s even an analog clock in the center stack.

Those of you who are short, like me, might share this minor annoyance: when the driver’s seat is far enough forward for a 5’3” driver, the sun shade can’t be moved over to the driver’s-side window. (Well, it can, but not without a wrestling match.) The shade is usefully long, but so long that it doesn’t fit past the bulbous front-leaning headrest. This mattered to me when heading south on I-69 as the long-overdue sun came pounding up over the horizon at dawn.
But if that’s the worst thing to say about driving the Cadenza, that says something about how pleasant the experience really was.

That fuel economy of 19 mpg in town and 28 mpg on the highway is not stellar—but you would not expect stellar from a large sedan with a V-6 making almost 300 horsepower. Its fuel economy is the same as that of the Acura TSX, some BMW 5- and 7-series sedans, the Cadillac CTS AWD, the Lexus IS350, and the Lincoln MKS and MKZ, among others.


As for the driving experience, I knew I was driving a large four-door sedan the whole time, but it was completely smooth, energetic, and comfortable, handling both freeway and surface-road driving with full competence. No complaints.

But let’s talk about technology, and you will understand why I say the Cadenza is an old-man car in the best possible meaning of the term. With the Technology package (a $3,000 option), you get “smart” cruise control, blind spot detection, and lane departure warning. The blind spot detection lights up a red symbol on the side mirrors when another vehicle is near yours—which can quickly become a can’t-live-without feature once you are used to it. The lane departure warning feature is enabled with a switch to the left of the steering wheel. Choose it, and it will make an annoying “beepbeepbeep” when you even think about getting up on the center line or close to the edge of the road. The biggest magic, though, is found in the “smart” cruise control. I set it to 71—the cops in Indiana are ruthless—and enjoyed the way it showed an image of my car on the dash in front of me, then added an image of the car in front of me whenever there was one anywhere in range. Then, as soon as I got any closer than the computer’s idea of safe following distance, the car overrode the cruise control and slowed me down—all the way to 60 mph, at which time I overrode it myself by accelerating and passing the sedate Subaru that was, in my mind, plenty far ahead of me the whole time. For those of you who like to speed up on slower cars and pass them—just about everybody—you might call this frustrating. But put these three safety features together, and you are not going to be in any danger of rear-ending anybody, straying out of your lane, or missing a car, bicyclist, or motorcyclist in your blind spot. Even the heated steering wheel shepherds you along, since it's only heated in the center where your hands are supposed to be, not at the top or bottom.
Do you see why I’d love to see my eighty-five-year-old father signing a deal to buy one of these? Or my twenty-one-year-old college student son?

Or, really, even myself. Yeah, I’d turn off the active safety features, especially the lane keeping, some of the time. But it was actually nice to have the car’s “help” with my driving since I was behind the wheel for ten straight hours on a pretty boring stretch of highway.

pageElements.text:
The Verdict:

The Kia Cadenza is in the same price range as the Chevrolet Impala, the Toyota Avalon, and the Chrysler 300, yet it feels a good deal more luxurious. It's not a groundbreaking car, but it is one that will give you a full range of safety technologies, creature comforts, and electronic gadgetry, all in an understated way, without leaving you feeling like you're driving a spaceship. There is only one thing that might give you pause: that three-letter word Kia on the front. And if this automaker keeps it up, it will soon become a badge of honor.

Peanut Gallery:

Scott Allen: My mom has a late-1990s Buick sedan, and this car felt more like that than any other car I can think of, although in a very modern way. It really has a classic American-car vibe to it. Although it doesn't look that huge when parked, and it's not, it feels very big once you're inside. That's a good thing, whether you're sitting in the front seat or in the back. Anyone who, like my mom, is comfortable with a traditional American-style sedan will feel at home in the Cadenza. One thing I didn't like was the heated steering wheel. I do appreciate the heating, but the top and bottom of the wheel were ice cold while the sides were burning hot. That's a minor point, though.

Molly Jean: This is a sedan that is worthy of a road trip. There is so much trunk space that you can leave your sport-ute at home. The cabin is nicely styled, with a minimalist feeling even though it is stuffed with high-tech features. Best of all, it delivers a luxurious ride for the passengers, and the driver will be plenty happy with the V-6. This car would be a perfect daily driver to remove some of the grind of commuting.

pageElements.text: As the mother of an eleven-year-old boy who has become increasingly obsessed with video games, I was getting worried. Like most parents, I want to raise a son with character and a sense of responsibility—not a kid who’s prone to escape down the rabbit hole of the Internet. So I did something that disrupted my son’s couch-borne comfort. In an attempt to recapture the sense of adventure he had before discovering Minecraft, I bought him a dirt bike for his birthday.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: My gift wasn’t exactly out of the blue. I’ve been riding motorcycles for twenty-two years. For as long as my kid can remember, he’s seen me on a bike. Last year, we took the first steps toward dirt biking as a family when my son and I went to Dirt Bike School together, and in February, I sealed the deal. Not only did I buy my son his very first motorbike, I followed it up by purchasing one for myself.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: It’s been a month, and so far, we’ve been on two dirt bike adventures together, both of which have been filled with beginner’s folly, but our trips have also had the desired effect. They’re allowing us to spend more quality time together and experience situations that are helping me impart crucial life lessons about resilience, nature, community—the list goes on and on.
So, fellow parents. If you’re at all like me and looking for a radical solution to get your kids motivated to participate in life and on two wheels, I have the following advice:

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: 1. Go to dirt bike school. Yes, a formal school exists. One of twenty-three different safety programs run by the Motorcycle Safety Foundation, Dirt Bike School is available nationally to children as young as six. If your child has the hang of a pedal bike and is coordinated enough that replacing his bicycle’s hand grip with a throttle isn’t likely to end with an ambulance, Dirt Bike School is a great way to learn the basics of how to properly mount the bike and turn it on, then operate the clutch, throttle, and brakes and, finally, to ride. Prices for the one-day course vary by location, but when I took it with my son in Southern California, it cost $400 for the two of us in a semi-private lesson.
No one is going to ride your child’s bike for him. If he can’t handle falling down and will whine about getting back up and riding out, dirt biking isn’t right for him.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: 2. Know your kid. Does your kid want to do this? I mean, does he really, really want to? If you have a kid who’s a quitter or who doesn’t like to try new things or be outdoors or has genuine fears about falling down, dirt biking probably isn’t the right sport. No one is going to ride your child’s bike for him. If he can’t handle falling down and will whine about getting back up and riding out, dirt biking isn’t the right activity.

3. Assess your finances. There are a lot less expensive sports to get involved with. Basketball, gymnastics, swimming—the cost of participation in more traditional sports at the amateur level is a fraction of the cost of dirt biking. First, there are the bikes, which will cost a minimum of $800 per motorcycle, if used, and exponentially more if purchased new. I bought two new bikes this winter, the sum total of which came to about $11,000.

Then there’s the issue of the vehicle needed to get the bikes to the dirt, which, in my case, was $6,000 for a used Ford F-150. My daily driver is an all-electric Nissan Leaf that can’t travel the distance needed to get to an off-road vehicle area—or tow, for that matter. If you don’t have a truck but do have a vehicle that can tow, you’ll need a trailer. That will cost a minimum of $1,000, unless you want one that’s juryrigged from plywood, in which case you can get one for $200 on Craigslist.
Yes, there are special dirt bike socks, and they’re worth every penny. Hell hath no fury like a mom with chafed shins.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: Finally, there’s all the gear. Dirt biking is even more gear intensive than street biking. Embracing the mantra “expect the best, prepare for the worst” will set you back another $500 per person—at least—between the helmet, goggles, chest protector, knee pads, elbow pads, gloves, boots, jersey, pants and, uh, socks. Yes, there are special dirt bike socks, and they’re worth every penny. Hell hath no fury like a mom with chafed shins.

4. Determine the best bike for the job. It used to be that children’s dirt bikes were snorting, torquey two-strokes that could only be brought to life with a kick start. These days, most modern dirt bikes for children are more user-friendly four-strokes, but they’re still carbureted, rather than fuel injected. Some even have electric, or push-button, starts like modern street bikes.

image.altText: get your kid a dirt bike

pageElements.text: 5. Figure out your own level of resolve. Do you know enough about motorcycles, mechanically, to get yourself out of a pinch? Do you know how to read a map? While your kid is getting accustomed to the new reality of being out in the middle of nowhere on a new kind of bike (one with a motor), it’s inevitable that you, dear parent, will be the one in charge of the bike’s operation. Rest assured, there will be wipeouts that flood the carburetor and rocks that embed themselves in the drive chain preventing the back wheel from spinning. It’s on you to know your stuff mechanically to be able to get yourself out of these oh-so-common messes when the nearest civilization is miles away.

Knowing that my boy was going to be starting and stopping his bike a lot, I opted to buy a brand-new 2014 Honda CRF125FE with an electric start, so he wouldn’t get tired from constantly kick starting.  Dirt biking over sandy, rocky trails is exhausting enough. I purchased a dual sport model capable of riding in the dirt as well as on the street for myself, because I wanted the versatility of also using the bike for commuting. These on- and off-road capable bikes are available in displacements as large as 1,200, but I opted for a 2014 Honda CRF250L because it’s large enough to travel on the freeway and light enough that I can pick it up on my own. In the dirt, it isn’t a matter of “if” you’re going to dump it but “when” and “how.”

Before spending the money, consider: Does your child really, really want to do this?
This gets us out and away from screen time.
We've had two dirt bike adventures together so far, with many more to come.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: Emma Gilmour grew up in one of New Zealand’s smaller cities, Dunedin, where her mechanic father drove his Porsche “quite quickly. I just grew up with fast cars and didn’t know any differently,” said Gilmour, who inherited her dad’s need for speed.

The fastest female rally driver in the world, Gilmour added another first to her résumé today. She will be the first female to compete in Global Rallycross, joining Hyundai and Rhys Millen Racing for the 2014 season, which kicks off in May.

For the past week, Gilmour has been in Southern California, testing out the 600-horsepower Hyundai/RMR Veloster Turbo she’ll use to accelerate to more than 100 mph on the straights and drift around corners during the series. Global Rallycross will be Gilmour’s first race in America. Since 2002, she has competed in the New Zealand Rally Championship, placing second overall in 2010, 2011, and 2012 in an entirely male field. She has also raced in Europe and placed second in the International Asia Pacific Series in 2009.

“There aren’t that many females doing what we do in the rally world,” Gilmour said during a telephone interview Monday, her New Zealand accent loud and clear. “There’s less of us that want to do it to start with. There’s no reason we can’t do it, but fewer females seem to start in the sport.”

Gilmour started in the sport at age nineteen as a navigator for her cousin and older sister. In New Zealand, rally drivers are paired with navigators to help them negotiate blind turns since the races are run on closed public roads. She moved in to the driver’s seat at twenty-two and was quickly recognized as having a flair for the sport, which helped her realize she could race professionally, not just as a hobby.
Now age thirty-four, Gilmour has known she would be part of the Rhys Millen Racing team since last December.

“It was a really big secret to keep,” said Gilmour, who knew Millen because he is also from New Zealand. They met through the motorsport event run by Millen’s father in their home country, the Leadfoot Festival.

“In New Zealand we’re very lucky because lots of people do motorsports. It’s quite accessible to do even at the club level relatively cheaply,” said Gilmour, noting that New Zealand has spawned three Formula 1 racing drivers—as well as Millen, a Pikes Peak International Hill Climb champion, rallycross driver, and Formula D world champion.
Rhys Millen Racing wanted a woman for the two-driver team to reflect the Veloster’s relatively even buyership between men and women.

Gilmour said she was in the running for the Hyundai/RMR team with at least one other female rally racer; Hyundai and Rhys Millen Racing wanted a woman for the two-driver team to reflect the Veloster’s relatively even buyership between men and women, she said.

Gilmour’s most recent rally car was a modified Suzuki Swift Sport. She has also raced a Ford Fiesta, Mitsubishi Evo 3, Evo 6, and Subaru WRX, but the Veloster, she said, is the most powerful car she’s ever driven.

Gilmour describes her racing style as smooth, aggressive, and committed: smooth because she tries to keep the tires as balanced as possible, aggressive in that her reactions are quick and decisive, and committed in the sense of rally racing on her home turf.

“In New Zealand, we drive on closed public roads. We’re driving blind, so when our navigator tells us about the corner, whatever they say is what you do. You have to be fully committed going over the crest and doing 160 kilometers [100 miles] per hour.”

Gilmour’s first competitive sport was equestrian. She competed at the national level until “I got to the point where my ambition didn’t match my ability or my bravery, so I reluctantly gave it up,” said Gilmour, who missed competition and decided to apply her skills to stage rallying.
Some of the skills she learned riding horses are directly applicable to rally car racing, she said.

“You understand the balance of the car through the seat. There’s obviously coordination with the hands,” she said. “In horse riding, if you’re approaching with speed and you see the horse is striding wrong and it’s pretty ugly, you still have to go for it. It’s the same in rally driving. You come in a corner and you’ve locked the brakes and your speed is too high, but you’ve still got to give it a go.”
Gilmour will be giving it a go in Global Rallycross beginning May 17 in Barbados.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

title: 2015 Honda Fit
subTitle: 2015 Honda Fit: How big a deal is this little car? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: 2015 Honda Fit: How big a deal is this little car? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: 2015 Honda Fit: How big a deal is this little car? Here's what we think.
metaTitle: 2015 Honda Fit - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2015 Honda Fit: How big a deal is this little car? Here's what we think. Read our review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
2015 Honda Fit EX

Price: $16,315 (base model, including destination charge), $19,025 (EX, including destination charge)
Engine: Sixteen-valve 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 130 horsepower, 114 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Continuously variable transmission with Sport mode and paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 33 mpg city/41 mpg highway (base LX with CVT); 32 mpg city/38 mpg highway (EX with CVT)
My favorite standard feature: Expanded View driver’s mirror and multi-angle rearview camera
Option I can’t live without: Honda satellite-linked navigation system
Notable standard features on this model: Multi-angle rearview camera with dynamic guide lines, Honda LaneWatch lane departure warning, push-button start, power moonroof with tilt, intermittent rear wiper/washer, roofline spoiler, heated power side mirrors with integrated turn indicators, HondaLink telematics with Bluetooth streaming audio and Pandora compatibility, seven-inch information touchscreen, Bluetooth HandsFreeLink
Notable options: Honda satellite-linked navigation (on EX-L with Navigation), leather seating (on EX-L), six-speed manual transmission (on LX and EX, $800)
You might also be considering: Ford Fiesta, Hyundai Accent, Nissan Versa Note
Honda is one of several automakers who are stepping up their game year by year in the small-car stakes.

It’s a funny thing about cars in the subcompact category: you might think they are solely the choice of the young and unencumbered, or the person who can’t afford more of a car. Of course, there's always a strong cohort of buyers under thirty-five who like small cars or want to keep their purchase price down. But in addition, there is a growing population of genuine adults—empty nesters, the environmentally conscious, or just minimalists—who voluntarily choose a subcompact car and like it. Perhaps in response to this, Honda is one of several automakers who are stepping up their game year by year in the small-car stakes. So, if you are considering going (or staying) with a subcompact, how about this one?

It’s a good time to ask the question, because Honda has just revealed its all-new 2015 Fit. The Fit has been on the U.S. market since 2006. Honda skipped the 2014 model year to get this all-new, third-generation version out as a 2015, and it goes on sale April 14. I was one of the lucky ones to get behind the wheel just this week and take it for a long country drive. I will get to the point immediately and tell you that it exceeded my preconceived notion of how it would feel to drive, and how it would feel to try to fit people and things inside.

Sliding into the admittedly slimly padded seat, I actually found that it was comfortable, in a low-key way, and the Honda family feeling and look was reassuring. You know what I mean—that clean, crisp, shiny-happy look that appeals to so many Honda cultists. It’s there, even though Honda has added gewgaws to the Fit like "eco assist" lighting on the central instrument binnacle that turns green when you’re getting good gas mileage—such as when you take your foot off the gas entirely. I’d rather see hard numbers, thanks, which I watched on the touchscreen, but I’m sure some people will like it.
Pulling away from the curb, I felt immediately at ease, and not—as I have in some other very small cars—a bit vulnerable in traffic next to tall-boy SUVs and trucks.

This makes sense, because the new Honda Fit has an all-new engine, still a 1.5-liter four-cylinder, but now with 11 more horsepower at 130 hp and 7.5 percent more torque at 114 pound-feet. It also has a new continuously variable transmission. There are a lot of people who dislike CVTs, but most people ought to like this one, which is teamed on the EX and EX-L trim levels with a pair of paddle shifters mounted on the steering wheel. In accelerating from a stop, you do know you're not in the most powerful car on the market, but it almost sounds sporty, and getting up to cruising speed is not unpleasant. I didn't get to try the all-new six-speed manual transmission, available on entry-level LX and midrange EX models only, but you stick-shift people out there should give one a try before you make a decision. Automobile Magazine's reviewer, himself a Fit owner, called it "slick" and "satisfying." Choosing the manual also cuts the price of a Fit by $800, although the CVT-equipped models get about 3 mpg better fuel economy.

Fuel economy is an important part of the package for a car this size, and the Fit delivers, especially with the base LX equipped with the CVT: it achieves the Holy Grail of 41 mpg on the highway. You can also push a button to the left of the steering wheel, marked Econ, that will optimize powertrain operation for added fuel economy. I tried it, and it didn't cause any big dropoff in performance that I could detect.

How did it feel on the road? Picture yourself behind the wheel of this adorable, but undeniably small machine, heading out onto the pothole-ridden back roads of southeastern Michigan in early spring, and what would you expect? Pull over after a few miles and call the chiropractor? Actually, no. The ride was a little on the bumpy side on the worst stretches of pockmarked back road, but thanks to some judicious changes Honda made to both front and rear suspension to improve stability while reducing weight, it was kept to a minimum. At freeway speeds up to 80 mph, it felt smooth, stable, and competent.

Not totally trusting my own standards—possibly lowered by decades as a minivan driver—I checked with an older, wiser journalist, one whose store of technical knowledge is far, far greater than my own, and he called the ride “a bit flinty,” but he liked it, too.

What's really the news in the 2015 Fit, though, is what they've done to make the interior feel much bigger than a subcompact. Honda senior product planner Hiroaki Hamaya pulled out a vacation slide of his surfing outing, showing that he got a nine-foot longboard and two short boards into the back. That's thanks to the 60/40 split folding Magic Seat. Each side folds flat with an effortless flick of a switch, and there really is amazing space behind the front seats when they're folded: 52.7 cubic feet, compared with 38.3 cubic feet in the competing Nissan Versa Note. I opened the hatch and climbed in with the seats folded flat: Yes, I could lie down in the back without going diagonal. Keeping in mind that I'm 5'3", that's still impressive for a car this small. The front seats, too, fold all the way back, almost flat, in what the Honda people called Refresh mode "for relaxing." Not while you're driving, of course.

There are also 4.8 inches more rear legroom, even though Honda made the Fit 1.6 inches shorter in overall length with the new design. Testing that, I pushed the front passenger's seat all the way back and climbed in the second row behind it, and I had more than enough legroom to feel comfortable in the back seat. My co-driver, a solidly built 5'10" male, did not complain, either, when he tried it. My verdict is that this is a car that really would fit four adults, not in limousine style, but without making anyone feel terribly cramped. It's billed as a five-seater, and for kids or short hauls only, that could work. It also opens up possibilities for taking along your dog in a crate, making a massive Costco run, or even (shudder) helping people move, without that small-car feeling of limitation.

Even though the EX I drove had the sunroof, I didn't feel there was a compromise on headroom, which has been the case in several much pricier cars I've driven. You can see how much room Simone has in the photo at the end of this article.

New for 2015

Honda has increased the level of equipment at all trim levels on the 2015 Fit. The center storage console, when you fold up the armrest, is big enough to hold an iPad. There's a smartphone cubby to the left of the instrument panel. A USB port is found on EX and EX-L models. (On the entry-level LX model, according to LX owner Paul Carpenter, there's a USB port connected to the Aux input. "I removed the USB extension and simultaneously removed the Aux port, which is connected. Did not hurt anything; just pushed it back in. Now I put my left index finger over the Aux input when I remove the USB. Works fine." So your USB needs are met no matter which model you buy.) Anyone who drove an old-school subcompact (or is upgrading from one) will be happy to know that such items as cruise control, a tilting/telescoping steering wheel, cup holders, vanity mirrors, and power windows and doors are all standard even on the $16,315 base model. What's more, uplevel Fits now come with push-button start/stop, the app-based HondaLink platform, Siri Eyes Free integration, and SMS text messaging, with voice-recognition touchscreen navigation only on the top-of-the-line EX-L.

Instead of the previous base and Sport models, the 2015 Fit comes in LX, EX, EX-L, and EX-L with Navigation trim levels. Even on the base model, you get a standard multi-angle rearview camera, an expanded-view driver's mirror, cruise control, and a five-inch LCD screen. All models also have standard motion-adaptive electric power steering and vehicle stability assist with traction control. From EX on up, you get a standard sunroof, push-button start and stop, a seven-inch HondaLink touchscreen, and a LaneWatch expanded-view rearview camera. The EX-L adds leather seating and heated front seats and mirrors, and the EX-L with Navigation adds SiriusXM satellite radio and, obviously, navigation on the touchscreen system. Honda expects that 55 percent of buyers will go for the EX model and 35 percent for the entry-level LX, with only four percent choosing the top-end EX-L with Navigation.

Mystic Yellow, Perhaps?

The 2015 Fit overcomes one of my pet peeves about Japanese brands, that they have boring color choices. Eight colors are available, one more than in 2014. The black, silver, and red color choices carry over, but the other five are new, including pearlescent shades of Passion Berry, Mystic Yellow, and White Orchid, plus Modern Steel and Aegean Blue metallic shades. The black one I drove was attractive, but I really think small cars should wear bright, cheerful colors, don't you?

Honda is building the new Fit at a brand-new plant in Mexico, because North America is an important market for this car. A new small SUV is going to be built there, too, starting later this year.  They're targeting Fit sales of 70,000 plus. And I can see the reason for their optimism.

The Verdict:

A subcompact is not for everybody, but one that's this cute and capable is for a lot more people than you might think. If you want to spend $20,000 or less, get up to 41 mpg on the highway, and not feel like you're being penalized for it, the Fit is a strong contender. Even the base model deserves to be called a 2015, considering the amount of modern engineering it has on board. At the same time, this is still not a true family car, and you wouldn't want to drive three kids around in it all day long. But as for visibility, versatility, and looks? That's all there. And I will even go as far as to say I'd feel comfortable if any of the three kids themselves were to have this as a first car.

Peanut Gallery:

Simone Samano, Contributing Writer: In the past, while I appreciated the Fit’s brilliant capacity and gas mileage, I always felt the interior styling and features were lacking and the exterior was appealing but utilitarian. So I was pleasantly surprised by the cleaner, more upscale look and feel on the inside, with the standard upgrades like multi-angle rearview camera and Bluetooth in the 2015 version. The outside made me think of what would happen if a Fiesta hatchback and a Prius C married against their parents’ will, but I liked the sporty look, even if it wasn’t very Honda-like. And a big shout out for those new extended-width mirrors, plus extra kudos to Honda for keeping the windows ample, continuing the great visibility the Fit is known for.

The uplevel EX-L wooed me with its moonroof and large seven-inch touchscreen. I found it easy to use the steering wheel controls as well. Also neatly tucked on the steering wheel were new paddle shifters, a great help getting on the highway, although the plastic of the shifters felt a bit flimsy to the touch. To me this is really a city car, so when parallel parking, the tight turning radius came in handy, as did the “top view” of the multi-angle rearview camera. Sure, I felt some of the bumps and bounces in the potholed roads, but I would expect that in a car this size. The cabin was actually quieter, and roomier in the back, than I expected. In fact, I would say the whole car exceeded my expectations.

pageElements.text: If you read A Teenager's First Road Trip last week, you know that I'm a high school junior and I was just given the privilege of being put in charge of planning a cross-country road trip with my mom. (Also click back for Day 1, and Days 2/3.) We're on that trip now, and here's how it's going:

image.altText: on the road memphis to nashville

pageElements.text:
Day 4: Memphis to Nashville

My mom and I spent the morning exploring Memphis's Cooper-Young neighborhood. She loves to shop and will skip meals so that she doesn’t waste precious time. I convinced her to stop at Java Cabana and split a muffin. She agreed to the stop, but we got it to go so that we could press on.
We popped in and out of shops, and we both absolutely loved the House of Mews. It was closed, but dozens of cats were loose inside, with no human in sight.

image.altText: on the road memphis to nashville

pageElements.text: Our very best find was Memphis Drum Shop. I don’t even play the drums, but we managed to spend an hour checking out the goods. By the time we loaded up the bright red GMC Terrain, it was two o’clock. Since it is three hours to Nashville, we needed to seriously get moving.

Now that we have logged 650 miles, we are nearing the halfway point. Both front seats are eight-way power with lumbar, and the best part is that they are heated. It is shocking how exhausting just sitting can be, but these seats are literally saving my ass.

image.altText: on the road memphis to nashville

pageElements.text: On Saturday I am going to the Miley Cyrus concert in Michigan, so I have been listening to her a lot on our drive. The Monsoon speakers are awesome, but my mom is constantly turning it down. We have spent some time with it cranked up loud, and it sounds real good.

My midafternoon I was starved, and since we were in a hurry we stopped at a McDonald’s. My mom explained how when she is traveling alone she always uses their bathrooms rather than rest areas. She thinks they are safer. This McDonald’s was actually really nice, and the bathrooms were exceptionally clean. The food however was, well, you know, just as expected. We ate it in the car. How very American of us. I actually prefer sitting down and taking a break.

We noticed that Tennessee drivers are a touch more aggressive than their neighbors farther to the south. As we flew down the highway, a warning came on the screen that there was a camera in the area. We thought that was odd on the highway but appreciated the heads up and slowed down to the posted speed.

At one point we came to an area where the highway was under construction—no shocker. They had dug grooves into the road, like a rake in a Zen garden. We could still drive regular speeds, but the Terrain was slipping all over the road, like we were driving on ice. My mom was relieved when it was finally over.

We watched the gas gauge, and when it slipped below a quarter of a tank, we filled up. (Not like yesterday.) My mom shared stories of running out of gas over the years. Note to self: never let the level dip below a quarter of a tank. I do not want to be stranded on a highway or in a questionable neighborhood.

Our Airbnb host for the night asked us to meet her at her vintage shop in East Nashville, the Pony Show. Both my mom and I were psyched because we love vintage finds, and the pictures of her house were straight out of an Anthropologie catalog.
At one point we came to an area where the highway was under construction—no shocker. They had dug grooves into the road, like a rake in a Zen garden.

We arrived to Nashville right at rush hour, but luckily every time we made a turn we missed the heavy traffic. Winning. We pulled up to the Pony Show and it was exactly what we expected. From used cowboy boots to funky antler necklaces—we swooned over the merchandise. It was nearing six, so we drove the short distance to the Airbnb house and unloaded for the night. Again, we absolutely loved it. From the vintage sewing machines to the turntable and vintage albums,  we were sold. Every inch of the house was full of little knickknacks, and most definitely Anthropologie. Love was in the air.

image.altText: on the road memphis to nashville

pageElements.text: We quickly drove two minutes to a shopping district, checked out a few stores, and finally sat down to eat a meal at a Mexican restaurant called Rosepepper Cantina. Great food, great atmosphere, full of hipsters, and those are all good things. This may be my favorite vibe so far.
Back to our lovely home for the night. Perhaps I will look for colleges in Nashville.

pageElements.text: Of all the glamorous cars you'll see at an auto show, these are not two examples. The Ford Focus and the Chevrolet Cruze are the everyday compact cars you see around the streets and might not particularly notice. You're also fairly likely to know someone (or be someone) who drives one of these multimillion sellers. But this week is a moment in the sun for both: the updated and improved 2015 models are making their debuts at the New York International Auto Show. Let's give them the attention they deserve, since we'll be seeing these new models everywhere for years to come.

2015 Ford Focus

You're looking at a winner: The Ford Focus is the top-selling nameplate in the world. Twelve million have been sold since the initial launch in 1998, including almost 1.1 million in 2013. In China alone last year, sales topped 400,000, which was a 50 percent jump for that aspirational country.

The 2015 Focus five-door hatchback made its debut last month, in Geneva. At the New York show, we'll be seeing the four-door sedan version and the Focus Electric. The 2015 version of the hotter Focus ST comes out later in the year.

What's new for 2015?

For starters, you can now get the 1.0-liter three-cylinder EcoBoost engine, which is already in the Focus's little sibling the Fiesta. Pair that with the new six-speed manual transmission, and you'll be expecting some great fuel economy (not yet announced). The standard engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, which returns 37 mpg on the highway in the 2014 Focus.

An SE Sport package is new; it comes with a revised suspension, paddle shifters, and seventeen-inch gloss black aluminum wheels. The electronic nanny MyKey is standard on all 2015 Focus models, and a heated steering wheel is optional. And it should be; let's not hog that fabulous feature only to the luxury classes!

Technology moves forward for 2015, too. A rearview camera is standard on every trim level, whether with the basic 4.2-inch screen or the MyFord Touch eight-inch screen. Blind spot monitoring and lane keeping systems are optional.  Ford Sync AppLink has been upgraded, so you can download dozens of apps for your Android or iOS smartphone.

The Focus's new grille is a smaller copy of the one on the larger Fusion. Something about that bothers me: family resemblance is important, but even an attractive front end like this will get tiresome the 500,000th time I see one go by.

What does everybody see in this car? Don't make too much of the fact that the top-selling Focus color in the U.S. is the dull-sounding Sterling Gray. The Focus has a likable combination of fuel economy, modern technology, and just plain fun-to-drive personality. And, of course, people can afford to buy them. Prices for the 2015s aren't out yet, but the 2014 sedan started at $17,635, while the 2014 hatchback's starting price was $19,450 (prices include destination). The first buyers will get their hands on the 2015 Focus late this year.

2015 Chevrolet Cruze

Here's another ubiquitous compact that has achieved great popularity. The Cruze is the top-selling Chevrolet product worldwide, and more than 2.5 million have been sold since it came out only in mid-2010.

Chevrolet's marketing chief, Paul Edwards, would like you to know as well that it's the number-two seller among U.S. buyers under twenty-five. But the Cruze is not necessarily just a rite of passage for entry-level shoppers. Look at the connectivity features GM is putting onto this low-priced car, especially OnStar 4G LTE with an optional Wi-Fi hotspot feature so you'll be able to stay Internet connected just about everywhere in your universe. There are also new text message alerts and upgraded voice recognition features that work with Chevrolet's MyLink telematics,  and Siri Eyes Free for iPhone users.

There is no doubt that in-car connectivity is the future, and it's nothing short of awesome that Chevrolet makes its affordable sedan into a rolling hotspot on the leading edge of that future, so millions of people can enjoy it. What's more, you can hook up seven devices to the high-speed wireless. If there are three passengers in the car, and each has a smartphone, a laptop, or a tablet, seven isn't as crazy as it sounds. Okay, kids, get that homework edited and submitted before we get to soccer practice!

What's new for 2015?

The Cruze's new look is not a complete overhaul, just a refreshed appearance, but it does bring the small car closer to the look of larger siblings Malibu and Impala, notably the new front end with its LED daytime running lights and a split grille. GM also promises several new colors, without giving details yet.

You'll still be able to get the fuel-efficient Eco model and the diesel version, which in the 2014 version takes you more than 700 miles between fillups and offers 46 mpg on the highway. Pricing has not yet been announced, although the 2014 model started at a reasonable $18,345, including destination. The 2015 Cruze will be on sale in the fall.

pageElements.text: The unseasonable arrival of spring sleet and snow didn’t defeat the overnight assembly of the 50th Anniversary triple-yellow Mustang on the eighty-sixth floor of the Empire State Building during the New York Auto Show.  Ford had a deadline fifty years in the making. But first, as it had done back in the Sixties, it had to get the Mustang to fit into the elevator.
Preparation for the feat began six weeks ago. Turns out, it’s no small thing to hoist a car 1,000 feet in the air.

image.altText: ford mustang on top of nyc

pageElements.text: The first car to be displayed atop the Empire State Building was in October 1965, a quintessential moment in the early years of the Mustang brand. It followed the 1964 introduction of the first Ford Mustang at the 1964 World’s Fair. Preparation for the feat began six weeks ago. Turns out, it’s no small thing to hoist a car 1,000 feet in the air. Ford stuck with a tried and true formula, removing parts piece by piece in the tradition of age-old craftsmen. The Detroit automaker collaborated with the longtime Michigan-based supplier DST, which helped stage the first Empire State Building suspended stunt. The Mustang was cut into surgically rendered pieces and then reformed for display in a narrow six-hour window while the observation deck was closed to the public.

Mustang has become the iconic symbol for all things Ford embraces about its heritage. Bill Ford, Jr., the brand’s scion and Ford executive chairman, was on hand to take a seat behind the wheel. He remarked that his first car was a 1975 electric green Mustang.

To commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the pony car, Ford has produced a Mustang 50 Year Limited Edition and made an appropriate number, 1,964 vehicles. It will go on sale this fall. The special car will be made in Kona Blue and Wimbledon White—in homage to the very first Mustang—and relies on the classic 5.0-liter V-8 that produces 420 horsepower and 390 pound-feet of torque. Brembo brakes and nineteen-inch alloy wheels are also included in the performance package. Two transmissions are available: a six-speed automatic and a souped-up six-speed manual. It’s essentially a GT.

image.altText: ford mustang on top of nyc

pageElements.text: Meanwhile, the suspended Mustang will be on display only through today, April 17, before it makes the long journey back down to earth. Check out the stunt in progress in the photo gallery below.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. pageElements.text: Auto-show reveals are always exciting, and the one last night for the 2015 Hyundai Sonata was no exception, as our video (below) shows. The all-new seventh-generation version of the mid-size sedan, built in Alabama, will be on sale this summer, and here's what you can expect.

This new body design is described as Fluidic Sculpture 2.0. We've got more patience with this kind of poetic lingo when it really shows on the car, as it does here. The looks are definitely more refined without becoming too aggressive: "the way an award-winning chef refines his recipe over the years," in the words of Chris Chapman, Hyundai Design North America's chief designer. The cleanliness of the new Sonata's design cannot be overstated. Or, put simply, it's "a more planted look," as Chapman described it.

At the official introduction this morning at the Jacob Javits Convention Center, president and CEO Dave Zuchowski called the new sedan "more taut, sophisticated...the next step in a substantial design evolution" and "a great leap forward in Hyundai's engineering capabilities." How do you like it?
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/rGuimyksRA8?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

What's new for 2015?

Active safety is upgraded for 2015 with a Lane Change Assist package. It determines the closing speed of any vehicle in the lane next to the Sonata and uses an audible alarm to let you know if the lane change is safe. Along with that go lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and blind spot detection, so you're covered at every angle.

A pair of four-cylinder engines have been revised for better drivability at low RPM: the 2.4-liter 185-horsepower four-cylinder in SE, Limited, and Sport models, and the 2.0-liter turbo, which makes 245 horsepower and is for the Sport 2.0T model. Both are mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. Hyundai explains the continued commitment to four-cylinders only is a way to optimize space and fuel efficiency.

Other tech to appreciate, coming down from the 2015 Genesis to the mid-size class, includes high beam assist, smart cruise control, a more touch-sensitive 8.0-inch navigation touchscreen, Siri Eyes free integration, and a smart trunk that opens if you get anywhere near the trunk with the key fob in hand and wait three seconds.
Good news about color: seven choices will be available. That orange, though, that you see in the video: it's exclusive to the turbo model.
A Blue Link in-vehicle app for Hyundai Assurance car care downloads onto the nav screen so, if you want to, you can schedule your maintenance and service right inside the car. Interesting!

People who ride along will appreciate a height-adjustable passenger's seat, a pair of heated and ventilated front seats, and heated rear seats, plus an optional heated steering wheel. Another inch of rear legroom is added this year, and Hyundai points out that it has so much space inside that the EPA actually classifies the Sonata as a "large car," unique among cars in the mid-size class. Put this together with the new 2015 Genesis, and Hyundai has an ambitious sedan lineup in place.

pageElements.text: As buzz accumulates about the next-generation Mazda Miata, the Japanese automaker is reminding us that in order to understand the future, we should also honor the past. And what better way to celebrate a quarter-century of blissful top-down motoring than with a 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition? Mazda debuted this special-edition Miata at the 2014 New York auto show as a preview of the limited-run roadster set to go on sale later this spring.

"The original concept behind the MX-5 was so simple: to offer the pure joy of a lightweight sports car that moves precisely as the driver intends," said Mazda chairman Takashi Yamanouchi in a statement. Twenty-five years later, with nearly a million Miata vehicles sold worldwide, the 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition keeps the same formula of light weight, balance, and handling prowess that we’ve known and loved since we named the Miata our first Automobile of the Year in 1990. Today, the Miata still carries the torch for the original car we called, “a paragon of sports-car virtue. It does everything right, and it’s enormous fun.”

Under the hood is the Miata’s third-generation, 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine delivering up to 167 hp to the rear wheels.  Mazda says that for every 25th Anniversary Edition Miata, its engineers hand-selected the highest-quality pistons, connecting rods, and flywheels for exceptional lightness and low inertia. Mazda doesn't claim that hand selection leads to more horsepower, but does say those engines will rev, “even more freely.” Vehicles equipped with the six-speed manual gearbox also get standard Bilstein dampers.

All 100 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition vehicles will come in Soul Red Metallic paint with contrasting black for the A-pillars, mirrors, windshield surround, and power-retractable hardtop. Other black trim pieces include the headlamp bezels and 17-inch aluminum-alloy wheels, which are shod in Bridgestone Potenza RE05A tires. Unique 25th Anniversary badging on the front driver’s side fender distinguishes each vehicle with its own serial number.

Almond leather seats and door trim come standard on the special-edition Miata, which is finished with aluminum pedals and satin chrome details on the door handles and gauge cluster rings. Black seatback and Piano Black steering wheel spokes match the leather steering wheel, shift lever boot, armrests, and parking brake handle, which echo the exterior’s theme with contrasting red stitching.

On sale later this spring in a limited run of 100 vehicles, the 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition should be a wonderful collector’s car for any Miata enthusiast, as it also represents the final iteration of the third-generation “NC” Miata. Mazda’s fourth-generation Miata will presumably go on sale as a 2016 model with a full redesign that includes a new lightweight Skyactiv chassis. More details on the next-gen car will be revealed today in New York.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: It’s small. It’s wide. Or, as Jeep would have it, it’s “small-wide.” That’s the name for the build of this 2015 Renegade, Jeep’s entry into the small SUV segment. It’s also rugged yet adorable, especially with the new removable open-air roof panels known as My Sky. Driving the point of it home, the new Renegade made its debut at the New York Auto Show perched on the way down a steep incline.

Advantages to the new architecture: best-in-class off-roading and world-class on-road driving dynamics, says Jeep, which introduced the new model at the New York Auto Show today. It builds on the Wrangler’s form and the Cherokee’s 4x4 technology but has a charm all its own.

“The Renegade is the essential element for the next urban adventure. It can go from rigorous off-roading to social climbing in the city,” according to Jeep Brand president and CEO Mike Manley, but what you’d really want the Renegade to do is go exploring. For that, there are two versions: the Latitude (the red model shown here) and the Trailhawk. The Renegades include not just full-time four-wheel drive but a standard Active Drive Low 4x4 system with a 20:1 crawl ratio, which engages instantly in case you need that kind of traction. Or how about the five inspiring modes in the Jeep’s Selec-Terrain system: Auto, Snow, Sand, Mud, and Rock, that last one exclusively available on the Trailhawk model. In the Trailhawk with its Trail Rated 4x4 capability, you can ford up to nineteen inches of water! Will you? Well, you could if you wanted.

Designed in the United States but to be built in Italy, the new Renegade is intended for sale worldwide. Already this year, Jeep is proclaiming sales up 44 percent, with some 85,000 of its vehicles sold worldwide so far, on the way to a target of a million. The new Renegade's 30 mpg on the highway should aid popularity; the Renegade comes with a choice of a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine with a nine-speed automatic transmission (a first in this segment) or a 1.4-liter MultiAir Turbo engine with a six-speed manual transmission.

Jeep buyers are looking for a rough-and-ready interior, and they’ll get one in the 2015 Renegade. “Tek-Tonic” is the descriptor of the style. Several off-road-ready features (like grab handles) are borrowed from the Jeep Wrangler. The flexible interior package includes a removable, reversible, and height-adjustable cargo floor panel.
Protective clamp fasteners and the X shapes on the taillamps will make you think of camping equipment or extreme sports, Jeep hopes.

Maybe our favorite part of this new Jeep is its My Sky roof system, either with a power tilt and slide feature or manually removable, that lets you take off the fiberglass roof panels and store them in the rear cargo area.

It may look old school, but Uconnect touchscreen, emergency assistance, Bluetooth connectivity, HD radio, and an optional seven-inch instrument display are all on board.  Plus the active safety features that are becoming more common across the automotive world: forward collision warning, lane departure warning, blind spot monitoring, a rearview camera with dynamic grid lines, and rear cross-path detection are all available.
The 2015 Jeep Renegade goes on sale late this year, with pricing to be announced closer to launch.

pageElements.text: Here’s an all-new performance-luxury sedan from Acura, which made its debut at the New York Auto Show after being displayed in prototype form at the Detroit Auto Show in January. It can be hard to keep up with the Acura lineup, since all its products have similar alphabet names. Suffice it to say that this one  replaces the TL sedan and TSX sport wagon. It joins a lineup that includes the five-passenger RDX and seven-passenger MDX SUVs and the ILX and RLX sedans

It’s worthwhile getting to know the initials, because this sedan offers some major upgrades from the previous models. As Acura senior vice-president Mike Accavitti proclaimed, “The 2015 Acura TLX is the next generation, a true world-class athlete built and bred to deliver performance.”

Among the news: Two new transmissions to go with two familiar Acura engine choices. With the 2.4-liter four-cylinder, you get a dual-clutch eight-speed transmission, and with the 3.5-liter V-6, you get a nine-speed automatic that operates using a push-button gear selector instead of a gearlever for “a premium futuristic appearance.”
The new TLX is projected to get highway fuel economy as high as 35 mpg. An Acura Super-Handling All-Wheel Drive version is also available, which garners 31 mpg on the highway.

Physically, the 2015 TLX is nearly four inches shorter than the outgoing TL, and it has cut weight (at least 145 pounds) thanks to diligent use of lightweight materials. The interior gets soft-touch materials on the instrument panel, optional Milano leather seating and trim surfaces, and alloy and wood-grain accents. The exterior gets the Jewel Eye LED headlights that distinguish the Acura marque these days.  As an option, you can get a 455-watt, ten-speaker premium audio system that has been created by multi-Grammy-winning music producer Elliot Scheiner specifically for the TLX.

Technologically, there’s a full slate of active safety technology, including collision mitigation braking, forward collision warning, lane departure and lane keeping, adaptive cruise control, and blind spot monitoring.

The new TLX goes on sale later this year, with pricing to be announced closer to the launch date. As a comparison, the outgoing 2014 TSX starts at $31,530, and the TL at $36,925 (including destination charges).
“We think it’s ready for the bright lights of Broadway and a getaway to upstate New York,” noted Matt Hargett, chief engineer and vice-president of Acura R & D.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: The Ford Mustang has many fine qualities, not least of which is its sparkling color palette. So it's logical that Ford would offer nail polish in shades to match. Right?

It's for that reason that I was able to choose "The Sky’s My Limit" and get my nails painted right in the middle of the New York Auto Show at the Jacob Javits Center on Manhattan's West Side this week.

The shimmery aqua I chose is part of a limited-edition issue of nail lacquer by the well-known firm OPI that you'll actually be able to buy soon. The six-hue collection is being launched in July in collaboration with the fiftieth anniversary of the Ford Mustang. The other Mustang-inspired hues in the limited edition collection are Race Red (pays tribute to Mustang’s signature color), 50 Years of Style (a partygoing golden pearl), Queen of the Road (jet black, inspired by the pony car's black interior), Girls Love Ponies (which, despite the name, is a grownup shade of pink), and Angel with a Leadfoot (a statement-making white).

“Nail color, just like the car she drives, is the ultimate expression of a woman’s personality,” you won't be surprised to hear Suzi Weiss-Fischmann, OPI co-founder, say. “Automobiles are synonymous with style, and there is a special kind of love affair between a woman and her car.”

I agree. I love my cars and my nails! So, as I was having them polished at the Ford booth, I asked one of Ford’s PR team members if there was any chance of more cosmetics collaborations in the future.
“I’m working on lipstick,” she smiled.
(FYI: The ladies weren’t the only peeps getting their nails done. A few of the trendier guys came in to get one nail painted black.)
