contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Do you know what to do if one of your tires blows out while you are driving? Well, if your car has something like Bridgestone’s brand-new DriveGuards on, you just keep on driving. That is because they are run-flat tires. You can actually drive for up to fifty miles at 50 mph after a puncture or even complete loss of air. No more dangerous side-of-the-road replacing necessary.

In the past, run-flat tires were limited to vehicles that were equipped with them at the factory. Not anymore: DriveGuard is a new family of all-season run-flat tires, the first you can buy aftermarket. With them, Bridgestone is aiming for the sweet spot as replacement tires on today's bestselling coupes, sedans, and wagons that came from the factory with standard tires. The one caveat is that the vehicle must be equipped with a tire pressure monitoring system.
My mind flashed back to a recent scare with my octogenarian parents, who experienced a blowout in a remote area and were stranded until a kind motorist stopped.

Bridgestone recently invited me to drive cars at a track to compare the DriveGuard with conventional tires. They released all of the air in the front left tire right in front of me and then told me to take a lap and to make sure I hit 50 mph. Then I was asked to make lane changes and experiment with hard braking. I dutifully did all three tasks. There was absolutely no pulling, and other than a slight clunking the car handled normally. My mind flashed back to a recent scare with my octogenarian parents, who experienced a blowout in a remote area of the upper peninsula of Michigan. Luckily they did not lose control of their vehicle, but they were stranded until a kind motorist stopped and helped them out. Perhaps DriveGuards are the perfect Christmas gift.

Run-flats have a reputation for delivering a stiff ride thanks to their reinforced sidewalls. But Bridgestone has worked some molecular magic on the DriveGuard tires. They have a lighter-weight construction while still maintaining the strength to support the vehicle weight with zero pressure.

The tire also has cooling fins built into the exterior of the sidewalls. Heat is Kryptonite to tires, and when the tire has less than the optimal amount of air the temperature of the rubber begins to rise. Eventually the tire starts to break apart.

I tested the DriveGuards side by side with conventional tires, including Bridgestone’s best-selling Turanza Serenity Plus. I could not tell the difference in ride even on skidpads with very tight cornering.

Michigan would prove a worthy adversary for any tire right now. Our roads are chewing up tires at an alarming rate. Bridgestone will replace your tire in the first year or 12,000 miles if it can’t be repaired. There is also a tread-wear warranty of up to 60,000 miles. I recently had to replace a factory-installed Yokohama tire on my less-than-one-year-old car and did not have that coverage. You can also take advantage of the Buy & Try program: drive on them for thirty days, and if you aren’t satisfied, you can return them. But in order to switch to a DriveGuard, you need to switch out all four tires.
These are all-season tires, so if you want a winter tire as well, you will need to switch to conventional tires when the snow starts to blow.

At the time of my visit the pricing was not set, but Bridgestone did say the run-flats will cost about as much as the all-season Turanza Serenity Plus line. So a safe estimate is between $400 and $800 a set, depending on size. That's not bad for a tire that is able to let you keep driving until you can safely drive it to a repair shop. I once had a flat while on my way to a job interview. It would have been nice to be able to go to the interview and deal with my tire trauma afterward.

When it gets right down to making the decision to switch to run-flats, consider just how important your tires are to safety. Consumers often forget how important the rubber is when it comes to automotive safety. Airbags, traction control, blind spot alerts, and other accident prevention technologies are very important. But also remember that you are literally sitting on arguably the most important safety feature in your car: the tires. The contact patch—the part of the tire that actually touches the road—is only about the size of your hand. So next time you are considering a tire and are comparing prices, you may also want to add into the equation if the added safety of run-flats might be worth a few more Benjamins.

pageElements.text: I love white cars. Don't you? But I don't love the way you have to wash them every Saturday, or they look all dusty and polluted.

I love my dark-blue car, too. But I inevitably curse the people who drive past my car on my street and splash mud onto the side. It, too, only looks lovely for about an hour after it goes through the car wash.
So I am as excited as you surely are to see what Nissan in Europe is up to. This.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/UwoGsCAKsxU" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Can it be true? Nissan's Swiss technology center is experimenting with this water- and oil-resistant paint known as Ultra-Ever Dry. As the video shows, it seems to let dirt and mud roll right off the shiny surface of the car. The product is made by a company called UltraTech International, so this is (apparently) no April Fool's Joke.

The company describes the product as "super-hydrophobic" and says it adheres to any surface, creating an air barrier. It's so interesting that the National Geographic TV channel is using it in a challenge video. UltraTech points out that it's not available to the general consumer and that it is not to be applied to windshields.
Nissan says the coating "has responded well" to rain, spray, frost, sleet, and standing water. That about sums it up; I'm sold. Nissan says it's considering the aftermarket possibilities. Please do!

subTitle: Tips to help you celebrate Car Care Month, starting with these essentials up front.

pageElements.text: April is National Car Care Month, and to celebrate, Sears Auto called in world-famous "dirty windshield" artist Scott Wade to call attention to the glass in the front of your car. See it in Jean's related story, My Name Is Mud.
Wade's Dirty Car Art website is brilliant, and so is the work he created featuring Jean, but it's all to prove a point: you need to focus on the health of your wipers.

After a long winter, or just a lot of time since you last replaced wiper blades, you're driving at a disadvantage. Sears Auto's chain of 700 service facilities changes more than its share of them. Yet the company says more than 46 million cars on the road today have worn wiper blades. And, shameful fact, three-quarters of us only break down and change the blades when they become an actual hazard.
Don't be that way.
Here are five things you should do, and the reasons they make sense:

1. Replace your blades every six months.

Why? Because the blades need to be fresh to make firm contact with the windshield surface. Otherwise, they might streak, smear, or skip right when you need them most.

2. Have a good look at the windshield wiper assembly on a regular basis.

Why? There's a lot that can go wrong: for instance, detachment of the frame arms at joints or connection points, or even a broken wiper frame. Metal corrosion, particulalry at the joints. Visible cracks or tears in the rubber.

3. Is your rubber flexible? Find out.

Why? The squeegee part of the wiper needs to be flexible to conform to the windshield's shape. When it wears out, the edges can round off, the rubber loses that flexibility, and you can see streaks.

4. Are your blades loose? Find out.

Why? If it's not securely installed on the wiper arm, or secure in the frame, it is obviously not going to do the optimal job for you.

5. Take good care of your wipers in the first place.

Why? Preventive care is going to make those pricey blades last a little longer, after all. Wipe the rubber surfaces with a damp paper towel to keep dirt and oil from accumulating; keep your windshield clean (Sears recommends you wash the windshield every time you fill up the tank); and the big one for us Northerners, don't make your wipers do the ice scraping on frosty mornings. Use an ice scraper and the defroster for that.

pageElements.text: Have you ever considered the cost of insuring your car as a percentage of your annual income? NerdWallet has. As its name suggests, NerdWallet.com loves to crunch numbers in the service of the average consumer.

That's why the site chose the Ford F-150, the top-selling vehicle in America, as its point of reference. Its price is average ($24,735 for the base 2014 model); its average cost to insure is pretty average (a little over $1,000 per year). And the average F-150 owner pays 2.31 percent of his or her household income for the insurance policy.
But there's more. How do America’s cities rank when it comes to auto insurance costs? Check out NerdWallet's entire survey.

To figure it out, NerdWallet used four consumer types as examples: a man and a woman, each age twenty-seven and single, and another man and woman, each age forty and married.  Just as a typical consumer would do, NerdWallet averaged the two lowest rate quotes for basic insurance coverage. By calculating the cost of insurance according to a city’s median income, the index arrives at an affordability percentage.

And, surprisingly, California has the other states beat when it comes to affordability. Six of the ten most affordable cities to own an F-150 are in the Golden State, with Fremont toping the list at 0.75%, translating to a $754.38 yearly portion of their $100,574 median income. In fact the top thirty most affordable cities all fall at a desirable 1.5 percent of median income or below. California's high median income and relatively low insurance rates are the reason, says NerdWallet.

On the opposite end of the spectrum is Detroit, the most expensive place to insure an F-150 (or any other vehicle). Detroiters would pay 17.8 percent, or $4,199.43 a year, of their median income of $23,000 to insure the F-150. That’s a situation Detroit’s new major Mike Duggan is hoping to rectify by creating a city run auto insurance called D-Insurance. (http://www.jeanknowscars.com/you-auto-know/car-maintenance/d-insurance-for-detroit/)
Another challenging city is Cleveland, eighteenth on the list with a median income of $24,257 and an annual cost of about $750, or approximately 3 percent of income, to insure the ubiquitous truck.
The F-150 Index is a helpful resource about what to expect geographically, but to compare quotes for your personal car or truck NerdWallet has a tool to evaluate several companies at once.
Of course, don’t discount the value of a good local insurance agent to help you find the best insurance fit.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Ford of the Americas president Mark Fields needs to visit his mom more often. What with the daily pressures of saving Ford and all, he could use a bit more of his very down-to-earth mother's brand of support. Elinor Fields lives not far from the old family home in Paramus, New Jersey. She is the mother behind a son who has navigated his way through an economics degree at Rutgers, an MBA at Harvard, and what has been a stunning career at Ford. Fields headed Mazda in Japan at age thirty-eight, the youngest person to ever run a Japanese car company. He went on to lead the Premier Automotive Group, now dismantled, and he sits at the right hand of Alan Mulally, trying to move his Way Forward program, well, forward.

Related story:

Mark Fields Finds His Way Forward May 5, 2014

Today, though, Mark is seated at his mom's left hand, home for a rare lunch while the PR team readies the Flex press fleet for an event in New York. "He always followed his brothers. At A&S department store, Mark worked in Men's Pants, Lee was in Linens, Howard wired the Music Department," says Mrs. Fields, an elegant woman whose flawless skin and thick mane of dark hair make her look fifteen years younger than her actual age. "All three went to Rutgers. They were in the same fraternity. They had the same part-time job in college. All of them worked at IBM."

She hasn't seen her boy in a while, and she's laid out a spread that covers the dining room table. "He told me, 'Ma, I'm bringing someone for lunch, but she's diabetic, so just make tea,' " she laughs. "I said to him, 'What are you talking about?' "
There is a plate of roast beef and seven salads: tuna salad, egg salad, tomato salad, and so on. "I know," she shrugs at her three guests. "But how do I make less after all these years?"
She leans in toward him. A relative is holding a career day at school. "I told her you were very busy, but . . . " and pats his arm.
"Yes, Ma," he says.

"Mark was going to be my girl," she confides. "After two boys, this [she grabs his arm] was supposed to be my girl. But he was a hard worker. He wanted to make money when he was young. He was a caddy, and we found out he was carrying two bags at a time. We couldn't stop him."
She brings out his old tax returns. In 1977 he worked at Feeney's Sirloin Pit of Paramus and reported an adjusted gross income of $1334. The next year, he made $3014 at A&S.
"Do you know he still has his first car?"
"A 1983 Nissan 280ZX with T-tops," he interjects, getting younger the longer he sits here.

"I made him pay rent while he lived here. When he got his first apartment and went to buy furniture, I presented him with all of that rent money." She leans in toward him. So-and-so is selling her Saab, she tells him. "I told her I'd talk to you. Could you get her a deal on a Lincoln?"

"Yes, Ma," he says. She pats his arm and heads to the kitchen for desserts. That would be plural. Mrs. Fields made peanut butter cookies. "But I can't vouch for them," she apologizes. "I used Splenda instead of sugar. They don't look nice." She follows with a jam-filled angel food cake covered in whipped cream and fresh strawberries. "I even got diet raspberry jam," she tells her diabetic guest, who wants to take her home.
She pulls out a recent news clipping. "Did you see this?" She shows him a picture of himself over a fairly lengthy story. "Yes, Ma."

Ma smiles. "I kept it for you. Remember the time you upchucked? Praying to the porcelain god. I said to his dad, 'Jerry! He's sick! We've got to get him to the hospital!' Jerry said, 'Sick? He's not sick - he's drunk!' "
Mark is looking about fifteen years old now.

Mrs. Fields doesn't drive a stick, and her son doesn't buy her cars. "No, I pay. But I get the parents' deal. But I do like to test the next one first."
Has she driven the Ford Flex?
"The one that looks like a hearse?" she laughs. "But that's the look of cars now, isn't it?"
"It's too big for her," he says.
"You know, he is always working. The only time he isn't working is when he lays his head down and passes out. They have always given him something harder to do."

"I like the Zephyr. I was always happy when a car gave me good service. You know, remember when you were in California?" She talks with her hand resting on his arm. "They introduced the Mark. I like that name." Yes, this is Mark's mom. And she will have the last word.

"You know, he is always working. The only time he isn't working is when he lays his head down and passes out. He has never been able to reap the rewards of his work. They have always given him something harder to do. I worry; of course I worry. But if anything happens, it's going to happen to the whole country.

"The press has been nasty. My attitude has always been, if anyone can fix this, he can. Whatever he puts his mind to. You give them a good foundation. You repeat yourself and repeat yourself. It sinks in eventually. And then you never see them."

pageElements.text: The 2014 Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive goes on sale in the U.S. this summer, starting with California and nine other states, then rolling out to the rest of the country starting in 2015. It’s priced starting at an interesting $42,375 (including destination).

The arrival of the 2014 Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive is a reminder of how quickly the pace of technology moves. The first Toyota Prius dates back only to 1997—newborn babies driven home from the hospital in one are still in high school today—and now, a mere seventeen years later, you can buy a practical electric family car from Mercedes-Benz.

More than a million Mercedes-Benz B-Class cars have been sold around the world since it first came out in 2005, but the Electric Drive version has much to recommend it beyond the proven crossover-style body in which it rides: five-passenger seating capacity, a 0-to-60-mph time of 7.9 seconds and top speed of 100 mph, an eighty-five-mile range between charges, and, perhaps most enticing, a Tesla electric drive system inside.

Michael Jordan of Automobile Magazine tested the B-Class Electric Drive in California this week and found, despite its suburbanite looks, it prompted him “to produce a little antisocial behavior from what is meant to be a refined but innocuous people mover.” (Read his review here.)

With a price starting nearly $30,000 below that of the Tesla Model S (pictured), the 2014 Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive should draw interest based on its Tesla-sourced electric drive system alone. It also features a number of Mercedes’ vaunted safety technology items, including Collision Prevention Assist with adaptive Brake Assist, Attention Assist, and Parktronic advanced parking assistance. A 5.8-inch display screen is standard; a seven-inch display screen with Mercedes’ Comand infotainment system, and blind-spot and lane keeping assistance, are all optional.

Mercedes also set up the B-Class Electric Drive as a “digitally networked” vehicle, meaning you can check and configure its settings remotely using a computer or smartphone. For example, you can see how much charge you have in the lithium-ion battery, or plan out stops for recharging on the navigation system. Or, to be less environmental about it, you can set up heating or cooling so the B-Class is at your preferred temperature before you even climb in.

Add to this the fact that the rear seats fold and there's a back hatch, and the B-Class Electric Drive starts to look about as useful as a standard crossover.

Charge time is encouraging; with a 240-volt charger, you can get sixty miles’ worth of charge in two hours and a full eighty-five-mile charge in three. From a standard U.S. 120-volt electrical socket, charging time will be an overnight process.

How does it compare with BMW’s i3 (pictured), also just rolled out in the U.S.? The BMW, which seats four, is intended as more of an urban runabout, but other specs, including its price ($42,275, including destination), its range of seventy to 110 miles, and its 93-mph top speed,  put it in the same ballpark as the Mercedes. The i3 is available in a Range Extender version with a two-cylinder gasoline engine for an added $3,850, which effectively doubles driving range up to 211 miles.

In the realm of all-electric cars, prospective buyers have been stuck at the mini- or subcompact-car level with cars like Mitsubishi's i-MiEV or the Smart Fortwo or the more reasonably sized Nissan Leaf (pictured); or those fortunate to have the $70,000-plus to spend have sprung for the Tesla Model S. Now we're starting to see fully electric cars  you'd want to drive anyway, with the creature comforts and enjoyable attributes you would expect in any car. And they're practically affordable. That 1987 baby might aspire to own one of these in a few years, if her college loans let her.

pageElements.text: Tires are that expense we often balk at when it comes to making sure our car is up to snuff. For instance, many people feel that they can’t afford the price of four new tires.
The new tires go on the back because in dangerous conditions like wet weather you want to feel the car beginning to hydroplane as soon as possible, so you can correct.

When I visited the Michelin proving ground outside Greenville, South Carolina, recently to participate in the Michelin Safe Driving Experience, I had the opportunity to explore just why Michelin recommends that you always buy four new tires at a time (and get them rotated regularly to extend their life).
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/NP8wit28uHs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Of course, they want you to buy four. But what about those times when you feel you can only afford two tires? The least you can do is install them correctly.

There is a common myth that if you only have two new tires they should go on the front. Technical marketing manager Sarah Robinson explained that the new tires go on the back because in dangerous conditions like wet weather you want to feel the car beginning to hydroplane as soon as possible, so you can make a correction. If the new tires are on the front, you don’t feel the instability in the car until it’s too late.

So it was off to a part of the 3,500-acre facility to test this theory, as you see in the video above. We would be driving Toyota Camrys around a giant circle track with sprinklers creating a deluge on the polished concrete. Engineer Michelle Phillips was my co-pilot as I took out a Camry with new tires on the rear and worn tires on the front. She had me circle the track at speed, getting the car up to about 55 mph, until I naturally felt the need to lift off. I could feel the car begin to lose grip but corrected in time to avoid a spin. The reverse was true in another Camry that had the worn tires on the back and the new tires in front. I took it around faster and faster, but when I felt the car getting loose, the back end was already coming around. It was pretty exhilarating to experience that kind of spin on a wide empty test track. In actual traffic, it would be horrifying.
Note to self: If you can only buy two new tires, they go on the back.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The first time I drove the Chevrolet Corvette Stingray was last fall at Gingerman Raceway in western Michigan, during the Automobile Magazine Automobile of the Year competition. Every staff member and many freelance contributors came to that event, and it was all I could do to get any seat time. The Corvette was obviously a track animal and very exciting to drive, but it really showed its mettle on the two-lanes all around the west side of the state. When the dust cleared, the Stingray had won the 2014 Automobile of the Year award.

Next, I went to California in February for two months to film the reality show Motor City Masters (premiering June 24 at 10 p.m. on TruTv). The day after I arrived, a Stingray appeared in my parking spot as a loan from Chevrolet to use as my daily transport the whole time. I was sorry to see it go when I came back home in the spring.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/IYyBu0fKFk0?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

As luck would have it, the white Stingray in this test arrived in our offices on April 8 to begin its stint as a Four Seasons test car, meaning it’s going to live at our offices for a year. It all comes full circle. My life is complete.

Chief competitors: Audi R8, Porsche 911, SRT Viper GTS

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

I am Gabrielle Taylor George, and I graduated in 2011 from Pioneer High School in Ann Arbor, Michigan, the city I was born and raised in. The words that describe me are DRIVE, determination, enterprise, initiative, eagerness, motivation, resolve, enthusiasm, hunger, commitment, sense of purpose. I have this crazy dream to become a great photographer and to have studios all over. I believe that we're put on this planet to enjoy life, that we have everything we would ever need to dream big, and that we can achieve the dream. I grasp the concept of first working for it, then deserving it. I believe it's up to you to take the wheel of the car that represents you and drive down that dark road—only seeing so much of what's ahead, not knowing but continuing anyway because there is no fear. Carry on and expect the best. When the worst comes around, keep driving.  And so far, I’ve only landed in jobs that support my dreams. I don’t want to stop for anybody.

pageElements.text: Most Embarrassing Moment Ever. 1981, Great Falls, Virginia. I was thirteen; four feet, eleven inches tall; considerably rotund; and remarkably unathletic. Great Falls—now an enclave of substantial wealth—was then a rural Virginia community, and some of us really did have to walk a mile in the sun or snow to get to our bus stop. One cold day, one of the Klett boys—cute high schoolers who lived down the road—stopped his white Ford Bronco and asked if I wanted a ride home. My heart a bit aflutter, I tried to get in, but the Bronco lacked a running board for the vertically challenged. Between my short legs, girth, and complete lack of flexibility, I couldn’t step up into the car. I had to be hauled into the Bronco like a beached whale…and I wanted to die, right then and there. I have hated Broncos and that lack of a running board ever since.

Thirty years later, very much because of that moment, my girth is significantly reduced, my flexibility notably improved. My height, however, remains unchanged, and my contentious relationship with the automobile thus continues. Most vehicles are designed with the “average male” in mind: five feet, nine inches and 172 pounds. Women? Secondary consideration. Under five feet tall and 100 pounds? Not under consideration at all, unless we’re talking child car seats.
Try functioning in a driver’s seat when you’re the size of a fifth grader.

images.caption: Sitting up close for comfort can put you too close to the dash--and the sunshade.
Good thing there are tilting and telescoping steering wheels, but that's not always enough.
Then there's the issue of getting the door closed once you're situated.
Cars are not necessarily one size fits all, that's for sure.

pageElements.text:
Yet, seats are the battleground. Try functioning in a driver’s seat when you’re the size of a fifth grader. Driving my mother’s Audi always reminds me of sitting in a wheelbarrow: I can’t see the hood, but I have a great view of the sky. Depressing the clutch in that car is a bit of a trick: full leg extension required, it becomes quite the quad workout. In other cars, it’s not the distance to the pedals, it’s the overall configuration of the vehicle. Once, in a loaner Accord, I could not for the life of me figure out where the speedometer was located. I got on the highway with great trepidation. What if I got pulled over?</br>
</br>
“Excuse me, ma’am. Do you know how fast you were going?”</br>
“No, officer. This car has no speedometer…”</br>
</br>
The speedometer, my incredulous salesman later informed me, was an LED display. The top of the steering wheel, directly level with my eyes, obviously blocked more than my view of the road.

I do not have these issues in my Odyssey—I can (barely) see the hood and reach the pedals, and the speedometer is in full view. However, the seat is so far forward that there is not a lot of clearance between my body and the vehicle parts. I live in fear of the airbag. My breasts have an intimate relationship with the steering wheel; only a couple of inches of distance maintain a more proper relationship between the wheel and my thighs. It is a tight fit. My apologies to the many average male valets who have jauntily jumped into the driver’s seat after me, only to emasculate themselves. Being average height seems to have its hazards, too.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: Resinno Design’s Grand Rossa just might be the Ferrari of pianos. Certainly that is the maker's intention. The 1957 Testa Rossa inspired the design of this one-of-a-kind Yamaha piano, currently on display in a Ferrari showroom in Tampa Bay, Florida. The piano legs are painted in actual Ferrari red Rosso Corsa factory paint. The front legs form semi-helixes in the likeness of the Testa Rossa’s sleek dimensions, and the arch has the contours of a Ferrari physique. The Testa Rossa’s interior is re-created in the bench’s hand-stitched pattern.

Justin Elliott is the co-founder of Resinno, a firm that makes fine pianos into high art. Not only a master craftsman but a possessor of that prized attribute of musicians that is perfect pitch, Elliott has tweaked pianos for such artists as Elton John, Chick Corea and Alicia Keys. With this latest work, the 27-year-old designer has found a way to merge his passion for Italian sports cars with his specialization in musical precision.  “I’ve always loved cars and concepts,” he says.” I decided to design the Testa Rossa according to the curves and accents of the car.”

To incorporate the Ferrari spirit into the piano, he studied the engineering of the car’s exhaust notes and compared the process to the craft of making instruments. “The grand masters who tuned engines would tune it by ear, and you can do the same thing with wood.”

He used Neodymium magnets instead of fasteners to achieve fullness in sound. The red surfaces are especially slick, due to ten coats of paint, which are hand rubbed and buffed. “I use the exact same technique as an instrument maker. It’s hand rubbed, all wood, nothing’s metal, which accounts for the tonality and richness.”

Resinno Design can recreate the design on different kinds of pianos and plans to produce a limited edition run of ten Testa Rossa pianos. Each piano takes about three months to complete by the team of seven that work for the company in Clearwater, Florida. The design alone is $55,000. Add that to the cost of the piano at $97,000, and the total comes to $152,000.

pageElements.text: The 2013 ILX sedan aims to offer lots of luxury in a small package. Although not much bigger than the Honda Civic, the ILX holds up better on bumpy roads. The ILX’s smooth plastic interior isn’t as highbrow as some competitors', but it certainly doesn’t grate the eyes. Keyless entry and ignition, push-button start, and a power moonroof come standard, but the real draw is the standard Pandora Internet radio interface. Acura’s first offering to the entry-level luxury market comes with three powertrain options: a five-speed automatic, a more exciting six-speed manual transmission, and a 111-horsepower hybrid. The hybrid makes up for its lack of punch with an impressive 39 mpg in the city, which might be enough to make you embrace the gridlock on your morning commute. Even the base ILX is more fuel-efficient than the rest of Acura’s fleet. The ILX’s styling may not turn heads, and for the money (around $30,000), you may as well check out the peppier Acura TSX, but the ILX offers a touch of sophistication without the sticker shock usually associated with a luxury brand.

title: 2013 Acura TL
subTitle: A redesigned TL is less distinctive, less controversial

promoTeaser: 2013 Acura TL
metaTitle: 2013 Acura TL Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars

pageElements.text: The 2013 TL has no changes from the 2012 model, perhaps because 2012 was the TL’s best year in recent memory. The redesigned front end is much more appealing, with changes to the grille and the front and rear bumpers. Previous TLs sported a love-it-or-hate-it beak-like snout; the new incarnation is much more refined. The real changes are on the outside, but the TL does now offer optional creamy Milano leather seats. The TL allows drivers to choose between two engines: 280-horsepower V-6 with a six-speed automatic transmission or a 305-horsepower engine with a six-speed manual transmission. If you know your way around a clutch, the manual is refreshingly smooth. The smaller engine is an improvement over previous five-cylinder models, but the 300-horsepower manual has more pickup and handles tight turns better than the automatic. The TL’s fuel economy is respectable at 17 to 20 mpg city and 25 to 29 mpg highway. Like the RL, the TL has a dated navigation system and cluttered climate and audio controls. Despite minor deficiencies, the redesign gracefully handled most of the TL’s problems, leaving behind a car that both looks and feels more like luxury.

metaDescription: Smart has introduced a way for owners to personalize the body panels of their cars with body wrap kits. Read all about it and see images on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Smart has had trouble gaining traction in the U.S. market, despite its undeniable practicality as a city car. Smart was introduced to the U.S. in 2008 and enjoyed a year of strong sales with distributor Penske. The brand’s second year,  sales fell by 41 percent, however, and third-year numbers were 66 percent below the previous year. Daimler took over distribution and marketing for the brand in 2011 and has since seen ten consecutive months of “year-over-year sales increases,” according to the automaker. A little over a year ago, Smart launched its Uncar ad campaign, and the brand is working that edginess in quest of a growing customer base.

The microcar has an impressive commitment to personalization, offering dozens of colorful wrap kits to make your car stand out from the crowd. Available for browsing on the Smart USA website are choices from houndstooth to camo to plaid, not to mention a few designs reminiscent of MS Paint scribblings. Buying a stock wrap kit for your car might feel a little like buying art from Ikea, but Smart can also create a body wrap from your original design.  If permanent car modifications aren’t your style, you can make temporary attitude adjustments to your smart by switching the interchangeable body panels, allowing you to change your car’s exterior color on a whim.

images.caption: Go ahead, get ideas for design and then try them out on your Smart Fortwo.
Take two: they're small.

pageElements.text: A full set of panels – don’t worry, they’re 100 percent recyclable – will run you $900 to $1,400, depending on the color and where you buy them. Smart owners can save money (and let’s face it, if you’re buying a $13,000 car you’re not rolling in it) by arranging panel swaps over online forums like SmartCarofAmerica.com, Smart451.com, and Smartmadnessforum.com. Although dealers can switch out panels for you, websites also offer instructions for the do-it-yourself types.

It remains to be seen whether the potential for personalization will be enough to give Smart a new spring in its step, but when we called a Smart dealership to check prices, they didn’t even realize they sold the panels and said no one had ever asked for them.

pageElements.text: The German automaker said it intends to roll out cabin features in the near future that make a production car a "wellness oasis and fitness studio in one," but it hasn't yet said which Mercedes-Benz car is likely to get the health-oriented features.

"What could be better than a personal coach with a tailor-made training program to enhance your fitness and general well-being, on hand to support you at any time of the day or night," the company said in a statement.

The "healthcare-on-the-go" features - what Mercedes-Benz calls "Active Comfort" - are likely to come from its TopFitTruck research vehicle. They include a massage seat, a perfume atomizer and a cushion that fits over the steering wheel and "supports power napping" while the vehicle is in park. The audio system can select songs to help wake you up or calm you down.

The driver can do exercises that are borrowed from Pilates. Expander bands attached to lugs in the roof and floor of the concept truck allow the driver to do bicep curls and leg stretches in between road trips.

The exercise-oriented features don't just help the driver to stay in shape. Surprisingly, Mercedes-Benz said its research among long-distance truckers found that tired, distracted, and out-of-shape drivers contribute to a vehicle's lousy fuel economy.

This is the latest in a growing automotive trend that promotes rolling healthcare. Ford is developing a similar system by using Sync, healthcare apps and other technology to help drivers with everything from sensible food choices at the drive-through window to monitoring insulin needs in diabetic drivers.

Look for copycat ideas from other automakers in the future - even though we expect some pushback from drivers who think some of this stuff sounds too much like an interfering Big Sister. Or that annoying little Wii Fit nag.

pageElements.text: To those who call for the Volvo XC90 to freshen up: you’re right! Once the bestselling SUV from Europe, the XC90 has fallen way behind the curve, and the piddling updates for 2013 will hardly mitigate this laxity. If an important Volvo nameplate has suffered as the result of changes in Volvo’s corporate status, it’s the XC90. It’s the story of how a good-looking face can become merely familiar. The XC90 originated the trim, urbane look in the full-size crossover segment, but nothing has been done with that in years. And problems accelerated, so to speak, when the excellent V-8 departed the engine bay. Now left with the 236 horsepower 3.2-liter six-cylinder and six-speed automatic transmission as the only powertrain, the XC90 is dated and finds itself at a significant disadvantage to competitors; meager power output combines with mediocre fuel economy. For 2013, there are a few new items: for example, a leather strap on the tailgate, red wood trim in the interior, and white lighting for the instrumentation. The list of safety features looked good a few years ago, but today the XC90 even lags behind other Volvos in this aspect. The most important new feature it can receive is a refresh button.

pageElements.text: Toyota is known for building cars for busy minds, not flaming hearts. With that in mind, consider the Highlander the very quintessence of the brand. Bringing all the style and comfort of a sensible shoe, the Highlander is perfect for people who don’t like to think too much about their vehicles at any point, whether it’s before, during, or after acquiring them. The Highlander is larger than Toyota’s RAV4 and Venza crossovers, yet it remains carlike next to the similarly sized and priced 4Runner. It features a second-row seat that can be equipped either with captain’s chairs or a bench, plus a standard third-row seat for a maximum capacity of seven souls. With base, SE, and Limited trim levels and a new Highlander Plus package available for the base model, the Highlander can be equipped either as a bare-bones kid shuttle or the next best thing to a Lexus. The Highlander breaks little new ground this year in technology, either inside the vehicle or under the skin, with the exception being the Highlander hybrid, which is offered in addition to the four-cylinder (front-wheel drive only) and V-6 models. But that’s okay, since the Highlander is pretty swell as is. And as we said earlier, for most Highlander customers, that’s good enough.

pageElements.text: As the saying goes, “If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again.” But what happens if at first you do succeed? Do the same thing again and again and don’t change much. Toyota certainly struck gold with its 50-mpg Prius hybrid, so last year, it took the Prius’s winning formula, added a model with a little more cargo space (and, according to some, better-looking styling), and called it the Prius v. Shortly thereafter, Toyota created the Prius Plug-in, which uses the same wedgy body of the workaday Prius but gets super-potent batteries that can be recharged in three hours from a standard power outlet, thus helping it travel up to fifteen miles at speeds up to 62 miles per hour on electricity alone.  Note, to stay in electric power, you have to go seriously easy on the go pedal, as the gas engine will fire up at the slightest provocation or incline. This makes driving an un-fun vehicle even less fun, but the payoff comes in stratospheric EPA-rated fuel economy of 87 MPGe. The catch? At nearly $33,000 before options, the plug-in model costs considerably more than the standard Prius. But for now, the Prius Plug-in remains the closest thing Toyota has to an extended-range electric vehicle like the Chevrolet Volt. Given the busy year it had in 2012, the Prius doesn’t change much for 2013, with the only noteworthy news being addition of the new Prius Persona Series, available in black, white, or new Black Cherry Pearl with seventeen-inch wheels, charcoal SofTex interior, and some dark chrome interior trim.

pageElements.text: An all-new gen-four RAV4 makes its debut for 2013, although at the time of this writing, Toyota’s lips were still sealed on the details. We expect, however, that Toyota dealers may have a few 2012 RAV4s sitting around well into 2013, so what about that model? Well, the gen-three RAV4 has never been a shabby ride, having grown about as large as a compact crossover can get and still be considered “compact.” It even offers a vestigial third-row seat, although that’s a place we only recommend for compact people. The front two rows offer good views and space for four adults, and spendy types can select from a laundry list of options, including leather seats, navigation, and an audio system with EnTune data services and iTunes song tagging. Both of the RAV4’s available engines, a somewhat overburdened 179-horsepower four-cylinder and a 269-horsepower V-6, are available with front- or all-wheel drive. We prefer the V-6 not just for its passing power, but because its highway fuel economy remains close to that of the four-cylinder. California residents may also consider the new, all-electric RAV4, which was introduced in late 2012 for about $50,000, minus a $7,500 federal tax credit and a $2,500 state tax credit. Based on the 2012 model with some cosmetic refinements that make it both more distinct and more aerodynamic, the RAV4 EV is expected to continue unchanged well beyond the introduction of the all-new 2013 RAV4, which is set to make its debut by the end of 2012.

pageElements.text: How is it that, while so many car companies struggle with the task of fielding a worthy compact sport sedan, Volvo easily scored a win with the S60? The company’s bestseller holds its own against tough competition, providing American buyers with an appealing alternative. Now available with all-wheel drive, the T5 is the base model, succeeded in the range by the T6 AWD and the T6 AWD R-Design. Like the optional engines in the C30 and C70, the T5’s turbocharged 2.5-liter five-cylinder engine makes 250 horsepower. The T6 AWD has a 300-horsepower 3.0-liter turbocharged six (325 horsepower in the R-Design model), and all-wheel drive is standard. A six-speed automatic transmission is included with all models. Trim levels are Premier, Premier Plus, and Platinum. The latter adds navigation, a premium sound system, a backup camera, an integrated garage door opener, and active Xenon headlamps. Front and rear parking assistance is available on the R-Design. The S60 keeps up in the technology race, too, adding the standard Personal Car Communicator, first introduced in the S80, which knows from a distance if the car is locked and, thanks to a heartbeat sensor, if an intruder is inside. It even turns on all lights as you approach your car.

pageElements.text: America loves its mid-size sedans. But poor Dodge wouldn’t know about that; it hasn’t been a player in that segment for decades. When its current offering, the Avenger, came along in 2008, adopting the window treatment and muscular rear fenders of the big Charger sedan, customers ran in horror once they drove it—that is, if they could get past the wretched interior. Dodge gave the Avenger a thorough make-over for 2011, although no one seemed to notice, since the bulk of the work was done in places no one could see. The car’s sloppy handling was cleaned up, and a fabulous new 283-horsepower V-6 engine was offered. With its standard six-speed automatic transmission, V-6-powered Avengers achieve decent fuel economy (29 mpg highway). A four-cylinder model is offered, too, although with its antiquated four-speed automatic, highway mileage is not a lot better (31 mpg). The interior was simply revolutionized, with soft-touch material everywhere, edgy new color schemes, and handy connectivity features. In the end, the Avenger became a decent car overall. However, that was 2011, and nothing about the Avenger has changed much since then…except, that is, its competitive set, which now includes fresher (and better) mid-sizers from pretty much every carmaker that offers one. The Avenger’s sole claim to fame for 2013 is its status as the cheapest entry in the segment, as it should be. Its replacement is expected by 2014, which can’t come soon enough for Dodge.

pageElements.text:
Coast through the streets of any American city in a Challenger, and prepare for many prolonged stares, thumbs up, and requests to rev the engine. Seriously, Dodge’s charismatic muscle car could be the best wing man (or wing woman) ever in terms of helping shy folks make friends. Despite receiving few updates over the years, the Challenger’s square-jawed styling is as fetching now as ever, with the new Rallye Redline package making even the base model look like a badass. The base Challenger is sort of badass, actually, with 305 horsepower available from its 3.5-liter V-6. Upgrade to the 375-horsepower R/T model to get more power and a pistol-grip manual shifter, or if you simply want to say yes when someone asks you, "That thing got a Hemi?" True horsepower addicts will love the 470-horsepower SRT8, which also happens to come with clever Track Apps that record acceleration, cornering, and braking performance to confirm that, yes, indeed, it really is fast. 

Regardless of what’s under the hood, the Challenger is built using the same big bones as the full-size Charger sedan, making it the only muscle car with five seatbelts. Also, despite its reverently retrospective styling and its intense interior ambiance, the Challenger offers countless luxury and convenience features, including an integrated Garmin-based navigation system, heated leather seats, and, on SRT8 models, an eighteen-speaker sound system with 900 watts that shouldn't have any problem drowning out the intoxicating exhaust note. But then, who’d want to do that?

pageElements.text: GMC presents itself as an upscale alternative to Chevrolet, and in no instance is this truer than with the Terrain, GMC’s mid-sized, five-passenger and identical twin to the Chevy Equinox. No bad thing, though, as both vehicles are quite nice overall. The Terrain’s rectilinear styling inside and out attempt to cast a more technical, masculine impression, though it can be seen by some as a bit over the top (particularly that obnoxious grille). The level of feature content is high, however, and fit and finish—a strong suit of GM’s of late—are excellent. Close your eyes (as a passenger, of course) and the smooth ride and quiet cabin may fool you into thinking you’re in a Lexus RX350, particularly in the case of the new-for-2013 Denali model, with its upgraded front shocks. The Denali also features an even glitzier grille, unique wheels, smoked mahogany trim, French seams, and a soft-touch dashboard. But you don’t have to spend Denali money to enjoy the Terrain’s huge, sliding back seat, excellent ergonomics, and complimentary six months of OnStar services. Power brokers may prefer the newly available 301-horsepower V-6, while efficiency-minded customers may gravitate to the 182-horsepower four-cylinder engine that features a transmission with “eco” mode. Even with optional all-wheel drive, the Terrain breaks little ground (pardon the pun) in the market, but it straddles the line between the mainstream and luxury ends of the mid-size SUV crossover class, and as such, is reasonably priced.

metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Evoque Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Evoque here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Evoque is a carryover model, since the stylish SUV was just introduced in 2012. It comes with either two or four doors and is the only two-door in the lineup – and the smallest model the automaker has ever built. The Evoque won major accolades, including being named the 2012 North American Truck of the Year by a prestigious panel of auto journalists. The Evoque marked a major shift for the British brand, which had been known for its boxy SUVs designed to tackle the harshest environment. The Evoque is showing the brand’s softer side. Victoria Beckham, the fashion designer and former Spice Girl, even created an Evoque Special Edition last spring, complete with a matching set of luggage, but the special model has yet to debut on the U.S. market. In the meantime, buyers will be attracted to the original’s appealing design, premium interior, and surprisingly roomy cabin. There is a downside to the sleek styling, however. The narrow windows may limit visibility and the cargo area is not as roomy as you’d expect from a Land Rover. The Evoque is powered by a respectable 240-horsepower 2.0-liter turbocharged inline four-cylinder engine – the vehicle’s sole powerplant. The engine is linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. Fuel economy is so-so at 20 mpg in city driving and 28 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. And just like a designer outfit, the Evoque comes with a high starting price.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

title: 2013 Aston Martin Virage
subTitle: An authentic beauty, cut from distinctive Aston Martin cloth.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Aston Martin Virage
promoTeaser: 2013 Aston Martin Virage
metaTitle: 2013 Aston Martin Virage Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Aston Martin Virage Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Virage burst onto the scene in 2011, holding down the middle ground in the Aston Martin model lineup. The Virage is clearly related to its older Aston Martin siblings, but it has its own refined exterior styling.  The Virage is the whole package; it will take you to sports car heaven. In the Virage, you’ll find plenty of thoughtful touches including Aston Martin’s staple hand-stitched leather. The engine, a 5.9-liter V-12, has power that’s wedged evenly between the DBS and the DB9. Substantial twenty-inch wheels give the Virage more of a weighty and grounded appearance. Aluminum, carbon fiber, walnut, and Bridge of Weir leather are melded to created a modernist interior. Glass switches and leather-wrapped steering wheel are what makes Aston Martin interiors beautiful. Add to that carbon-disc brakes and a ten-setting adaptive Bilstein suspension. What this translates to is a hot sports car that handles with confidence, class, and style.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

3. Optional 1,000-watt Bang & Olufsen BeoSound audio system.

2. Aluminum, carbon fiber, walnut, and Bridge of Weir leather interior.

title: 2013 Audi A6
subTitle: Fresh redesign makes a good thing even better
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Audi A6
promoTeaser: 2013 Audi A6
metaTitle: 2013 Audi A6 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi A6 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Though little has been changed for 2013, the A6 received a full redesign for the 2012 model, bringing it up to date with Audi’s fast-improving technology. Technical improvements include a more rearward position for the engine and 60/40-split, all-wheel drive (emphasis on the back wheels) to give it that sports car feel we all crave. The available supercharged V-6 engine is capable of going from 0 to 60 mph in a speedy 5.3 seconds. The A6 has a luscious interior, with sleek lines and nice materials. An available navigation system has a Google Earth interface and can be set up as a mobile hotspot for up to eight devices. There is even a touchpad that can read your handwriting, though writing on the nav system with one eye on the road is probably at least as dangerous as texting while driving. Luckily, the A6 also includes lane departure warning, blind spot warning, and Audi Pre-Sense Plus, which will take various safety measures including autonomous braking and seatbelt tightening in the half-second before a collision. The A6 seems to have few downsides, though the loss of the wagon model from previous years still stings.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

2. Despite impressive power, still manages more than 30 mpg highway.

title: 2013 Nissan GT-R
subTitle: The Nissan GT-R used to offer supercar performance for a less-than-supercar price, but buyers should be prepared for some major sticker shock on the 2013 model.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan GT-R
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan GT-R
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan GT-R
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan GT-R here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Nissan describes the 2013 GT-R as “an incredible value,” but buyers should brace themselves for some major sticker shock this year. The base 2013 Nissan GT-R Premium model starts at $97,820, reflecting a $6,870 increase over the outgoing model. The 2013 Nissan GT-R Black Edition starts at $107,320, reflecting an $11,200 price hike. Still, the GT-R is significantly cheaper than some of its chief competition, most notably the Porsche 911 Turbo. The 2013 GT-R gets performance enhancements, including a boost in horsepower from 530 to 545. It is equipped with a 3.8-liter twin-turbo V-6 engine linked to a six-speed automated manual transmission, but it lacks a conventional stick shift. The GT-R stands out with its distinctive good looks, standard adaptive suspension and four-season potential thanks to all-wheel drive. The suspension on the 2013 model has been retuned and the Black Edition gets a new dry carbon fiber spoiler. The new spoiler is handmade in a limited production run. Six exterior colors are available for 2013, including a four-stage metallic Super Silver. The GT-R scores points for its incredible performance, near-telepathic handling, and nice cabin. But it could be more involving and has a harsh, fidgety ride. Putting the GT-R through its paces on public roads may attract the attention of the local constabulary. To experience its true potential, it must be unleashed on a track.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competitors:
1. Audi R8
2. Chevrolet Corvette
3. Porsche 911 Turbo
4. BMW M3

Cool Tech:
1. On-board driving recorder.

New for 2013:
1. Performance enhancements, including a boost in horsepower from 530 to 545.
2. New blue lighting treatment inside the tachometer ring to match the shift position indicator light.
3. Rearview monitor now standard on all models.
4. New dry carbon fiber rear spoiler on Black Edition.

title: 2013 Audi TT
subTitle: Good things come in small, adorable packages
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Audi TT
promoTeaser: 2013 Audi TT
metaTitle: 2013 Audi TT Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi TT Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Before the R8 came along, the Audi TT was Audi’s sporty coupe in the United States. Sometimes overlooked as just a cute car, the TT is actually fast and well built, and it certainly won’t bore you. The 2012 model year saw the introduction of the very fast RS model (0 to 60 mph in 4.1 seconds), which put an end to complaints that the TT is too precious to perform. Available with either a 2.5-liter five-cylinder engine and manual transmission (the TTRS) or a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine, the TT has something for everyone. The TT’s interior is an interesting meld of racing-car-reminiscent shapes and materials with plush elements like sport seats and an optional navigation system. The exterior styling is just about perfect, exactly what you would expect from an Audi sports car. The TT gets more than 30 miles to the gallon on the highway, which might soften some of the sting of spending $50,000 to $60,000 on something so small. The 2013 model won’t see any massive changes, but new colors will join the TT’s palette, and all-leather, two-tone interiors will be available in the S and RS models. For the truly geeky, there are also new available nineteen-inch performance tires.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

2. Mercedes-Benz SLK

2. Standard driver information system with lap timer.
